DOC.HEADLINE: MIAMI QB COSTA IS HURRICANE TESTED

TEXT.P: As a native of Philadelphia, the town of brotherly hate where fans have booed Santa Claus, Mike Schmidt and Julius Erving, Frank Costa should have been prepared.
He wasn't.

Costa is the senior quarterback for the University of Miami (Fla.). That is the position of pedigree on a team that is famous for national championships and winning quarterbacks. During the past two seasons, Costa has struggled to measure himself against the Hurricanes' Heroes.

He has been benched (last season), booed (last season), blasted (by the media) and battered (by opponents' pass rushes). When Costa leads the third-ranked Hurricanes against top-ranked Nebraska in tonight's Orange Bowl, it will be his final chance to write his legacy at Miami.

``If I play well, people will applaud me. If I play bad, I'll get criticized,'' said the 6-foot-4, 215-pound Costa. ``I used to let little things bother me -- like what people said about me. I've gotten a lot more thick-skinned.
``In high school, I always got a lot of positive press and a lot of fan support. I had never been booed or ripped apart until I came down here. That's just part of being the quarterback down here.''

From Jim Kelly to Bernie Kosar to Vinnie Testaverde to Steve Walsh to Craig Erickson to Gino Torretta, the Miami quarterback torch has been passed. Along the way, there have been four national championships and two Heisman Trophy winners (Testaverde and Torretta).

``I'd love to be mentioned in the same breath with those guys,'' Costa said. ``If we beat Nebraska and I'm linked with those guys, great. If they don't, that's fine. That's something I can't control.''

When Costa's career ends tonight, his numbers will not match his predecessors. If the Hurricanes defeat Nebraska and Penn State loses to Oregon tomorrow in the Rose Bowl, Miami probably would have another championship. But that scenario is a long shot.
But for Costa, his status as a starter in a game as important as the Orange Bowl is a significant accomplishment.

``He's come a long way,'' said Miami offensive coordinator Rich Olson. ``With all the criticism he's had to go through, he's made tremendous strides. He's had a great year. The last couple of days in practice, he's thrown it about as well as since he's been here.''

On Oct.9, 1993, Miami lost to eventual national champion Florida State, and Costa lost his starting job to Ryan Collins. That loss -- a Costa interception was returned for a key touchdown -- became Costa's crucible.

``I was very depressed after that game,'' he said. ``I used to get up in the middle of the night and just drive around. I couldn't eat, even though I tried. I lost 20 pounds in about three to four weeks.''
His teammates realized that Costa was in a personal hell. They tried to help him.
``I really can't imagine what he was going through,'' said sophomore center K.C. Jones of Midland Lee High School. ``He's a tough kid. He not only survived, but he thrived.''
But as he battled his demons and fought to regain his confidence, Costa said, he began to see himself in a different light.
``I grew up a lot after that game,'' he said. ``I went into that game as a 21-year-old kid. I came out of it as a 21-year-old man.''

Collins started the rest of the season and led the Hurricanes to a 9-2 regular season. During Miami's 29-0 shellacking by Arizona in the Fiesta Bowl, Costa played well in relief of Collins. Then, after the game, Costa asked to meet with Miami coach Dennis Erickson.

``I told him I felt like I got blamed for a lot of the stuff that happened last season,'' Costa said. ``I asked him to look me in the eye and tell me that I would have a fair chance to win the job back during spring practice. I figured if I couldn't do that, then I might transfer. When he said he would give me the chance, that gave me a new life here.''
Costa reclaimed his job when he outplayed Collins during spring practice.

Then came a 38-20 loss to Washington on Sept.24 that ended the Hurricanes' NCAA-record 58-game home-field winning streak. The fans and critics focused on a Costa interception that led to a touchdown (the receiver slipped). With Florida State only two weeks away, could Costa win a big game?

Against the Seminoles, Costa's numbers were not impressive. He completed 18 of 32 passes for 177 yards, no touchdowns and two interceptions. But the statistics were overshadowed by Miami's 34-20 victory that served as the starting point to the team's eight-game winning streak.

``He executed the game plan, made some great throws, and he withstood their pressure,'' Olson said. ``The question was, could he win the big game? For a quarterback, being able to win the big game is what they live for. When he was able to win that game, that was a great weight off his shoulders. His confidence, he's just a different guy in practice.''

In the Hurricanes' final regular-season game against Boston College, Costa was sacked six times and knocked down a dozen more. A self-described pocket passer, Costa realizes that if he is going to complete passes, he has to hold on to the ball until the last minute. His toughness has earned his teammates' respect.
``He's taken an enormous number of shots,'' Jones said. ``There have been some games I'm surprised he's been able to walk out of the stadium.''
Costa was asked what advice he would give if asked by a high school quarterback prospect who was considering playing at Miami.

``If he wants to prepare himself for the NFL and to get the most out of himself as a quarterback, he should seriously consider coming here,'' Costa said. ``If he wants to live the college life, have a good time and start for three or four years, he shouldn't come here. Most of our quarterbacks start for two years.
``There's nothing wrong with being a quarterback here. It prepares you for anything. It prepares you for life.''

DOC.HEADLINE: KIDD PASSING TEST WITH MAVERICKS

TEXT.P: Jason Kidd admits he belongs in calf-hugging tube socks, short shorts and Chuck Taylor canvas high-tops.

In an NBA era dominated by 20-somethings obsessed with hanging on the rim after their dunks, striking poses for their commercials and comparing zeros in their bank accounts, the Mavericks' rookie is a breath of fresh air for a rare, dying breed who appreciate the lost art of passing the basketball.

``Some people say I'm a throwback,'' Kidd said. ``I don't know about that. I just love to pass. I guess that appeals to the older generation. Hopefully, I can do my part to make it vogue to pass the ball at any age.''

Kidd's National Basketball Association career is only 25 games old, but there's no hiding where it's heading. Following in the footsteps and chest passes of legendary assist men Bob Cousy, Nate Archibald, Oscar Robertson, Magic Johnson and John Stockton, Kidd seems destined to re-establish the assist as an exciting, marketable basketball play.
``People go to games just to watch Jason pass,'' Mavericks coach Dick Motta said. ``It's been a long time since you heard that about someone.''
Despite struggling with his shooting, Kidd has already proved why the Mavericks paid $54 million for his services.
``He can control a game without scoring a single point,'' teammate Jamal Mashburn said. ``Players like that don't come around very often.''

But for all his playmaking and productive energy, it's Kidd's innate ability to propel a round ball from Point A to Point B with precise efficiency and awe-inspiring flash that is drawing attention from fans and praise from the game's all-time best ballhandlers.

``He's got great instincts,'' said Utah's Stockton, who is on pace to become the NBA's all-time assists leader in February. ``You can see it in his eyes. He has a passion for passing. When he gets the ball, everybody in the arena and his four teammates all perk up. It's like they expect something great to happen.''
Since a spectacular opening night in which he energized a victory against New Jersey with a smorgasbord of behind-the-back and no-look assists, Kidd has excelled.

``I'm getting used to my teammates, and they're getting used to me,'' said Kidd, 21, who occasionally bounces a pass off an unsuspecting teammate's face. ``I'm not real concerned with my stats, except that our record is better than most people predicted.''

His 8.1 assists-per-game average is ninth in the league, a pace that would challenge Derek Harper's team record single-season assist mark of 637 but needs to improve if Kidd hopes to surpass then-New York Knick Mark Jackson's rookie assist record of 868. Kidd's contract, however, contains no assist incentives.
``I wouldn't have dared asked for bonuses for assists,'' said Kidd, who has 202 assists and 79 turnovers. ``When I make an assist, I'm just doing my job. That's why the Mavericks drafted me.''
It's also why his idol, Johnson, speaks so highly of Kidd.

``He's impressive, fun to watch,'' said Johnson, the current all-time assists leader with 9,921. ``What I like is that after one of those plays where he jumps in the air, looks one way and goes behind his back the other way to set up a dunk, he just busts his butt back on defense. You've got to love his attitude. He's a player.''

Kidd, accustomed to but still not comfortable with gushing compliments, shies away from any comparisons to Hall of Famers such as Johnson, Robertson and Cousy, who never shot above 39 percent in any season but is considered one of the NBA's founding fathers of assists after leading the league eight consecutive seasons from 1952 to '60.

``People can mention me in the same sentence with Magic and Cousy because that would be proper English,'' Kidd joked. ``But there's no comparison. I'm just a rookie learning the ropes. Someday, maybe.''

Kidd said there's nothing magical about his play, explaining that fast-break, no-look assists are a natural part of his pedigree developed as the youngest, shortest player on the blacktop courts in Oakland, Calif.
``When you're the 10th guy picked to play,'' Kidd said, ``you pass the ball or you don't get picked again.''

Not all of Kidd's ability is natural. Sure, he has the physical hand-eye coordination to thread the eye of a needle in a haystack, but he also has a quick-thinking mind that appears to keep him one step ahead of the other nine players on the court.
Consider the mental checklist Kidd goes through upon grabbing a rebound, making a steal or receiving an outlet pass en route to an assist:
``First I have to identify where the other players are and figure out where they're going to be in the next couple of seconds. Knowing the personnel is half of the solution.''

``After looking for a long pass possibility, I determine by personnel and pure numbers whether to push the ball or not. A lot goes into that, like realizing who is on my left, on my right, who is back on defense and what the game situation is.''

``If I decide to break, I've then got to decide what's the best setup. Is it to give it to Jamal on the left against a good defender with four fouls, to Jimmy (Jackson) on the right against a poor defender with one foul or to take it to the hole myself?''

``That's the hard part. Once I decide what to do, though sometimes that's not until I'm in the air, that's when I've then got to determine which type of pass to use -- chest, bounce, no-look, behind-the-back or invent something new. At that time it's a matter of executing a pass I've thrown thousands of times.''
If it sounds complicated, remember that Kidd produces those decisions and actions in about the same amount of time it takes to read this sentence.

``Behind every great pass, there is usually a great risk,'' said Motta, who said former Chicago center Tom Boerwinkle is the best pure passer he has coached before Kidd. ``Jason makes great passes, but he usually doesn't take great risks. Some of his best passes aren't flashy at all. But he simply loves to pass. He probably spends nine-tenths of his practice time working on passing and ballhandling. That's a trait a coach can't instill.''
But it's one Motta and other throwbacks can certainly appreciate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOLPHINS, MARINO OUTDUEL CHIEFS AND MONTANA 27-17

TEXT.P: The year's final evening might have been HIS exit as well. For now, Joe Montana has been retired.
He'll have the rest of the Super Bowl tournament to start racking up contemplations.

The surest way to see Montana live in '95 was denied by Dan Marino and the Miami Dolphins, who get the January playoff game. Football's pass-throwing deity and the rest of the Kansas City Chiefs were crunched by Marino's gaudy numbers Saturday, falling 27-17 in an AFC wild-card shootout at Joe Robbie Stadium that some suspect was Montana's last.

``Ain't even thinking about that right now,'' said Montana, the 38-year-old living legend who, until this moment, had overshadowed the statistically superior Marino with four San Francisco championship rings. ``I didn't think I had to think about it.
``It's like asking a fighter after he's lost a championship bout if he'll fight again. You feel bad, but, yeah, the game's fun. I'm having fun with it.''

It had been a decade since Montana and Marino last dueled, and both quarterbacks appeared intent on clarifying how grand a shame that is. Throwing to a standard befitting Super Bowl qualifiers -- as they were in 1984, when Montana's 49ers took the title in a 38-16 rout of Marino's Dolphins -- each had a perfect game going at halftime.
The fun factor then began to dissipate for the Chiefs, who earned this first-round appearance minus Montana for part of the fourth quarter in last week's one-sided victory over the Raiders.

Saturday with its cult figure, Kansas City (9-8) figured to have a comeback shot in this fourth quarter after Marino, long maligned for little success in the big games, guided the Dolphins to a touchdown just before the break and again to start the third.
Kansas City's old reliables faltered at the end, though, with Montana intercepted by J.B. Brown at the Dolphins' goal line with 11:28 left and Marcus Allen fumbling on the Chiefs' next possession.
Miami advances to Sunday's divisional round at San Diego, champion of the AFC West.

``Obviously, we're disappointed,'' said Allen, who picked up 10 of his 64 yards on the fateful carry before strong safety Michael Stewart yanked the ball out of the ex-Raiders back's hands. ``What we thought at the beginning of the season didn't happen. There's no rhyme or reason. It didn't happen. That's life, and you keep playing.''

We'll see about Montana, who, if still bothered by that Raiders-inflicted knee injury, hides pain well. He opened with seven straight completions, moved the Chiefs to all 17 points in their first three drives, was 12 of 15 passing for 178 yards in two quarters and finished 26 of 37 for 314 yards and those two early scoring throws.

Marino's glowing, intercept-free line -- 22 of 29 for 257 yards and two touchdowns -- was just supported by a better defense, as the Dolphins beat Kansas City a second time to go with a 45-28 victory here Dec. 12 with Steve Bono in for Montana.

``I don't know whether he's lost anything or not,'' Dolphins linebacker Bryan Cox said of Montana. ``Everybody wants to make a god out of him. I'm not looking to make a god out of anybody. He's had a great career, he's a future Hall of Famer, but I can't be concerned with that.''
Marino added, ``There were no scores to be settled.'' Asked to share his post-game conversation with Montana, Marino replied: ``There were too many people around. I just wished him good luck.''

Montana might have used up his good fortune in the first half. From the first series, he was flawless, displaying a touch that came through clearest on a looping, just-before-the-contact connection with Allen for 16 yards.

On the opening drive, Montana was 6 of 6, capped by a 1-yard toss to Derrick Walker after just 6:28. After the Dolphins retaliated -- Bernie Parmalee's 1-yard run made it 7-7 -- Montana needed just four plays for another score.

To that point, he was 9 of 10, the only errant pass being an underhand shovel under pressure from Cox. On the next play, Cox ended up helping the Chiefs, propelling Kimble Anders down a wide-open sideline by failing to hold on after the hit on Anders' catch of a screen.

The first hint of Montana's mortality came at the Miami 3 on third down with the Dolphins within 14-10. Looking for Eric Martin, Montana sailed the pass behind him, and settling for a field goal gave Marino an opening to tie it before the half closed.

Marino did (a 13-play, 80-yard march ending on a 1-yard pass to Ronnie Williams), and again to open the third. Unruffled by James Saxon's drop of an uncontested pass from Kansas City's 7, Marino found Irving Fryar for a touchdown on the next play for 24-17.
When the Chiefs punted away on a fourth-and-1 from Miami's 47 halfway through the third, Marino responded by taking the Dolphins to points anyway, Pete Stoyanovich's 40-yard field goal.

``My feeling on that, I don't want to give them (such good field position) in a seven-point game,'' Kansas City coach Marty Schottenheimer said. ``That QB is too good. You have to make them play on a longer field.
``In the final analysis, you give them 27 points and that's a handful to overcome. The quarterback is extraordinary. He hasn't achieved everything he's achieved with mirrors.''

Marino certainly didn't need any help, but willingly took it on the field-goal drive when the Chiefs tacked on a face-mask penalty to the first playoff reception for UCLA alum Scott Miller, moving the ball to Kansas City's 28.

``Look, we had our chances,'' said Chiefs cornerback Mark Collins, the former Cal State Fullerton standout who victimized the Raiders with an interception for a touchdown just seven days prior. ``We didn't do it. That's the bottom line.
``The other guy had a great game, and that was basically it.''
For the Chiefs' season, yes. For their quarterback ...
``I assure you,'' Schottenheimer said, ``I didn't broach the topic.''

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY PAPERBACK RELEASES
DOC.TEXT:
LIVE FROM THE BATTLEFIELD. From Vietnam to Baghdad: 35 Years in the World's War Zones
By Peter Arnett. Touchstone/Simon Schuster, $14.
A reporter who has covered conflicts all over the globe, most recently the gulf war, describes the dangerous work that has earned him many distinguished prizes, but also the criticism of senators and Presidents. His memoir is ``lean and clear ... rich in anecdote, redolent in its description,'' Bill Keller said here last year.
THE SILENT CRY
By Kenzaburo Oe. Translated by John Bester. Kodansha International, $11.
This 1967 novel by last year's winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature concerns two brothers who have come back to their ancestral village in western Japan. One turns inward, contemplating personal crises; the other tries to mobilize the local youth against a predatory Korean merchant. Writing in The New York Times last year, Sarah Lyall called the book ``among Mr. Oe's most famous works.'' Grove has also reissued new paperback editions of two works of fiction by Oe, both translated by John Nathan, and an anthology he edited. A PERSONAL MATTER ($7.95) draws on the author's own experiences as the father of a handicapped child. The protagonist, called Bird, cannot accept the birth of his brain-damaged son, and withdraws into thoughts of escape and infanticide before accepting responsibility for the frail baby. ``It owes obvious debts to Kierkegaard: the search for -- and confrontation with -- the self,'' James Toback said here in 1968. TEACH US TO OUTGROW OUR MADNESS ($11) consists of four short novels that explore themes ranging from mental and physical illness to Japanese-American relations. THE CRAZY IRIS: And Other Stories of the Atomic Aftermath ($11), edited by Oe, includes work by various writers and translators. Most of the authors were victims of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and their fiction captures their history and that of their country. In 1985, our reviewer, Fumiko Mori Halloran, said they ``seem to have reached the same conclusion -- the best way to express their feelings was to restrain emotions and concentrate on facts.''
AT THE HAND OF MAN: Peril and Hope for Africa's Wildlife
By Raymond Bonner. Vintage, $12.
The author concentrates on the African elephant, a species that can be as destructive to its environment as man is to his. He argues that culling the herds is necessary to preserve them -- a view many animal rights proponents oppose. The book's ``greatest value ... is that it shows how complex the realities of conservation really are,'' Ian Tattersall said here in 1993.
THE PALACE THIEF
By Ethan Canin. Picador USA, 175 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10010, $10.
These four long fictions illuminate the lives of men who are trying to make their way in a world that has passed them by, largely because of their own failings. Last year, our reviewer, Abby Frucht, praised ``Mr. Canin's habit of tightening a character's grip on ordinary, dependable objects, only to allow those objects to detonate in a vast psychological minefield.''
DEN OF LIONS: Memoirs of Seven Years
By Terry Anderson. Ballantine, $5.99.
The author recalls both his ordeal as a hostage of Islamic fundamentalists in Beirut and his relationship with the Lebanese woman, now his wife, who gave birth to their daughter while he was captive. ``Beyond its compelling reportage,'' the book is ``an improbable and moving love story,'' Eugene Kennedy said here in 1993.
DOGS OF GOD
By Pinckney Benedict. Plume, $10.95.
The scene is the West Virginia mountains, where an amoral drug lord named Tannhauser rules over an abandoned military post until he is challenged by an idealistic boxer. Last year, our reviewer, Marilyn Stasio, said the author writes ``with the lyrical exactitude of Henry Thoreau on a metaphysical field trip to hell.''
MORE HOME COOKING: A Writer Returns to the Kitchen
By Laurie Colwin. Harper Perennial, $12.
This posthumously published collection includes more of the author's tributes to food and its pleasures, whether it is fresh biscuits, free-range eggs, or a chocolate cake from childhood. ``Read as they were meant to be, Laurie Colwin's food thoughts are like phone calls from a dear friend,'' Laura Shapiro said here in 1993.
PALAIS-ROYAL
By Richard Sennett. Norton, $11.95.
Two brothers, one an architect and the other a priest, illustrate different sides of the Romantic imagination in this novel, which takes place in mid-19th-century Paris and London and features cameos by the likes of Balzac and George Sand. In 1987, our reviewer, Richard Holmes, called it ``exhilarating and amusing to read.''
SONGBIRDS, TRUFFLES, AND WOLVES: An American Naturalist in Italy
By Gary Paul Nabhan. Penguin, $10.95.
The author, an ethnobotanist, trekked 200 miles across the Italian heartland in 1990 for both professional and personal reasons: to study the world embraced by St. Francis and to seek solace from a messy divorce. The result is ``as satisfying as a shot of grappa with a plate of anisette cookies,'' Peter Bernhardt said here in 1993. More reflections on nature are to be found in two books by Roger B. Swain, both reissued, with new introductions, by Lyons Burford. FIELD DAYS: Journal of an Itinerant Biologist ($12.95) explores everything from ``hamburgers and houseplants'' to ``sophisticated fly-paper.'' In 1984, our reviewer, Linda Yang, called it ``subtle and positively sparkling.'' EARTHLY PLEASURES: Tales From a Biologist's Garden ($12.95) celebrates the cultivation of human relationships as well as the planting and preparing of vegetables. In 1981 our reviewer, Ken Emerson, said the author ``is able, like most good essayists, to think big thoughts and small thoughts at the same time.''

DOC.HEADLINE: `EAKINS AND THE PHOTOGRAPH'

TEXT.P: Hailed by many critics as the greatest American artist of the 19th century, Thomas Eakins has long been an almost mythical character. His blend of meticulously detailed realism and psychological insight has been proclaimed a particularly American style of painting; the story of his dismissal from his teaching position in 1886 for removing the loincloth from a male model before a female drawing class has been endlessly recounted as an example of the modern artist's commitment to visual truth in the face of provincial prudery.

But as often happens, the legend of Eakins has obscured the complexities of his work and life. Instead of seeing him simply as a Modernist hero, recent scholars have tended to regard him as a figure whose checkered career, with its early successes and later disappointments, raises a host of questions about what it meant to be an artist in late 19th-century America.

A central topic in this reconsideration of Eakins is his long involvement with photography. ``Eakins and the Photograph,'' a catalogue of images by the artist, his family and students taken from the collection of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, offers a somewhat specialized look at an important and problematic aspect of his career.

Eakins took up photography around 1880, and over the next two decades made extensive use of the medium. Not only did he take photographs as sketches for some of his most famous paintings, from ``The Pathetic Song'' (1881) to ``The Swimming Hole'' (circa 1883), but he also created nude studies for his classes at the Pennsylvania Academy, where he taught from 1876 to 1886.

Many artists of the day welcomed photography as an aid to drawing, but Eakins appears to have taken it more seriously. He often enlarged his pictures, then a difficult operation, and printed them with the demanding platinum process.

Eakins's platinum prints, some of which are included in a small show of his paintings and photographs now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, are replete with sharp detail and delicate tones. But they also have a shimmering, hazy quality out of keeping with the precise, clearly delineated style for which he is renowned.
Many of the pictures in the academy's collection are portraits and show the attention to nuances of expression that characterizes his paintings of individuals.

A few are landscapes and studies of such genre subjects as shad fishing in Gloucester, N.J. Others are examples of the motion studies that he carried out in 1884-85 alongside Eadweard Muybridge, the photographer whose pioneering studies of people and animals in motion are often credited with leading to the invention of the motion picture.

But the largest group of photographs consists of nude studies, a fact that at first seems curious, given that Eakins rarely included nudes in his paintings. The essayists in ``Eakins and the Photograph'' spend much of their time trying to figure out what these pictures meant to Eakins, and to place them in the context of the time.
The most intriguing, and convincing, analysis of Eakins's use of the nude in his photographs is offered by Elizabeth Johns, a professor of art history at the University of Pennsylvania.

Professor Johns suggests that Eakins's practice of having students pose nude for him and for one another, and of himself posing without clothes for photographs, was not, as he claimed, simply a way to further the study of anatomy that he believed was central to an artist's education.

Nor was it just the product of repressed sensuality and latent exhibitionism on Eakins's part, though he was involved in enough incidents that echo the loincloth episode to make clear that, at the least, he had a predilection for courting scandal.

Instead, Professor Johns suggests, such practices reinforced a sense of artistic community among Eakins and his pupils and strengthened the idea that artists were outside the moral constraints of conventional society.

Eakins may also have been looking back to his days as a student in Paris, where, as Anne McCauley writes in her essay, academic photographic studies of nudes for artists were a tradition. Or he may have been looking even further back, to an Arcadian past exemplified by classical Greek sculpture, or to a sylvan paradise; in a notable series taken outdoors, he photographed himself and his wife nude with a horse. But in a time when images, and particularly photographs, with even the slightest hint of sexual content were widely condemned, Eakins's unorthodox behavior was bound to draw censure.

As Mary Panzer makes clear in her contribution to the book, Eakins had a genuine interest in anatomy and the engineering of the body: the course of instruction he set up at the academy included dissecting cadavers, and in 1894 he addressed the Academy of Natural Sciences in Philadelphia on ``The Differential Action of Certain Muscles Passing More Than One Joint,'' illustrating the talk with his own photographs of the functions of a severed horse leg.

Given the current interest in artists' personal lives, it is tempting to psychologize about Eakins's behavior. But to regard him and his art simply as the sum of his neuroses or compulsions, real or rumored, overlooks important issues about his work.

What was the relationship of his photography to the careful method he followed in his painting, which was based on extensive analysis and research into his subjects? How exactly did he regard his photographs, particularly the nudes?
``Eakins and the Photograph'' offers no definitive answers to these and other questions, but it raises them in ways that are both provocative and insightful.
EAKINS AND THE PHOTOGRAPH Works by Thomas Eakins and His Circle in the Collection of the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts
By Susan Danly and Cheryl Leibold, with essays by Elizabeth Johns, Anne McCauley and Mary Panzer
Illustrated. 235 pages. Smithsonian Institution Press for the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. Cloth $85; paper $34.95.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRANNY CRADOCK, BRITISH TELEVISION COOKING TEACHER, DIES AT 85

TEXT.P: Fanny Cradock, who won a niche in British social history by teaching luxury-starved Britons to cook better after the austere years of World War II, died on Dec. 27 in a nursing home in East Sussex, England. She was 85.

Mrs. Cradock, garbed in gems and evening gowns, enlightened television viewers with hundreds of how-to-cook programs, which began in the early 1950s and were influential in Britain for years. Her television career lasted until the late 1980s.
The programs also featured her amiable kitchen partner, companion and, eventually, husband, Maj. John Cradock, an alumnus of Harrow who sported a monocle and a tuxedo.
In addition, the Cradocks wrote columns for British newspapers. Her writings included ``The Practical Cook'' (1949) and ``The Ambitious Cook'' (1950), and she also wrote books jointly with the major.

``The Cradocks' secret was the snobbery and pretension of the times,'' the British newspaper The Independent recalled on Thursday. ``In the postwar era they made their hungry, servantless readers and viewers feel they still belonged to an elite.''

Mrs. Cradock was also known for such comments as, ``The British housewife's greatest handicap is the British husband -- who just wants what mum used to make.'' In 1956 she got into a dispute with Raymond Oliver, a chef appearing on French television, when he suggested that men were better cooks than women.

Mrs. Cradock, originally named Phyllis Primrose-Pechey, learned about cooking as a girl, from hotel cooks and her grandmother. Her father went bankrupt and she was a vacuum-cleaner seller, dressmaker, newspaperwoman and novelist.
The major died in 1987. She is survived by two sons.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHRIMPLAND INHERITING ORANGE BOWL

TEXT.P: They're shifting the game called the Orange Bowl to the land of the shrimp-eaters. In 1997, the Orange Bowl game will be played in the swanky confines of Joe Robbie Stadium, where the wealthiest fans can ingest crustaceans behind air-conditioned glass and use private plumbing without having to mix with those sweaty people out there in the stands.

This is the future of sports. America's going soft. The children are playing video games instead of hide-and-seek or catch-a-fly-is-up. We might as well get used to it. Much of the upwardly mobile mischief committed by our benefactors who run big-time sports is done in the name of luxury boxes, the money-producing inner sanctums.

Now it's even happening to the venerable madness of the Orange Bowl game. The officials should have moved the game next year rather than wait until 1997. It's not going to be the same without the old joint being the center of the universe.

Bizarre, compelling things have happened very late at night in the New Year's game, very often affecting the national title of college football. That legacy continued Sunday night. If Nebraska happened to beat Miami, Nebraska would be undefeated and probably maintain its edge over Penn State in the polls. But if Miami happened to beat Nebraska, that would leave it up to Penn State to beat Oregon in the Rose Bowl this afternoon.

``I'm sure Joe Paterno is out there thinking this is out of his hands,'' said Tom Osborne, the Nebraska coach. ``I don't get caught up in it. I just hope we play well. I'd love to win a national championship, but it depends on the ballot box. The luck of the draw, when you play 'em, where you play 'em.''
This is nothing new for Penn State, which claims to have been jobbed out of three national titles by the anarchic system of polls.

But come to think of it, who told Penn State to join the Big Ten, casting its fate with schools stretching all the way out to Iowa? Who told Penn State to join a conference that is committed to playing in the Rose Bowl into the next century? That's Penn State's problem.

And it will be the Big Ten's problem again next year, when the new coalition takes over, rotating the two top available teams among the Fiesta, Orange and Sugar bowls. That means that only once every three years can the Orange Bowl affect the national title. That's kind of too bad, because the Orange Bowl has been the hot bowl of the 80s and 90s, making the Cotton Bowl totally obsolete and the Rose Bowl usually irrelevant.

Who will forget Miami edging Nebraska, 31-30, for the 1983 title? Certainly not Osborne, the Jimmy Stewart look-alike who bravely went for a 2-point conversion. Osborne walked into the Orange Bowl last week and admitted he had ``mixed feelings'' about the place, and he added, ``I'm not necessarily sad to see it go.''
He's also lost Orange Bowls to Oklahoma, Clemson and Florida State in this house of horrors.

But then again, Notre Dame had a touchdown called back for a penalty against Colorado for the 1990 title and Oklahoma was bushwhacked by Miami for the 1987 national title. And the Miami players have come to identify the crumbling palace as their extra weapon even though their 58-game undefeated streak was ended by Washington in September.

``It's our home,'' said K.C. Jones, the Miami center. ``It makes us real confident. At night, there's something different. People have been partying all day, most of them are intoxicated, and they let it loose on the other team. I wish we could play at night all the time here.''

He loves the crowd, that unique Cuban, Jewish, African-American, Southern, glad-to-get-away-from-road-salt-and-overcoats, northern-capital-of-Latin America crowd that converges on the Orange Bowl on select occasions.
``It's not really a melting pot, but it's a tossed salad, the epitome of South Florida,'' Jones said with great affection.
Jones has enjoyed standing on the sidelines watching visiting quarterbacks trying to change signals while the great majority of 78,000 fans screamed their south Florida lungs out.

In two years, a big chunk of the Orange Bowl crowd will be behind insulated, tinted glass -- unseen, unheard, but wolfing down those shrimp and that cocktail sauce. With video games for the kids, no doubt.

DOC.HEADLINE: `IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF BUDDHA'

TEXT.P: If the romance has gone out of travel, blame television and all those old movie travelogues. The urge to go trekking to far-off places can be considerably diminished by films that, even if sketchy, give the armchair tourist a fairly good idea of what it's like being there, but without the burdens of luggage and surly waiters. The better the television documentary, it seems to me, the worse for travel agencies.

Among the best of those television excursions is the current PBS series ``Legendary Trails'' (an inadequate title that suggests dull hikes through dreary woods). The four programs, produced by the BBC and each narrated by an expert author or journalist, travel to places considered sacred by pilgrims of various religious stripes.

As George Page, executive producer for Channel 13, observes, ``You don't have to believe in anything particularly religious or spiritual to be awed by the variety and difficulty of the journey people have made for the sake of their souls.''
The series began by following the ancient frankincense trade route from Oman to Jerusalem, retraced by the broadcaster Emma Freud, a great-granddaughter of Sigmund.

Then Nicholas Shakespeare, a novelist and critic, joined 60,000 pilgrims atop a glacier in the Peruvian Andes, where Jesus is said to have appeared to a young goatherder 200 years ago. Shakespeare's theatrics, replete with unsubstantiated claims, were the weak point of the series.

Monday night, Alexander Frater, the chief travel correspondent for The Observer in London, follows ``In the Footsteps of Buddha,'' beginning in Katmandu, Nepal, now a refuge for thousands of Tibetans fleeing China, and moving through Hindu India to reach Bodh Gaya, Buddhism's most sacred shrine. Explaining that Buddhism urges followers to be ``not too hard on yourself, but not too indulgent, either,'' Frater travels through a land of stunning contradictions, finding at one point gentle monks protecting a little boy thought to be the reincarnation of a venerated monk, at another a nearly deserted town overrun by crime and corruption.
There are some almost surreal moments. Frater comes across another Buddha in the form of Keanu Reeves when he runs into the cast and crew of the Bernardo Bertolucci film ``Little Buddha.''

Frater makes a quick exit from the ornate set, noting ``I must leave this palace of illusions.'' In the end, he concludes that India offers a new dimension that ``can fill your mind, even your whole life.''

Next week, the series ends with the novelist David Lodge on ``The Way of St. James,'' or El Camino de Santiago, the 1,000-mile pilgrimage route from Le Puy in France to Santiago in northern Spain. Technically, to receive a compostela, or official verification, the journey is supposed to be made on foot. But Lodge confesses, ``The constraints of time and television compelled me to cheat a little on my pilgrimage.'' He adds, ``In fact, I cheated quite a lot.''

Although High Mass in Santiago is somewhat disappointing for Lodge (``The sermon didn't set the pews alive''), he finds solace in pondering the long, tangled history of the pilgrimage: ``a mixture of piety, superstition, commercial exploitation, nationalistic sentiment and superb art, all inspired by a legend with no historical foundation whatsoever, yet capable of exerting its magnetism even in our skeptical modern age.''

Add stunning photography, and ``Legendary Trails'' is almost enough to make every viewer sign up for the next pilgrimage package tour. Almost. As for this hopelessly lazy traveler, it's not likely I'll end up reading any pilgrimage guide book. I saw the movie.
LEGENDARY TRAILS In The Footsteps of Buddha PBS, Monday night at 8.

A production of the BBC in association with WNET in New York. John Heminway and Chelle Tutt, producers for WNET; John Blake, executive producer, and Sally Doganis, series producer, for the BBC; George Page, and Linda Romano, executive producers for WNET.

Penn State is a day late and perhaps a ranking short. If the stars align, or if Miami were to defeat Nebraska Sunday night, the No. 2 Nittany Lions can win an undisputed national championship. Otherwise, a salute to the Rose Bowl queen will have to do.

Monday's Rose Bowl will be either anticlimactic or climactic, depending on the score in a far-off stadium. At times in Joe Paterno's 68 years, he has seen something like it, so he is not scheduling his New Year's Day dinner around the Orange Bowl.

``I like Tom Osborne,'' Paterno said of top-ranked Nebraska's head coach. ``But I suppose, in the clutch, I'll be rooting for Miami. Because of our kids, of course. We'll watch it the way we always do. It's the night before our game, and if the ball game's on, we'll watch it. If they want to go to bed, go to bed. I've never been one to worry about things I can't do anything about.''

If Miami were to prevail over Nebraska and Penn State gores Oregon in the Rose Bowl, then the 11-0 Nittany Lions will carry Paterno from the field and own their first national title since 1986. If Miami takes Nebraska and Oregon shocks Penn State, then Paterno will have a headache and the Hurricanes will own the title. But if Nebraska and Penn State are both victorious, then it comes down to a poll.
``If so, I may call my Italian friends to see how many votes we've got,'' Paterno said.

At Paterno's age, he would prefer to just smell the roses, and, so, he is obviously at the right place. He is simply happy to be here, Oregon will second that emotion, and may the least distracted team win.

Penn State has perhaps the nation's best running back (Ki-Jana Carter), best wide receiver (Bobby Engram) and best quarterback (Kerry Collins), and 9-3 Oregon acts as if it is shaking in its collective cleats.
``I'd get Kerry Collins to sign my program if I could,'' Ducks tight end Josh Wilcox said.

``Listen,'' said Oregon Coach Rich Brooks, ``Penn State is one of the top two or three teams that has ever played college football. Collins is bigger than any our of linebackers. He hasn't been sacked a lot because people don't even get close.''

But Oregon has an idea: the blitz. It has been the team's recurring theme all season to send their linebackers at all cost and pray for their talented secondary. All-American cornerback Herman O'Berry could be most valuable player, or toast.
``A lot of skeptics think we'll screw it up somehow,'' Brooks said.

Sights and sounds may be deceiving, but the Ducks appear to be the looser group. Paterno has been frightened ever since Carter and Collins took off on a post-season banquet tour -- posing with Bob Hope, for instance -- and his worst nightmare is that they will show rust.
Carter, after his initial practice here, complained of sore legs, and that is all it took to get Paterno cracking the whip. His practices have been closed and, he said, mediocre.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
Brooks, on the other hand, has described his practices as charming, and the workouts have been open to any passerby able to climb through the fence.

These are obviously, then, two teams passing in the night. Penn State players are not allowed to wear earrings; some Oregon players wear three at a time. Penn State players have been careful not to critique Oregon or upset them; Oregon has gone on record rooting for Nebraska.
``I love Nebraska,'' Wilcox said. ``Nebraska's my favorite team. If I'd gotten a recruiting letter from them, I'd have probably framed it.''

For the first time in three years, the Rose Bowl is in breathing distance of a national championship game, and all of the 103,000 tickets have been swallowed whole. And, in reflection this week, Paterno has turned sentimental.

``Listen, this is the first Rose Bowl Penn State's ever been in, for all intent and purposes,'' the coach said, alluding to a 1923 loss to Southern Cal. ``So, there shouldn't be one negative thing about this trip. If we win this football game, this will be one of the greatest seasons Penn State's ever had.''

It would certainly be better than 1969, when the Nittany Lions went 11-0 and still lost out to Texas in the polls. That year, President Nixon even presented the Longhorns with a No. 1 plaque -- late in the season -- and Paterno could not help bringing that up this week.
``One of my most annoying moments,'' he called it. On the other hand, if the stars do not align tonight, if Nebraska does beat Miami, Paterno expects the president to side with him this time.
``Because Hillary's father, Hugh, played for Penn State,'' he said. ``You can look it up.''
In 1934, to be exact.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE PEOPLE WHO DECIDE WHO WILL MAKE MUSIC

TEXT.P: When an orchestra performs, listeners reflexively allocate credit and blame to the conductor and the players. But in the freelance ensembles that account for most of New York City's musical life there is another significant but generally unnoticed force at work. Although the players produce the sounds and the conductors shape them, it is the orchestral contractor who decides which musicians the conductor will face.

Unlike the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, which have permanent rosters and year-round contracts, ensembles like the New York Chamber Symphony, the Brooklyn Philharmonic, the American Symphony Orchestra and the Mostly Mozart Orchestra are assembled from a pool of more than 1,000 freelance musicians who work in the New York area.

Putting these ensembles together requires not only a sense of the players' strengths and weaknesses, but a feeling for the chemistry among them. When contractors discuss performances they have arranged, they tend to speak in terms of authorial pride about the ones that went particularly well, or with uncertainty about the ones in which last-minute changes left them biting their nails.

``We're about to play Bruckner works for brass and choir,'' said Ronald Sell, a hornist who has been the contractor for the American Symphony Orchestra since 1980, when he was elected to the position by the orchestra's musicians. ``Suddenly, there's talk of recording the pieces the day after the performance, and I'm trying to find out if all the players are available. I don't want one group playing the concert and another making the record. Generally, musicians like to record and make themselves available, but I'm not sure yet how this will work out.''

There are more than a dozen major contractors on the classical music side of the business in New York, each juggling symphonic, chamber music and sometimes choral accounts. Some also contract for theater productions and jingle recordings.

The job evolved decades ago as a matter of practical necessity: entrepreneurs who wanted to present concerts realized that the most efficient way to hire an ensemble was first to hire a musician with good contacts.

At the moment the contracting business is in flux. After freelance musicians went on strike last January, the biggest freelance orchestras agreed to establish core rosters. Contractors must call those players first, which means that their control has diminished considerably.
Market pressures have also taken a toll.

``In the last two years, organizations have cut back on the number of performances they are presenting,'' said Glickman, a bassoonist who began contracting in 1952 and now runs Lydian Productions, the biggest symphonic contracting concern in New York. ``Some have cut back by 20 or 30 percent. That hurts, and if it hurts me it hurts the players much more.''

Nevertheless, the field is expanding, and as younger players get into the contracting business, they are challenging established alignments. Last season, for example, Neil Balm, a trumpeter, and Jonathan Haas, a percussionist, formed Gemini Music Productions.

Both highly regarded players, they cut their contracting teeth on independent projects like a concert of Frank Zappa's orchestral music at Lincoln Center two seasons ago. Now they have their first major account, the New York Pops, an orchestra that Glickman contracted until now.

``Actually, our main business is putting together projects and selling them to various halls and series,'' Balm explained. ``Contracting fell into our lap, but since we're both active performers and we know the musicians in New York, we decided that it was something we should do.''

The job is streamlined these days, thanks in part to computers. Usually, contractors and conductors meet well before a performance to discuss how many players are needed, how many rehearsals and concerts are involved and whether the music poses any special challenges. Once the details are seen to, the contractor calculates the costs and usually demands that the musicians' salaries be put in an escrow account.

The next step is working the phones. Balm has about 150 musicians listed in his little black book. Sell has about the same number. Glickman, the contractor for the New York Chamber Symphony, the Mostly Mozart Orchestra and the Little Orchestra Society as well as several choruses, said that his roster includes 400 musicians and that he knows how they all play.

``I also know their idiosyncrasies,'' Glickman said. ``I know who will absolutely not sit in a second violin section, and who won't share a stand with so and so. I don't write these things down, but I seem to remember them. I have to be very conscious of how an orchestra is made up, because I want my orchestras to sound good and I don't want any fights.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

But contractors inherit fights anyway. Relations with the musicians union, for example, have become increasingly complicated. Because virtually all contractors also perform, they are members of the union and are taken into account in the union's fee schedule, which provides for payment at double the normal scale (although some prefer to earn a percentage of ticket sales). Yet the union regards them with suspicion.

``It's a gray area,'' said Bill Moriarty, the president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians. ``In their capacity as players, we protect them. But when they do their duties as contractors, we view them as management representatives. I have to say, they don't have an easy job. They have to call the players, make sure everyone shows up, do the payrolls and see that the musicians get their checks. But before the 1993 contract brought job security to the freelance field, players were subject to contractors' whims, or to changes that might occur if an orchestra changed contractors.''
Contractors, not surprisingly, take a different view. Mr. Sell, of the American Symphony, is one of several contractors critical of the 1993 contract.

``The union pretty much wiped out the freelance field with that contract,'' Sell said. ``When you establish a roster, it's no longer a freelance orchestra, at least not entirely. There is some leeway. If core players are not available I can call a substitute, and since our core is about 60 players, I can call on another 20 or 30 to fill out the orchestra.

``But it means that for a great new violinist or trumpet player, the opportunities are fewer. Freelancing used to be a way for new players to be heard, to get a foot in the door. That can still happen, but it's much more difficult. Essentially, the union has supported a small group of haves over a vast number of have-nots, and it's unfortunate.''

There are different views as well on what Moriarty called contractors' whims. ``Years ago,'' Balm said, ``a contractor could call you and say, if you don't take this gig you'll never work in this town again. I've been on the raw end of that, and it's not fun. But that kind of thing is over. And the beauty of New York is that there are other contractors and you have other options.''

Contractors, in fact, say that there is plenty of abuse on the other side. Sell mentioned a violinist whose playing he admired but who regularly arrived late to rehearsals. ``I didn't do anything about it until a conductor asked me why I kept using her,'' he said. ``So I had to not call her for a while. Then I gave her another chance, and she was late again.''

Sell also mentioned the case of a musician who failed to turn up three times without arranging for a substitute, as musicians are required to do if they are going to miss a rehearsal or a performance. The orchestra's executive director wanted to write to the union demanding disciplinary action. Sell counseled diplomacy, recommending that it would be better to write to the union asking its advice. The union responded by threatening to sue the American Symphony.

And for all the job's perquisites -- the higher pay, the feeling of power and authority and the sense of helping shape an orchestra's sound -- contractors sometimes find themselves pushed to make difficult decisions. When Leon Botstein took over the American Symphony Orchestra in 1991, he insisted that the orchestra's roster be revamped.

``He laid it right out,'' Sell said. ``He said that there were obvious personnel problems that would have to be fixed, and he put that right on my plate. It meant not re-engaging musicians who had been with the orchestra for 20 years. I lost two very close friends because of that. People always blame the contractor because they think you're in a position to fix it. Sometimes you are and sometimes you can't.

``But the bottom line is that the orchestra is much better now than it was two years ago. For me, that's the greatest satisfaction of the job. When a concert goes well and the players leave the stage with the feeling of having accomplished something, then you can hold your head up.''

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTING: REBOUND BOLSTERS INVESTORS IN REIT

TEXT.P: Investors in real estate stocks have developed a case of whiplash this year.

On top of three years of double-digit gains -- fueled largely by record low interest rates -- the stocks cruised upward in the first half of 1994 even when rates began to rise. Their strength belied the conventional wisdom that the category was sensitive to interest rates.

But the stocks soon slid into reverse. As a pattern of rising rates became apparent and new offerings of real estate investment trusts glutted the market, the total return on REITs, which are pools of real estate or mortgages that trade as stocks, plunged 10.4 percent from June through November. That pushed the group to a 5 percent loss for the year, the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts reported.

In December, REIT's staged a strong rally. Now money managers and REIT financial analysts are pointing to the rebound as proof that the overall decline this year is nothing more than a long-overdue correction in a continuing bull market.

At the least, the recent surge has eased some of the pain for investors. Real estate mutual funds, which buy REITs, were the best-performing fund sector for December, rising 6.89 percent on average through Thursday, according to Lipper Analytical Services, a mutual fund research firm in Summit, N.J.
And one young fund, American Capital Real Estate of Houston, gained 9.3 percent. Over all, real estate funds were down 3.28 percent for the year through Dec. 30.

Many financial analysts expect the rebound to continue for weeks as bottom-feeders troll for cheap shares. And for the longer term, they suggest the worst is over for many REITs. That makes the sector attractive for investors seeking high income, diversification and maybe even a hedge against inflation.

``We have seen the bottom of the REIT market, and it has been firming in the past few weeks,'' said James W. Williams, a senior real estate analyst and vice president at Prudential Securities in New York.

As of Nov. 30, the average yield on REITs was 8.1 percent, compared with less than 3 percent for the basket of stocks in the SP 500. The spread between those yields recently hit six percentage points, something that occurred only twice before, in the early 1970s and in 1990, Williams said.
Furthermore, the commercial real estate market appears to be on the rebound after bottoming out in 1993, said Lee Schalop, a real estate analyst with J.P. Morgan Securities.

But skeptics can be found. Frederick S. Carr, president of the Penobscot Group, a REIT research group in Boston, warned that the stocks could plunge to the depressed levels of November if rates rise again. He predicts that when REITs do recover, a new generation of companies will lead the way.

As promising stocks, he cited Developers Diversified of Moreland Hills, Ohio, which owns shopping centers mainly in the East and Midwest, and Post Properties of Atlanta, which develops and operates apartment complexes in the Southeast. Both companies have experienced management, proven assets, low debt and adequate capital.

This year gave rise to 40 initial public offerings of REITs, bringing the number publicly traded to 227, up from 66 in 1982. But the industry owns less than 2 percent of the nation's commercial real estate.
``The market is still young,'' Williams said, ``and we are early in the cycle of securitizing real estate.''

DOC.HEADLINE: FINANCIAL ADVISERS TO THE RICH SET CONSERVATIVE COURSE

TEXT.P: Got a cool $10 million to invest? Whoever Publisher's Clearing House catapults into that elite group on Super Bowl Sunday will have a whole new range of investing options, including the money management services of Bessemer Trust.

Founded in 1907 to manage the $50 million fortune of the steel magnate Henry Phipps, the trust company can point to a blue-blood client list that has even included a blind trust for President George Bush. The typical portfolio is $12 million, and the minimum a far-from-shabby $5 million.

Those who make the cut can drop by Bessemer's oak-paneled offices near Rockefeller Center in Manhattan, or if suffering from post-holiday exhaustion, ask a team of its financial advisers to make a house call.

For everyone outside that moneyed orbit who wonders what such advice is like, Bessemer Trust agreed to lay out its investment suggestions for the coming year. And it conceded that in one way at least, the rich are not very different after all; they, too, had a disappointing year in the markets.

The balanced-growth portfolio recommended by Bessemer Trust a year ago would have lost 1 percent to 2 percent of its value by year-end, estimated Robert C. Elliott, senior executive vice president of the firm, which has $9 billion under management. At the outset, Bessemer projected returns of 9 percent.

``Obviously, one is not happy not to reach the historical return,'' Elliott said, but ``our clients realize that 1994 was an aberration.'' He also noted that Bessemer's recommendation for 1993 would have produced a return of nearly 18 percent.
Michael Stolper of Stolper Co. in San Diego, which evaluates money managers, said equity managers' returns this year were clustered around zero, and he said Bessemer's performance was typical.

He noted, though, that fees at such prestigious firms, which boast of their personal service and their attention to everything from estate planning to tax advice, typically run 1 percent for the first $5 million of assets managed.
In terms of investing, ``You could probably go out and buy the average mutual fund and do just as well,'' Stolper said.

Investors everywhere may be heartened to learn that Bessemer's professionals expect a better year in 1995, with returns on its model portfolio nearing 10 percent. But an air of caution remains. ``We're going to be slightly more conservative than we were last year,'' Elliott said.
In fact, many of the money managers who cater to the wealthy sound rather conservative. None of those reached for this article recommended putting more than 65 percent of one's assets in stocks.

Bessemer's model portfolio for 1994 was 75 percent in stocks, and it is scaling back that portion to 65 percent for the coming year. Among its competitors, the U.S. Trust Company of New York also pegs stocks at 65 percent, unchanged from a year ago.

The investment subsidiary of Swiss Bank Corp. of New York, known as SBC Portfolio Management International, suggests 50 percent in stocks, up from 46 percent a year ago, but shy of the 60 percent it calls typical.

Bessemer rounds out its portfolio with 10 percent in real estate and private investments and 25 percent in a broad bond category. The bond portion is split into three equal piles of short-term cash equivalents, long-term Treasuries and medium-term issues, mostly tax-free municipals.

``Bonds may well be the place to be in 1995,'' Elliott said. Interest rates are peaking, municipal bonds are in short supply and investors have overreacted to the Orange County bankruptcy and other municipalities' financial foibles, he said. After some price erosion early in the year, he predicted, municipal and Treasury bonds will finish 1995 with total returns of perhaps 8 percent.

Frederick B. Taylor, chief investment officer of U.S. Trust, where the typical portfolio runs $25 million, suggests keeping bonds at 35 percent but shifting into issues with maturities of 5 to 15 years, from 1 to 7 years now.
Similarly bullish on bonds, the Swiss Bank officials expanded to 30 percent from 27 percent the bond portion of what they call their balanced growth accounts, which average $3 million.
Over all, they are a bit more aggressive than they were a year earlier, as indicated by moves both to more stocks and to less cash, down to 20 percent from 27 percent.

``We expect a tough year with returns of 5 to 10 percent, but not as difficult as 1994 because the bond market won't detract as much from equities,'' said Lydia J. Miller, the director of SBC. A year ago, the firm predicted a 5 percent gain but said investors merely came out even.

Among equities, Bessemer has dumped most financial and other cyclical stocks, whose earnings will be under pressure if the economy slows, as well as manufacturing companies like Raytheon and Burlington Northern, Elliott said. It continues to favor technology companies, especially software and telecommunications concerns.

For the coming year, it suggests reducing large U.S. stocks to about 30 percent of a portfolio, from 40 percent, trimming foreign exposure to 25 percent, from 27 percent, and increasing the share in small emerging-growth companies to 10 percent from 8 percent.
American companies with global operations account for 25 percent to 30 percent of U.S. Trust's portfolio, up from 18 percent a year ago, Taylor said. Pepsico, Kellogg and Motorola make his list.
Other picks are companies poised to benefit from the aging population, including Johnson Johnson, health-maintenance organizations and companies like Conagra that sell prepared meals.
On the international front, Bessemer recommends putting 40 percent of one's foreign equity investments in emerging markets, including Asia and Latin America.

In Europe, it is shifting from the West to other countries. In Poland, it likes the engineering group Elektrim; in Turkey it favors a linens producer called Arcelik, and in Russia it is considering oil exploration and production companies.
Both U.S. Trust and SBC are more wary of emerging markets. ``We are not in Latin America,'' Ms. Miller of SBC said. ``I'll wait until I see more stability.''

U.S. Trust has loaded up for now on American companies that sell to Latin America and Asia, but likes the long-term prospects in those stock markets. ``We think continued volatility in both regions will provide buying opportunities,'' Taylor said.

On another front, Bessemer stands apart from the pack. It is increasing its real estate and private venture recommendation to 10 percent of the model portfolio from 5 percent a year ago. Among its picks are office buildings and shopping centers in suburban Boston and Washington, where property prices are low.

Forseeing a year of slower economic growth in the United States, a pickup in growth abroad and the possibility of a capital gains tax cut, Elliott expects investors to breathe a sigh or relief and perhaps crack a smile at the end of 1995.
``The biggest risk will be whether a combined tax-spending package out of Washington will increase the deficit or lead to higher interest rates,'' he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: STRATEGIES: FOR A DEAL ON WRAP ACCOUNTS, JUST ASK

TEXT.P: They are not advertising it, but brokerage firms are lowering the fees on their popular wrap accounts.

Generally open to people with $100,000 to invest, a wrap account is overseen by a brokerage consultant who analyzes the client's needs and then places the money with an outside money manager. The lure is the prospect of a top-notch manager who would not normally bother with an account of less than $1 million.

Critics have long complained that the annual cost of such accounts is too high -- up to 3 percent of assets on portfolios smaller than $500,000. The firms counter that the pricing formula is intended to reassure investors that their holdings will not be churned to bolster transaction fees.

No matter, change is rumbling through the industry. In a survey earlier this year, Cerulli Associates of Boston found that the fee on the typical brokerage wrap account had fallen to about 2.3 percent, with even bigger discounts available, depending on the size of the account and the type of investments held.
But an examination of several firms' literature shows that published costs remain as high as ever, suggesting that investors need to ask for the lower prices to get them.

Cerulli said that brokerage houses were sometimes discounting their published fees from 3 percent to as little as 1.2 percent. ``A year ago the houses were far less flexible,'' said Mary McAvity, a consultant with Cerulli, which advises the financial services industry.

Several factors have conspired to push down wrap fees: new rules by the Securities and Exchange Commission, investor disappointment this year, criticism by the financial press and greater competition.

In April, the SEC offered new regulations on wrap accounts after it found that many investors did not understand the layered fees -- with part going to the brokerage firm and part to the outside manager -- and that those fees were often excessive.
As of October, brochures for the accounts must outline fee schedules, list additional charges and say if fees are negotiable, said Robert Plaze, an SEC official
Several brochures, including those from Smith Barney and Prudential Securities, indicate that the total fee for an account of less than $500,000 remains 3 percent in general.

Yet, on the typical portfolio of $240,000, the average cost was 2.3 percent, Cerulli found in its survey of 100 brokerage firms at the end of the first quarter. About 90 percent of the respondents said fees could be negotiated, Ms. McAvity said.

Most wrap account contracts allow investors to quit or renegotiate at any time. ``You could sign today and change your mind tomorrow,'' said Derick Driemeyer, senior vice president of A.G. Edwards Sons, who added that his clients had been negotiating more as the financial markets weakened.
At the least, investors can request changes to take effect at the start of the next quarter, when a new billing period begins.
The first step is to ask other firms for a quote. ``Play off one against the other,'' advised Janice Johnson, a tax lawyer with Coopers Lybrand, the accounting firm.
Concessions may depend in part on the portfolio. An account composed mostly of bonds should cost less to manage than an aggressive portfolio of stocks, Ms. McAvity said.

Another way to save is to ask the firm to split transaction fees and management fees -- called ``unbundling.'' Bertram J. Schaeffer, a partner with the national accounting firm of Ernst Young, said most investors were better off with an all-inclusive fee their first year because many purchases would be made. But ``buy and hold'' investors may want to switch afterward.

At A.G. Edwards, for example, the total fee on a wrap account is up to 3 percent, with the consulting fee typically accounting for 2 percent. By paying for transactions separately, the consulting fee drops to 1 percent. The firm's literature says transactions are then handled at a preferential commission rate.

But critics are not satisfied. Victoria Felton-Collins, a partner in Keller, Coad Collins, a fee-only financial planning firm in Irvine, Calif., said a $250,000 balanced account split evenly in stocks and bonds would pay a first-year fee of about 1.3 percent at her firm. ``We think the person paying for a wrap account is paying more for the service than they should,'' she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLAIMS DEADLINE IS NEAR FOR PRUDENTIAL INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Time is running out for thousands of people to lay claim to a restitution fund created by Prudential Securities, which has set aside $660 million to compensate investors who were defrauded in the sales of its limited partnerships in the 1980s.

Claim forms are to be filed within one year, and since Prudential says all of the forms were postmarked by Jan. 10, 1994, only days remain for them to be returned. Although many people find the process and the paperwork confusing, there is every reason to submit a claim, plaintiff's lawyers and regulators say.
``For the cost of a few stamps, investors can determine if they are eligible to take advantage of the process,'' said Philip A. Feigin, the Colorado securities commissioner.

The claim is the last chance for many people who bought into the Prudential partnerships. That is because the statute of limitations for an arbitration or court proceeding is generally two to six years, while such limits have been waived for the restitution fund.

Prudential initially put $330 million into the pool as part of a settlement with regulators, and later raised the total to $660 million. Its liability is unlimited, meaning the final tally could go higher.

As of Dec. 17, 152,000 investors had submitted claims and 56,000 of them had received $392 million, said Joel F. Brenner, a lawyer with Storch Brenner, a Washington firm assisting with the restitution.
An estimated 30,000 investors are still on the sidelines, said Wayne Klein, the bureau chief of the Idaho Securities Commission.
About 340,000 investors poured $8 billion into 700 Prudential limited partnerships. The partnerships eventually turned sour, creating losses amounting to hundreds of millions of dollars.

Not all of those investors are eligible for restitution, however. The vast majority of the 130,000 who bought energy-income partnerships accepted a $90 million class-action settlement earlier this year. They are precluded from participating now, as are others who have already been to arbitration or to court or who have reached a settlement with the firm. Furthermore, some of the investors are now dead.
The pace of filings has picked up in the last month, Brenner said. Weekly filings are averaging 3,000, double the level of a few months ago.

For restitution, claimants must show that the investments were unsuitable for them, that they were misled by marketing or that they did not receive full and fair disclosure. If they are not satisfied with the offer they receive, they may still turn to arbitration -- but they must act within 90 days.
Investors who have not yet submitted forms can receive assistance by calling (800) 774-0700.

DOC.HEADLINE: TREATMENT OF SEVERANCE

TEXT.P: IRAS AND BENEFICIARIES

Q: I am a widow who will be 70 and a half in 1995, so I must start withdrawals from my individual retirement account. My beneficiaries are my three children, all of whom are, of course, more than 10 years younger than I. How do I figure the required minimum distribution? Does having more than one beneficiary change the rules? Lore Jarmul, Southbury, Conn.

A: For withdrawal purposes, all your beneficiaries are deemed to be 10 years younger, explained Seymour Goldberg, a lawyer in Garden City, N.Y., who is a specialist in retirement distributions. For this reason, you need to use a special number based on life expectancies to calculate your distributions. Details can be found in Appendix E of Publication 590 from the Internal Revenue Service.

In your case, Goldberg said, to calculate the minimum withdrawal amount for 1995, you look at your account balance as of Dec. 31, 1994, and divide by 26.2 (as explained in the booklet). The following year, you would divide by 25.3 and then 24.4 the subsequent year.

When you die, the life expectancy of your oldest child at the time that you turned 70 would become crucial. Suppose she was 45. That would give her a life expectancy of 37.7 years when you turned 70. If you take distributions for five years before you die, your children would subtract those five years from 37.7, meaning they would have to take the remaining money over a period of 32.7 years.

To protect their right to stretch out the payment period, the children must maintain the account in your name after your death. The children can split it into three chunks, however, so that each controls a portion of the account, Goldberg said.

``They should send a letter to the institution asking to have the account split up but maintained in your name,'' he said. For example, the accounts might say ``Mary Smith, deceased, for the benefit of Sally Smith.''
``The mistake many banks and brokerages make is to send a check to the kids or roll the account over to an account for the kids,'' he said. ``Then it becomes immediately taxable.''
TREATMENT OF SEVERANCE

Q: What is the role of severance pay in Social Security benefits? I retired in August, and am receiving 12 monthly checks of $5,163 as severance. The money is fully taxed, but not earned income. Does it affect Social Security benefits? What about the Social Security tax base? Richard V. Bucaria, Middle Village, Queens, N.Y.

A: Severance payments made upon retirement are excluded from the Social Security earnings test, which means your benefits will not be reduced. These payments are included in your adjusted gross income, however, meaning they will affect what portion of your benefits are taxable, said Dale Detlefs, a consultant for William M. Mercer Inc. in Louisville, Ky.

DOC.HEADLINE: `THE NICOTINE WAR' ON PBS `FRONTLINE'

TEXT.P: Remember the lineup of tobacco company executives before a congressional committee last year, chorusing their assurances that nicotine is not an addictive drug and that their companies do not manipulate the amount that goes into their cigarettes? If not, you can see that comical display of corporationally correct thinking Tuesday night on ``Frontline.''

``The Nicotine War'' adds little to news accounts of the campaign by David A. Kessler, head of the Food and Drug Administration, to demonstrate that the cigarette is a means of transmitting nicotine into the body and hooking smokers and hence belongs under his agency's regulatory aegis. But the program does a tidy job of packaging a dispute that, as the narrator notes, involves science, politics, jobs and public health.

The scientific consensus (excepting scientists in the pay of the tobacco companies) is that nicotine is indeed highly addictive, working on the body much like alcohol, cocaine or heroin, although cigarette manufacturers emphasize that it does not have the invidious effects of those drugs. (Lung cancer and heart disease are not directly caused by nicotine.)

Whether cigarette makers purposely add the nicotine to their tobacco is less clear, although as viewers acquainted with ``Frontline'' might expect, the report is not inclined to give the tobacco interests the benefit of any doubt.

Of particular interest to smokers is the news that low-tar, low-nicotine cigarettes actually have as much tar and nicotine as any other cigarettes. The difference is in the filter. If you crave a bigger jolt, you can cover the filter holes with your fingers or put the cigarette deeper into your mouth and inhale strenuously. Then you can have the comfort of smoking a seemingly safer brand yet filling your lungs with as much foul stuff as ever.

``The Nicotine War'' ends with no truce in view. On one hand, a billion-dollar class-action lawsuit against the tobacco companies is being waged by an all-star band of personal-injury lawyers. On the other, control of the House committee that was putting the heat on the companies has passed to tobacco-state representatives more inclined to put the heat on Kessler. Since a crackdown on cigarettes is not part of the Republican contract with America, his future is smoky. After the election, he canceled a scheduled interview with ``Frontline.'' FRONTLINE The Nicotine War

PBS, Tuesday at 9 ET. Written, produced and directed by Jon Palfreman. Michelle Nicholasen, Michaela Barnes, associate producers; Bill Lattanzi, editor; Michelle Nicholasen, Michaela Barnes and Kathy Boisvert, field producers; Will Lyman, narrator

DOC.HEADLINE: A LITTLE SEED MONEY IS PLANTED TO HELP AN ENDOWMENT GROW
DOC.TEXT:
Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., has announced the largest gift from an alumnus in its 46-year history.
Herbert Beigel, class of '66, has donated $3 million to the school's theater program. In return, the university's 750-seat theater will be renamed the Herbert and Nancy Beigel Main Stage Theater.
Beigel, a Chicago-based lawyer, said it was a somewhat dubious distinction to have given the university its largest alumni gift. ``It makes me feel that there should be others making big contributions because Brandeis has a lot of successful alumni,'' he said on Friday in a telephone interview from his vacation home on Cape Cod in Massachusetts.
``Brandeis is still a fairly young institution and it's been challenging for it to develop an endowment. Maybe my gift will inspire other alumni to pay attention.''
Lyle Lovett figures his 15 minutes of fame arrived when he married Julia Roberts 18 months ago.
The press scrutiny and public curiosity that followed their wedding has subsided, Lovett said in an interview in Sunday's Los Angeles Times.
``I think I have definitely peaked in terms of pop culture,'' said Lovett, the singer-songwriter and actor. ``I don't think anything I'll do in my life on a public level will be as newsworthy, and maybe that's a good thing because all I'm interested in doing is what I've always done ... write about my life.''
Fans still ask Lovett to sign the cover of The National Enquirer, one of several publications that have speculated about the state of his marriage since the couple's work schedules often keep them apart.
``You have to keep focused on the reality of this relationship and not on the publicity,'' Lovett said. ``I'm married to this girl and I am in love with her. We have a relationship that doesn't get played in the tabloids ... what you hear about is a fictionalized version.''

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAZILIAN ARTISTS SHOWN IN NEW YORK GALLERIES

TEXT.P: In a neighborhood that still runs a cable car, two Brazilian artists, Waltercio Caldas and Daniel Senise, conceive and create contemporary sculptures and paintings using two totally individual languages.

For Caldas, the appeal of hilltop Santa Teresa is that ``it doesn't have time, just space.'' Space has been a central concern of Caldas for over 20 years, but his intriguing experiments with visual perception have had relatively little exposure in the United States. He attributes the absence of a strong Brazilian presence in the international art world to a ``lack of consciousness of Brazil's cultural complexity.''

Over the last year, Brazil has been more receptive to international exchanges than it had been, both financially and culturally. In May, Mary Sabbatino of Galerie Lelong and Lori Ledis and Robert Flam of LedisFlam Inc., all New York art dealers, were invited by the Brazilian Embassy in Washington to see the Sao Paulo Bienal of 20th-Century Brazilian Artists.
