Ms. Sabbatino said, ``We were bowled over by the incredible richness of the art we saw, and we kept saying, what can we do to bring this to New York?''
Now the works of Caldas, Senise and 14 other Brazilian contemporary artists are to be displayed in 11 exhibition spaces in New York City. The first openings will be on Saturday.

``In America, there has been a lack of exposure to Brazilian art,'' said Ms. Ledis, an organizer of the exhibits, collectively titled Art From Brazil in New York, which will be partly supported by the Brazilian Embassy and the Brazilian-American Cultural Institute. ``There are certainly a lot of stereotypes of what Latin American art looks like. I think people are going to be very surprised at how conceptual, how different Brazilian art is.''
Charles Cowles, another participating gallery owner, said, ``There are certainly no parrots, no pretty hot-colored flowers.''

Historically influential artists like Mira Schendel and Helio Oiticica, both of whom had special rooms at the recent Sao Paulo Bienal, will represent Brazilian art that emerged during the 1950s and 1960s. Monotypes on rice paper and a series called ``Graphic Objects,'' dating from 1967 to 1972, by Schendel will be shown at the Drawing Center. A 1973 audio-visual installation by Oiticica featuring the music of Jimi Hendrix will occupy a room of the Marian Goodman Gallery.

Caldas and Cildo Meireles, who began to explore movement and space in the 1970s, will show sculptures and an installation, a dark room within a room, at Galerie Lelong. Senise will exhibit three series of paintings at the Charles Cowles Gallery. And two newly acclaimed artists will be shown, Nuno Ramos at Brooke Alexander and Adriana Varejao at Annina Nosei Gallery. Other artists will be shown at the Nicole Klagsburn Gallery, the Robert Miller Gallery and the New Museum.

The 48-year-old Caldas, who works here in a studio overlooking vivid orange flamboyant trees, slums and the blue expanse of Guanabara Bay, was born in Rio. During the 1960s, he studied painting at Rio's Museum of Modern Art and first exhibited drawings and objects in 1967. Since then he has annually been exhibiting what he insists on calling ``sculptural moments'' in Rio and Sao Paulo.

In 1993, he participated in group shows in Cologne, Berlin, Venice, Milan, Florence, Rome and Vancouver and in two in New York, at the Museum of Modern Art and at the John Gibson Gallery. He has created large environmental works, using materials as diverse as plants, stones and stainless steel, for public spaces in Sao Paulo, in Punta del Este, Uruguay, and in Norway.

Caldas's interest in the relationship between materials and the space in their midst is present in the three works that will be shown at Galerie Lelong. ``Mirror With Light,'' from 1974, displays a small red light emanating from an ordinary black-framed mirror. In ``Double Untitled'' (1989), two rectangular veils are suspended from the ceiling by nylon strings; polished brass rods hang from the nearly transparent veils and dangle, free to move continuously, touch one another and possibly create distinct sounds on impact. It is an ``an image to hear,'' Caldas says.

In ``Wood-wind'' (1994) a rectangle and a diamond of dark-grained wood hang at a steep angle from a spare, thigh-high wood frame. The artist calls this juxtaposition of wooden angles and air an experiment in ``structural perversity,'' because it goads the viewer to explore the tensions in a resting object, the possibilities of movement in what he calls the ``skin of air.''

There is also an element of mystery in the paintings of 39-year-old Daniel Senise, another carioca, or Rio native. In paint-splattered shorts or carpenter's overalls, Senise has recently been working with a common garden hose, hundreds of small rusting nails, sheets of nearly transparent voile fabric and grand canvases in two vast rooms.
He carefully aligns the nails to follow the path of a boomerang, then sprays a canvas with water and waits to see what rust reaction will remain once he removes the nails.

The flight of a boomerang also appears in several of Senise's paintings to be shown in New York. ``You have the whole story in front of you,'' he said. ``You see the beginning, the whole trajectory, and the end. I am not showing the action, but I am showing the history of the boomerang.''

The history of painting has been a recurring preoccupation of Senise's, and in different series in the last few years, he has used the well-recognized images of Caspar David Friedrich, Giotto and James Whistler.

Since 1983, Senise has been regularly exhibiting in Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo, and has also had solo shows in Paris, Amsterdam, Stockholm, Chicago, Lisbon and Santafe, Spain, and most recently in Monterrey, Mexico. He was one of the artists representing Brazil at the 1990 Venice Biennale and last year at the Museum of Modern Art.

References from Giotto's ``Last Supper,'' Friedrich's landscapes, 18th-century English silhouettes and current children's books are used in the three other series Senise will have on exhibit in New York.
``Daniel cannot abandon completely the image in his paintings,'' said Tomas Cohn, a gallery owner who represents Senise here. ``This is very Latin American.''

Brazil's wealth of artistic expressions should not be readily defined as merely another example of ``Latin American'' art, however. As Marcoantonio Vilaca, a prominent gallery owner in Sao Paulo, said: ``Daniel and Waltercio offer two distinct artistic thoughts, proof of the various propositions of Brazilian art.''

DOC.HEADLINE: ESSAY: ROYALTIES IN OFFICE

TEXT.P: As a Nixon speechwriter a generation ago, I was delighted to get a check for $150 from The New York Times for a piece about language. I told the White House counsel I would keep it because the article had nothing to do with my official duties and was written on my own time.
Counsel said to send the check back. Why? Because I was working full time for the U.S. government and it would be unethical to earn money on the side.

I grumped about returning the payment, but was gratified we had someone keeping the White House on the strait and narrow. (The counsel was John Dean, who later served time and gained bankable fame as architect of the Watergate cover-up; the only ethics he worried about were mine.)
This episode of denial of outside income was brought to mind by the case of speaker-to-be Newt Gingrich's $4.5 million book deal.

When first revealed, his contract to receive an advance of royalties expected from two books caused a furor. Newt at first dismissed the reaction as ``book envy,'' a play on ``penis envy,'' pointing to piddling advances paid to liberals in the past.
Newt had no sense of how unseemly his bonanza was -- making it appear that the Republican scourge of society's freeloaders was promptly cashing in on his new position.

Two critics saved his neck. Democratic whip David Bonior, always against free trade, went overboard in professing to see a remote conflict of interest in the deal in the control of the publisher by Rupert Murdoch, whose interests may be affected by legislation. Bonior's excessive, partisan blast made Newt look put-upon.

The speaker was assisted further by an editorial in The New York Times, which suggested an apparently ethical way out: ``He can forgo an advance and simply wait for the royalties to come in once the books are actually on sale.''

Newt seized that opening and ran to daylight. As Bob Dole needled him and talk show hosts hollered ``sellout,'' author Gingrich circulated a letter to his House colleagues announcing he would ``forgo four and a half million dollars,'' awaiting the royalties after the books were sold.
Editorialists hailed his self-denial. Republicans in Congress heaved a sigh of relief, as if he had dealt forthrightly with impropriety.

But his quick fix misses the point. The ethical issue is not whether he gets paid in advance. The issue is how much, if any, outside income a public official should be permitted to earn while on the public payroll.

Is it right for an elected official, drawing a salary from the public for his full-time talents, to capitalize on the celebrity and controversy gained through his office by writing books -- or for that matter, by giving speeches, endorsing products or earning outside income in any way?

It's not against the law. Nor is it unprecedented: Gingrich showed us a list of books by legislators, including Vice President Al Gore's ill-selling screed on the environment, written more as a springboard for publicity than for profit. If Al can earn thousands, why not Newt millions?

I have nothing against anybody making big money. Bleeding hearts should note that half of Newt's earned millions will go to government in taxes. And the public interest is served when a sitting lawmaker invests extra personal effort in writing and articulating political ideas.
But --

Outside earning, drawn from memoirs of public service, or made possible by the celebrity gained by a time in office, should await the end of that service. That's what presidents have always done; that's what Gen. Colin Powell properly did in his $6 million deal. To make serious money, first get out of government.

While in office, when books, CD-ROMs or profit-making on-line services are undertaken, earnings should be capped; one-third of the official's salary is reasonable. Income in excess of the cap should go to the government, not to some preferred orphanage, because notoriety derived from government power gives value to the official's editorial output.
Public officials should not compete with private citizens as providers of media content. Officeholders should not line their pockets with the latest form of ``honest graft.''

DOC.HEADLINE: `THE VENETIAN TWINS' BROUGHT BACK TO RIBALD LIFE

TEXT.P: Carlo Goldoni's early comedy ``The Venetian Twins'' (1748) comes to vigorous, ribald, disorderly life in the Pearl Theater Company's production of a translation by Michael Feingold, directed by John Rando.

The play dates from a time when Goldoni was struggling to transport Venetian theater from the commedia dell'arte's wild improvisations on a bare scenario to the performance of fully written plays, and it has remnants of the commedia's slapstick along with an arsenal of tricks Goldoni devised to grab an audience's attention. The Pearl's version is wonderfully fresh, even if its exuberance at times reminds one of some stage experiments of the 1960s.
Rando and the actors approach Goldoni's contorted plot with the boisterous humor the playwright intended, often mocking it in asides to the audience, which he also wanted.

There are elaborate schemes over a horde of jewels and gold, sword fights, fistfights, love duets, seduction attempts, flirtations with incest, battles with the law and endless confusions of identity, especially between twin brothers who have not seen each other in many years and who turn up in the same town on the same day. Goldoni even had the effrontery to include a murder and a suicide in this overstuffed bag of laughter, and they are surprisingly amusing.

Renzo Antonello's masks for the few characters still dressed in commedia dell'arte garb are splendid little works of art. Deborah Rooney's costumes are designed in every case to accommodate the elaborate sleights all the characters use to produce comic effects. And the fight direction by Rick Sordelet is superb; a couple of the sword fights here are astonishingly swift, elegant and funny at the same time.
All in all, good Goldoni: slapstick all right, but sharpened by satire, intelligence and style.

THE VENETIAN TWINS By Carlo Goldoni, in a new translation by Michael Feingold; directed by John Rando; sets by Robert Joel Schwartz; lighting by Stephen Petrilli; costumes by Deborah Rooney; properties, Deborah Roth; sound by Casey L. Warren; fight director, Rick Sordelet; mask and movement coach, Mace Perlman; composer, Thomas Cabaniss; maskmaker, Renzo Antonello; production stage manager, Lynn Bogarde. Presented by the Pearl Theater Company. At Theater 80, 80 St. Marks Place, East Village, through Jan. 28.

WITH: Rachel Botchan (Rosaura), Robin Leslie Brown (Columbina), John Wylie (The Professor/Tiburzio), Greg Steinbruner (Brighella), Arnie Burton (Zanetto/Tonino), Clement Fowler (Pancrazio), Jennifer Thomas (Beatrice), Michael James Reed (Florindo), Kevin Black (Lelio), Mace Perlman (Arlecchino) and Branford Cover (Porter/Constable).

DOC.HEADLINE: BROTHER ROGER CALLS, AND 110,000 YOUTHS RESPOND

TEXT.P: Before Brother Roger spoke, young people from all over Europe were already kneeling in prayer, leaning on backpacks, singing hymns or just sleeping by the glow of a sea of candles.

More than 100,000 strong, they had come from more than 30 nations -- Orthodox Christians from Russia and the Balkans, Protestants and Catholics from north and south. They had filled five cavernous exhibition halls and transformed the chilly sites into spaces of meditation, warmed by red banners, religious icons and a pervasive sense of calm.

``We have come here to search, or to go on searching through silence and prayer, to get in touch with our inner life,'' Brother Roger said to a vast congregation in jeans and anoraks, who listened to his words as they were translated into 19 languages. ``Christ always said: do not worry, give yourself.''

Through simple words and music, Brother Roger, 79, a Swiss Protestant theologian and his ecumenical community of monks have been addressing the challenge that many say organized religion on this continent has widely failed to meet: how to awaken Christianity among young people growing up in a secular world?

The 90 monks in white robes include Lutheran, Anglican and Evangelical members as well as Roman Catholics. They speak in plain language instead of traditional church oratory. Their chants merge the meditative prayers of Orthodox and Western monasteries.
Above all, they never preach. Rather, they say, their role is to question and understand and help others in their inner search.
``My brothers and I want to be seen as people who listen, never as spiritual masters,'' was the phrase that Brother Roger used.

A measure of the quiet force of the monks, the Taize Community, is that the annual meetings they have organized since 1978 have now snowballed into the vast gathering of 110,000 people for five days of discussion and prayer that is ending in Paris on Monday.

Brother Roger began his community in 1940. He was Roger Schutz then, the son of a Swiss Calvinist pastor. He and three friends had the idea that war could be averted if Christians could unite, and they bought a house in Taize in eastern France to be their headquarters. During the war, before they were known as a formal community, they hid refugees, including Jews.

In the postwar years as Communism spread, the community grew and members traveled as tourists to Eastern Europe, quietly setting up prayer circles among young Catholics in Poland and Hungary and Protestants in East Germany.

Their long presence in the former Soviet bloc, the organizers said, explains why almost half the participants in Paris last week came from Eastern Europe. Many spent two and three days snaking their way to Paris on precarious-looking buses from as far away as Moscow, Athens, Warsaw and Helsinki.
The participants in the New Year program have created a presence in Paris, with their vehicles inevitably clogging the city's traffic and with the backpackers surging into streets and subways.
``The prayers and the discussion help us so much,'' said Sonia Verger, a chemistry student who helps AIDS patients in her spare time and attends a Taize prayer group once a week in Lyons, France.
Gregor Puchala from Katowice was part of Poland's delegation, the biggest, with 40,000 people.
``The religion part is good but young people also see this as a way to see the world,'' he said. ``It's very cheap. I went to the Eiffel Tower and found a lot of other Poles.''

Brother Emile, a Canadian member of the Taize community, does not object. ``We're not naive,'' he said. ``We know that Paris is an attraction in itself. But our purpose is to bring young people together.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
The last meeting in Paris, in 1988, drew 33,000 people.
Organizing the event has been tantamount to logistic acrobatics. More than 40,000 participants were housed in private homes, schools, sports and church halls and even military bases.

At the Porte de Versailles, the center of activities, French soldiers set up 20 mobile field kitchens to heat a mind-boggling 100,000 C-rations for each night's dinner -- provided for $1 each by the German army.

And so it was that a group from the Ukraine, holding cans of hamburgers, was testing out a version of English on Italians gobbling up military lentils and sausages. By Saturday, the word was out that Serbs and Croats had prayed together the previous night.

``We still cannot believe we are really here,'' said Alexandra Bobric, a member of a Christian Orthodox parish in Belgrade, Serbia, recounting how the Serb contingent needed visas from Hungary, Austria, Germany and France to get here. ``But we really needed this. At home we're at the end of our rope.''
Tim Wilkins, 24, visiting from Brooklyn, knew of the Taize Brothers through their small community in Manhattan.

``What we hear about Europe is about war and conflict,'' said Wilkins, who completed his degree in political science at Amherst College. ``This is extraordinary. It's spiritual and it's about friendship, about building a network of trust.''

On Saturday night, in Hall Two, thousands sat on the concrete floor, chanting and sharing texts. It was a stirring occasion, yet not grand by the standards of modern mass events. There were no giant monitoring screens, no outsize stage or spotlights.

``To me this is wonderful,'' said Karla Hudelja, an economics student from Lubljana, Slovenia. ``First I loved the music because I play the flute. Now I understand young people need God. This is the time we must decide about our life, so we need calm inside.''
Monday she was off home again, with 3,000 others from Slovenia. The buses, they hoped, would swing once last time past the Cathedral of Notre Dame.

DOC.HEADLINE: IN WASHINGTON HEIGHTS, DRUG TRADE THRIVES

TEXT.P: When Danny Cabero returned recently from two years in prison for drug possession he hardly recognized his old turf in Washington Heights, where streets were once congested with young men hawking drugs to drive-by addicts, and guns and knives were a preferred means of communication.

``It's quiet,'' said Cabero, 20, who went back this spring to the northern Manhattan neighborhood that became a landmark in the nation's cocaine crisis. ``They have less people selling drugs in the street. Less people robbing. One thing you can say about Washington Heights: you can walk down the street here and be safe.''

Although there is no evidence that the drug trade has diminished significantly, it has become less violent. With the sharp decline in the city's crime rate, Washington Heights offers evidence that the deadly edge of the drug business has dulled, at least momentarily, with police strategies more effective and some turf wars between dealers now settled.

In 1991, when those wars were raging, 119 people were killed in Washington Heights; last year the number fell to 56. Shootings dropped by a quarter from 1993 to 1994. And possibly as a result of an increased police presence in the neighborhood, reports of other crimes, like auto theft and grand larceny, fell significantly last year.
With legions of former drug sellers now consigned to either cells or coffins, both the police and residents say there are fewer new recruits taking their places on the streets.

Everyone has his own barometer for the drop in crime. The Rev. Earl Kooperkamp, of the Church of the Intercession at 155th Street and Broadway, says he is rarely harassed by drug dealers now. ``It used to be constant,'' he said. ``When I was driving around making parish visits -- a white guy in a Jeep -- it was constant soliciting: `Hey, Popi. What do you want? What do you want?' ''

While new programs in Washington Heights are offering youths alternatives to the street and more tenant groups are fighting drugs in their buildings, the biggest changes in crime appear linked to police efforts and changes in the drug trade.
These days, the police see more organization and sophistication among dealers, whose operations have been forced from the streets into apartment buildings by years of enforcement pressure.

Narcotics officers say knots of street dealers have been replaced by a handful of ``steerers'' on the sidewalk, directing customers to apartments outfitted as sales offices. The men on the street use electronic buzzers and walkie-talkies to warn those inside about the nearby police.
Many of the apartments are furnished with nothing more than a desk or two, scales for weighing drugs and nearly-invisible custom-made compartments for hiding contraband.

When officers raided an apartment on 190th Street recently, they made five arrests and seized 25 pounds of cocaine and two guns. But what surprised them most was the network of video cameras trained on the street to spot police activity.

Many drug dealers now use one apartment for transactions and others, blocks away, to stash larger amounts of drugs and money. And the police say cars that carry drugs are being customized so that the push of a hidden button opens a secret compartment in the dashboard.
``It's more secretive and better hidden now,'' said Richard Wells, a police officer in Washington Heights for the last four years. ``It was so blatant before.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)
The crack explosion of the mid-1980s transformed the side streets of Washington Heights into wholesale cocaine supermarkets minutes from New Jersey, Westchester County and other parts of the city.

In July 1986, in an undercover political event to show how open the selling had become, Rudolph W. Giuliani, then the U.S. attorney in Manhattan, put on a leather vest and sunglasses, and together with Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato, who wore a windbreaker and Army cap, bought crack as part of a buy-and-bust operation on 160th Street.
The market overwhelmed both the police and the new Dominican population, which had grown in Washington Heights since the mid-1970s.

Washington Heights is still a favored destination for cocaine buyers, and the police say heroin -- which preceded cocaine as the main drug available in the neighborhood -- is now being sold with increasing frequency.

But much is different. The number of police officers has increased to 445 from 338 in the last two years. The police precinct itself has been split in two, creating another station house for the neighborhood.

Community policing programs, expanded under the Dinkins administration, have more officers walking beats. And new powers granted to street officers by the Giuliani administration allow them to investigate and arrest drug sellers, augmenting the department's narcotics division, which previously handled most drug investigations.
Through mid-December, the police made more than 2,800 drug arrests in Washington Heights in 1994, nearly 35 percent more than in 1993.

``A couple of years ago, we'd see these guys in the street; we knew they were drug dealers, but we'd just pass them by,'' said Dennis Rodriguez, an officer who has patrolled some of the most drug-infested streets of Washington Heights. ``Maybe we would just tell them to move on. But when you went off the block, they came back. We were handcuffed.''

The department has tried a variety of other strategies, including seizing the cars of buyers who travel across the George Washington Bridge and from other areas to make their purchases. And although the volume of the drug business cannot be measured, both the police and residents say it has slowed slightly.

The crackdown has pushed some drug activity south to Harlem, and some New York drug dealers have moved to less competitive markets upstate and in other East Coast cities, say both the police and others familiar with the drug business.

The trade is still composed of mostly small operations, each run by fewer than a dozen people, police officials say. The difference now is that is that fewer of these operations exist. ``On one block you could have three or four major players,'' Rodriguez said. ``Five years ago on these blocks you could hardly get down the street, there were so many guys. And there were shootouts all the time because of the competition.''
Police officials say those battles -- which drew police attention and hurt the drug business -- have been quelled to some degree by understandings between dealers about who controls which areas.

``It's like the Mafia,'' said John Coyne, a lieutenant in the 33d Precinct in the lower half of Washington Heights. ``You go back 50 or 60 years and they were killing each other right and left, but you put someone in charge, and they know the rules and they don't kill each other as much.''

To community leaders, the reduction in crime also reflects an evolution of the immigrant community, which has increased its political power and expanded organizations to combat a host of ills, from apartment overcrowding to the high rate of school dropouts.

``It's the normal growth and development of the community,'' said Victor Morisete, the executive director of the Community Association of Progressive Dominicans. ``When you have a stake in where you live, you will think differently, you will treat that area differently, and crime is one of the things that is affected.''

A turning point for the neighborhood was five days of disturbances in July 1990 ignited by the killing of Jose (Kiko) Garcia, a drug suspect, by Officer Michael O'Keefe during a scuffle. Although the officer was eventually cleared, the killing raised the suspicions of many residents that the police were abusive and corrupt.
At the time, crime seemed boundless, and the influx of young immigrants had overwhelmed the already-crowded schools. Many had turned to the drug trade.

``I felt that perhaps we were threatened in a way we never were before,'' said Guillermo Linares, the first Dominican immigrant elected to the City Council in 1991. ``It was overwhelming to see people standing on the street and knowing that there is something going on that is not right and that the only way to confront it is if the whole community comes together to confront it.''
The disturbances, with overturned cars aflame and the police under attack from flying rocks and bottles, opened a pressure valve in Washington Heights.

Since then, residents' requests for more officers have been answered, and community and police officials have tried to erase stereotypes of all cops as corrupt thugs and all young immigrants as gun-packing drug dealers.

The redoubled focus on Washington Height's youths can be seen daily behind the battered brown doors of PS 143, where an after-school program of athletics, academics and crafts attracts hundreds of young people, from pre-teen students to former convicts wearing gang beads.
``This becomes like a surrogate home for these kids,'' said Eddie Silverio, a program director.

At the school on a recent night, Silverio asked Cabero about the 10 closest friends he had before he went to prison. ``Those 10 people,'' Cabero said, ``are now behind the walls of Sing-Sing, Attica ... ''

Silverio motioned to another man in the room that night. Milton Martinez, 28, who described himself as the leader of the Netas gang in Washington Heights, is a former drug dealer who has served sentences for robbery and attempted murder. Released this fall, he swears he is a changed man.

Silviero said reducing crime over the long term may require more than just putting people in prison and putting more police officers on the street, especially in neighborhoods where the economy is fragile and financing for youth programs is scarce.
``There are no jobs,'' Silverio said. ``What's Milton going to do to survive?''
Next: In a Brooklyn neighborhood, reported crime is down, but gangs are increasing and people are as fearful as ever.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAUSAGE SNACK SHAPES UP FOR THE '90S

TEXT.P: Let it be recorded for the edification of future historians. It was in the year 1994 that the Skinnies won the war. During that same 12-month span the Forces of Fat pulled down their colors, then reluctantly raised a white flag.
The surrender document was initialed by Jimmy Dean. In place of ink, he signed with melted Velveeta cheese.

For years we have been hearing about The New American Diet, high in oat bran and veggies, low in cholesterol and saturated fats. Yet if you walked into a typical American diner on a Sunday morning, you could not help but notice that most of the visitors were putting away four-egg omelets oozing with cheese. Included were side orders of hash browns crisped in the fat of the bacon that also rested on the enormous breakfast platters.
People talked thin. But they ate fat.
All that began to change in 1994. Who told me? Jimmy Dean. And those Kraft executives identified as members of the Velveeta Vatican.

Check it out. It was in 1994 that both Jimmy Dean sausage and Velveeta cheese appeared on the grocery shelves with low-fat products. The package labels suggest that the sausage and the cheese, combined, contain less saturated fat than a Spaulding tennis ball.

OK, purists may insist that Velveeta is not really a cheese, in either of its forms. And pig farmers may argue that Jimmy Dean's low-fat breakfast meat is not really sausage, since most of the pork has been replaced by lean turkey meat.
But the new products were enthusiastically welcomed by me. Because once again, with a clear conscience, I can enjoy my favorite holiday cocktail snack.
Using the new ingredients it will hereafter be known as:
NEW AGE SAUSAGE SNACK
1 package (12 oz.) Jimmy Dean low-fat sage sausage
1 pound low-fat Velveeta, in hunks
1 pound extra lean ground beef
1 chopped onion
1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce
One-half teaspoon garlic salt
One-half teaspoon oregano
2 tablespoons minced parsley
Cocktail rye bread
Plop the sausage, onion and ground beef in a lightly oiled skillet and saute until brown. Add the cheese and all the other ingredients. When the cheese has melted you're in business.
Spread the glunk on the small cocktail rye rounds, place on a cookie sheet and bake for eight minutes in a 450-degree oven.
This makes a bunch of glunk but the prepared cocktail rye canapes can be kept almost indefinitely in a freezer, wrapped, then baked when needed without thawing.
To properly toast the outgoing year we may need another low-fat appetizer like this one.
BEAN DIP 1994
2 tablespoons canola oil
Two-thirds cup chopped onion
1 clove garlic, pureed
1 and one-half teaspoons ground cumin
1 teaspoon dried oregano, crumbled
One-half teaspoon ground coriander
One-half teaspoon chili powder
One-half teaspoon salt
1 can (8 oz.) tomato sauce
1 can (16 oz.) vegetarian refried beans
Cayenne pepper
Combine the garlic, salt and spices in a bowl and mix.

In a skillet, cook the onions in the hot oil. When they begin to soften add the ingredients of the bowl and stir-cook for a full minute. Add the tomato sauce and cook another two minutes. Stir in the beans and, when the dip is well mixed, add cayenne pepper to your taste.
Serve at room temperature with taco chips or crackers.
Oh, yeah, 1994 also saw the introduction of the no-fat cherry fudge sundae.
Was this a great year or what?!

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSULTANT WANTS TO TAKE DOWN THE GOVERNMENT SAFETY NET

TEXT.P: Morris Shechtman travels North America advising corporations on how to operate and motivate in a risky global business culture that he defines as working without a net.
The high-profile change management consultant has acquired a new, high-profile client who wants to make lots of changes: incoming Republican House Speaker Newt Gingrich.

Shechtman is a leading member of Gingrich's brain trust, advising the incoming speaker and House Republicans on how to sidetrack the social engineering by government that he blames for most of society's problems.
``The foundation is being laid for some of the most significant changes in American society in this century,'' Shechtman said in an interview.
``It is a heavy-duty culture change that is about to occur in this country.''
Shechtman is committed to ending what he describes as ``caretaking'' by government. He sees ``this massive, wasteful federal bureaucracy'' as the enemy of rich and poor alike.
``Liberals are driven with the fantasy of a pain-free environment,'' argued Shechtman. ``The only pain-free environment is death.''
In Shechtman's view, the new Republican majority in Congress is part of a worldwide trend toward ending government paternalism and creating a new order governed by the free market.
``The repudiation of caretaking is global,'' he said. ``The world is unbundling caretaking.''
Gingrich has put Shechtman's book, ``Working Without a Net,'' on his holiday reading list for House Republicans.
Shechtman has conducted a six-hour seminar for the new speaker.
Shechtman is, like Gingrich, supremely self-confident and provocative. He believes, for instance, that punishing people for criminal behavior must be an absolute goal of society.

``We currently have a culture where we substitute help for criminal penalties,'' he said. ``The worst thing this country ever adopted was deterrent programs for criminal behavior. Caretaking has created violence in America.''
Although a record 1 million people are incarcerated in America, Shechtman wants more prisons. ``We're going to have to have institutions that keep these people out of the culture,'' he said.

He is also sympathetic to Gingrich's idea of orphanages or, as he puts it, ``community alternatives'' to violence-prone and dysfunctional families. ``We're talking about taking kids out of homes with parents who are animals,'' he argued.
Shechtman was asked about cases of abuse and neglect in orphanages and group homes.
``When a local institution goes haywire, who can best address it? Local people,'' he replied.

Gingrich has made headlines and controversy by proposing radical changes in programs for children. House Republicans are drafting legislation to abolish federal cash payments to hundreds of thousands of children who are considered severely disabled. Families would get vouchers to spend on a limited program of medical care. And the GOP wants to severely cut back the Aid to Families with Dependent Children welfare program.

Shechtman was asked what was wrong with providing aid, with such protection as parental leave, in the hypothetical case of a working single mother who is trying to complete a community college degree program.
``It keeps her dependent on a bureaucracy,'' he shot back. ``It exemplifies a philosophy of low trust, high control. We do not trust her to make decisions, so we control the money to her.
``What we should say is, `You get together. Tell us how you're going to use the money. How are you going to pursue your own development?' ''
Shechtman sees the free marketplace solving problems that caretaking has exacerbated.
He sees a partnership developing in the workplace that will be far better for workers than labor regulations.
``Employees who brutalize people go out of business,'' said Shechtman. ``The system has amazing checks and balances.''

Pollution problems will be solved, he argues, not by the Environmental Protection Agency and federal laws, but by local people standing up and saying they will not tolerate environmental degradation. ``What external regulation ultimately does is protect people from growth,'' said Shechtman.

He is looking forward to helping define issues, approaches and objectives for Gingrich and the 73-member freshman class of House Republicans. ``We need to be orchestrating the life of this country around core values,'' he argued.
Shechtman was asked whether Gingrich is overreaching, and whether the new House speaker risks getting a reputation as overbearing or a know-it-all.
``No,'' he replied. ``we're not telling people how to think.''

DOC.HEADLINE: MIAMI'S DEFENSE HAS BEEN SHAPING UP

TEXT.P: The banner hung ominously Saturday in the northwest corner of Joe Robbie Stadium. ``Bring back Arnsparger,'' it said.

Tom Olivadotti didn't think too much of the suggestion. Olivadotti is the Miami Dolphins' defensive coordinator. Bill Arnsparger, once Miami's defensive coordinator, holds the same job now with the San Diego Chargers, who will be the Dolphins' opponent on Sunday at 4 p.m. in the American Football Conference semifinals.

``Those people are kind of sick,'' Olivadotti said of the sign-writers. ``You can't please those type of fans. They're not real fans. They're just people who want to make change for the sake of change.''

The Dolphins enjoyed their greatest success when Arnsparger directed the Miami defense from 1970-73. And when when he returned for eight seasons starting in 1976, after being fired as the Giants' head coach, Miami again achieved more defensive respectability than it generally has without him.

But Olivadotti clearly wants Dolphins fans to show more of an appreciation for what they have now. As he stood in the bowels of Joe Robbie Stadium after Miami's 27-17 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs, his face creased in a pained scowl.

``Here we've just played probably our best three defensive games of the year and something like this comes out,'' said the man who has been in charge of the Miami defense for eight seasons. ``I can't believe it.''
The Dolphins had just defeated Kansas City, in part because of big plays by their defense. After a 17-point first half, the Chiefs could not crack the Miami end zone.
Three times the visitors came close, and three times they were turned away by distinctive plays. The first was an interception by cornerback J.B. Brown after Kansas City had reached the Miami 5.

It was such an uncharacteristic mistake by quarterback Joe Montana, he of the four Super Bowl rings, that cornerback Troy Vincent told Brown when they reached the sideline: ``You need to keep that ball and paint it, because you just got an interception from a legend.''
Next, safety Michael Stewart simply stole the ball from Marcus Allen as the running back reached the Miami 34 midway through the final quarter.
``He only had one hand on the ball,'' Stewart said. ``I butted him up and just worked the strip. It's something we've been practicing since minicamp.''
Finally, Vincent, playing in deep prevent coverage, spectacularly batted away the final Montana pass of the day, at the Miami 8 with 21 seconds remaining.
The Chiefs must have believed Vincent when he recently described himself as the league's top cornerback. They chose not to challenge him.
``It was a pretty quiet day for me,'' he said. ``They only threw my way once, and that was a 5-yard slant in the fourth quarter.''
After Montana picked the Miami defense apart in the first half, Vincent said the secondary made one key second-half adjustment.
``We went to more man-to-man coverage,'' he said. ``That forced Joe to make quicker decisions, and it forced his receivers to break their routes off.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

Olivadotti, whose defense had given up a total of 26 points against Indianapolis and Detroit heading into Saturday's game, at first said the Dolphins did nothing different defensively in the second half against the Chiefs.
Informed of Vincent's statement about going to more man-to-man coverage, Olivadotti said: ``Yes we did. But that's not something we want to talk about. We don't want to give San Diego any help.''

In any case, the Dolphins (11-6) head to 11-5 San Diego in maybe their best frame of mind of the season. The offense is clicking with a honed-in Dan Marino, who completed 22 of 29 passes Saturday for 257 yards and two touchdowns. And the defense, for a change, is holding up its end as well.
The Dolphins have played the Chargers twice since 1992 -- winning in Miami that season in the playoffs, 31-0, and losing in San Diego last season, 45-20.
``I feel very confident with our team going on in the playoffs,'' defensive end Marco Coleman said Sunday. ``I think we have a chance against any team we play in any game.''
Brown added: ``We feel like we're going to get to the Super Bowl. We don't feel there's any team in the AFC any better than us.''

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY FIGHTING IN STREETS OF GROZNY

TEXT.P: The war for Chechnya has turned into a vicious block-by-block street brawl. After days of pounding the capital from the skies, teams of Russian snipers entered central buildings in Grozny Sunday and fired on Chechen soldiers throughout the day.
Casualties were said to be heavy on both sides as the badly outnumbered Chechen soldiers fought back ferociously, but there was no reliable accounting of casualties on either side.
The hulks of several Russian tanks -- some with troops still in them -- smoldered near the central train station, where much of the heaviest fighting has taken place.
``I know only one thing,'' said Russia's chief human rights representative. ``Today there were hundreds of victims on both sides.''

The human rights representative, Sergei Kovalev, who has bitterly opposed the assault on Grozny, said Russian tanks were moving through Grozny destroying anything that got in their way, and he added that the human cost of seizing the city could be incalculable. He has been in Chechnya since the invasion began three weeks ago.

Although Russian troops have not taken the presidential palace, the Government Press Service in Moscow claimed Sunday night that President Boris N. Yeltsin's troops had surrounded the building. Fighting has continued without pause for more than a day in the palace area downtown.
The government said Russian troops were installing mobile kitchens in the streets to feed the Chechen population.

There was no clear information on the whereabouts of the Chechen leader, Dzhokhar M. Dudayev. Earlier Sunday, Dudayev was reported to be in a bunker near the building with a group of members of the Russian Parliament. And Sunday night the Interfax news agency reported that he and his bodyguards had moved to a bunker on the outskirts of Grozny, but did not attribute the information to a source.

The Russian defense minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev, told the Press Service that the situation in Grozny and around it ``is being gradually normalized,'' that troops had ``blocked'' the presidential palace, but that there was still firing around it.
The Moscow press center also acknowledged that the troops had not been able to enter the building and that the ``situation in Chechnya has worsened in the last 24 hours.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

That was readily apparent Sunday as Chechen soldiers fought regular Russian troops with grenades, machine guns and every other explosive at their disposal. Chechen soldiers -- moving about the city in roving gangs with no leadership or organization -- are using grenade launchers on any Russian tank they can find.

The Chechen military leadership Sunday issued an urgent appeal for all able-bodied men to defend the city, and thousands of volunteers responded, streaming into the capital packed like cattle on the back of open flatbed trucks.

``We are going to Grozny now,'' said Idris Zhandekov, as he stood with fellow volunteers on the main southern road into Grozny Sunday. ``Everyone is fighting. The only problem is we don't have enough arms. Send us some Stingers please.''
Zhandekov and his underfed, poorly clothed compatriots now threaten to tie the Russian forces in knots with guerrilla tactics in a city many of them have known since birth.

The city was in chaos Sunday. The south was quiet, the west was controlled by Russians, and the north and east were ablaze with fighting. Russian artillery units continued their assault from the northeast.

A ground war like this will be far harder for Russia than the air war has been. The Russian forces have superior firepower and training, but appear demoralized and divided, while the Chechen army -- which does not even assign ranks to its soldiers -- has only grown more committed to its cause of independence in the weeks since Russian government troops repeatedly bombed their capital and the villages around it.

Until Saturday, Russian military leaders seemed content to attack the city from afar, apparently realizing that sending soldiers into Grozny would open a dangerous new phase of the war that could have a heavy human and political toll.

But when Russian troops charged into the center of the city on Saturday, all that changed. Russian planes could no longer safely bomb the capital, or bombard it with indiscriminate artillery fire, without risking the lives of their own troops.

It is becoming clear that no matter what Russia does, the fight for Grozny cannot be over in a day or two, as the Russian defense minister suggested two weeks ago. The Russian public and even the Russian military are divided on the topic, and the Chechens are committed to their cause.
``We have the spirit,'' said Israel Abjullakhdjiev, a young Chechen man on his way to battle Sunday with hundreds of others. ``We have nothing to lose, and we have Allah with us.''

The separatist Muslim region's chief religious leader, appearing on the television broadcast from a bunker in the presidential palace, offered all soldiers the opportunity to repeat the Islamic oath that suicide fighters take before pledging to fight to the death. Normally, the oath must be taken in person, but clerical leaders decided that there was no time for that.

The city was carpeted in a deep fog Sunday, preventing Russian attack helicopters from firing weapons with precision. There were no pedestrians left on the streets. Market activity was minimal. Cars dodged bomb craters and telephone and electrical wires that dangled in the air.

The only major road left open to the city, approaching from the south, was practically deserted as well. For the first time, Russian special forces units conducted thorough searches of all cars and people entering Chechnya from Dagestan.
A BBC producer and her crew were arrested by Russian forces Sunday as they tried to film the area of bombardment from the village of Tolstoy-Yurt. They were being held overnight.
Every car leaving the city was filled with women, children and elderly people. Every vehicle entering was filled with young men taking up arms to defend the capital against the Russian troops.

``I don't know why we are here, why we have been sent to fight against Russian people,'' said Vitaly Ponvin, a Russian army private with an artillery battalion stationed just outside of Grozny. ``I think Yeltsin is crazy. This makes no sense. It will never end. It's worse than Afghanistan because it's in our own land.''

That, ostensibly, is the question about which this war is being fought. Chechen leaders say they want independence for their mostly Muslim republic, and neither Russia nor any other world power has ever recognized this region as anything other than a part of the Russian federation.

``A bullet, a shell, a bomb or a missile cannot create a border,'' said an open letter released Sunday to Russian soldiers from a Grozny organization called the Wolves of Islam. ``This will not end. We will sooner or later revenge ourselves upon you for the deeds you have done today.''

DOC.HEADLINE: WHAT THE TASTEMAKERS SEE

TEXT.P: Resolutions are a little like hot-from-the-oven souffles: the idea is enticing, though collapse is usually sure and swift.
Of course, that didn't stop us from asking some of the nation's most prominent tastemakers what they intended to make good on in the new year -- and solicit their predictions for '95.

A no-nonsense Julia Child says she doesn't believe in making resolutions. ``My general philosophy is, `Get it done!' '' she says in her inimitable trill. But America's culinary heroine foresees ``more and more people returning to home cooking and enjoying it more.''

Though the bulk of her time is spent criss-crossing the country on behalf of the American Institute for Wine Food -- and eating in restaurants and hotels -- Child says, ``I like simple cuisine bourgeois.'' (It's true: her contribution to a Christmas Eve dinner with friends was nothing more glamorous than mashed potatoes.)

Except for dessert, or maybe the first course, Child says she disdains ``froufrou,'' or excessive presentation. And she's weary of raw, burned and undercooked restaurant food. ``So much of what you see in restaurants, you don't know what you're eating.''
Another trend she hopes disappears: the ubiquitous chile pepper, ``which I've even had in dessert,'' bemoans Child.
What could America's leading authority on etiquette possibly want to improve?
``I hope to keep myself from being judgmental -- which is very hard in my field,'' says manners maven Letitia Baldrige. Thus, she plans to be more trusting and encouraged by young people in 1995.

Her mantra: ``Think kindness.'' Call someone who is sick. Remember to write a thank you note. Baldrige plans to soften her stance where feelings aren't at stake. ``If someone doesn't hold his knife and fork properly, it isn't hurting anyone. But responding to a dinner invitation and not showing up hurts the hosts, the guests,'' everyone involved, she says.
If it sounds like she's lowering her standards, Baldrige points out she's merely being less rigid. ``One has to roll with the times, and change manners to accommodate what's happening in society.''

What does Baldrige see in her perfectly shiny crystal ball? ``People are going to be less vocal about their dietary needs'' when being entertained. ``They'll leave discussion of diets and calories at home.'' After all, ``invitations are drying up!'' she says, sounding a warning to fickle eaters.

``The future is a gloomy one,'' moans Michael Jacobson, executive director of Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington, D.C. With the Republican march into the capitol, Jacobson envisions a Congress that ``will pass legislation or block introductions by Clinton that will result in a more dangerous food supply.''

For starters, he's concerned that both nutritional standards and funding for the national school breakfast and lunch programs will be reduced, and that laws banning cancer-causing food additives will be repealed.

Never one to mince words, the consumer watchdog hopes ``more and more people will equate eating fatty food with cigarette smoking,'' lumping the two behaviors in the same class. Dietary changes are never easy, he offers, but can be as simple as switching from 2 percent to skim milk.

Jacobson might have an ally in John Mariani, the food and travel correspondent for Esquire magazine, who plans to eat more vegetarian or vegetarian-leaning dishes (``easy these days''), eschew after-dinner drinks (``digestives don't help digestion at all''), and aim for shorter meals and fewer courses (the current vogue for lengthy ``market'' or ``tasting'' menus ``start to lap over into gluttony,'' he says. ``More than four courses'' is too much).

Mariani gets around -- this year, the critic logged about 300 meals away from home, dining in 25 cities. On his hit list: food that's been played with too much. On his wish list: chefs who take advantage of more of what's available in the seas. Mariani says Mediterranean and Italian themes will continue to dominate the national dining out scene and adds, ``I have a strong suspicion that `fusion' or Pacific Rim cooking will settle down. Chefs are tired of working with all those strong flavors.'' In its place, he predicts, diners will see ``more South American, Central American and Iberian'' cooking.
When it comes to bargains, Mariani suggests that the hungry traveler look no farther afield than his own backyard.
``America will continue to be the bargain of the entire world,'' he says, refusing to shed a tear for the demise of the $25 entree. Now more than ever, ``our food is cheap -- and great.''

DOC.HEADLINE: MIRIAM CAMPS, A WRITER ON EUROPE, DIES AT 78

TEXT.P: Miriam Camps, who wrote about European unification and other topics and who had been a State Department official, died Friday in a hospital near her home in Little Abingdon outside Cambridge, England. She was 78.
The cause was lung cancer, said her sister, Margaret Schwartz.
Mrs. Camps was born Miriam Camp in Lynn, Mass. She was the first woman to be vice chairman of the State Department's Planning Council, from 1968 to 1970.

After earning degrees at Mount Holyoke and Bryn Mawr colleges, she joined the State Department during World War II and went on to work at the U.S. embassy in London. She worked for the State Department in Washington from 1947 to 1953, then resigned to marry William Anthony Camps, a classicist at Cambridge University.

Her many subsequent writings included the books ``Britain the the European Community'' (1964), ``What Kind of Europe?'' (1965) and ``European Unification in the Sixties'' (1966). She was active in a variety of organizations concerned with foreign affairs.
In addition to her husband and her sister, Margaret Schwartz of Endicott, N.Y., she is survived by a brother, Paul R. Camp of Orono, Maine.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOSNIAN AND SERB COMMANDERS MEET AS CEASE-FIRE BEGINS

TEXT.P: The agreement for a four-month cessation of hostilities in Bosnia and Herzegovina took effect at noon Sunday, and shortly afterward Bosnian government commanders met with officers from the Bosnian Serb army they have been fighting for 33 months.
The meeting, held at the Sarajevo airport, was the first of what will probably be a long series of sessions at which the two sides will negotiate details of the cease-fire.
Leaders of both sides hailed the agreement. ``We welcome it, and we are ready to negotiate in good faith to end this conflict,'' said the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic.

Bosnian government leaders also pledged good faith. But President Alija Izetbegovic warned in a radio address that fighting could resume in the spring if no final peace treaty is negotiated by the time the cease-fire expires.

``The war must not last a day longer than it has to, but peace at any price cannot and will not be accepted,'' Izetbegovic said. ``We will negotiate where we can and make war where we have to. If the enemy does not show readiness for reasonable political solutions within the next four months, the cease-fire will not be extended.''

Although the agreement, which grew out of mediation initiated by former President Jimmy Carter, was widely welcomed as a potential breakthrough, it contains several major provisions that were included in previous agreements but never carried out. It remains to be seen whether they will be taken more seriously this time.

Under the agreement, the two armies will pull back from battle lines and allow troops from the U.N. Protection Force, known as UNPROFOR, to move between them. The agreement says negotiations are to follow about the exchange of prisoners and other issues, including procedures ``for the withdrawal and monitoring by UNPROFOR of heavy weapons of caliber 12.7 mm and above.''
The parties also agreed ``to assist fully in the total restoration of utilities and the establishment of joint economic activities aimed at the normalization of life in all territories.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

One provision that has been made and broken repeatedly in the past is a commitment to allow full freedom of movement for U.N. peacekeepers and for relief convoys. Another guarantees the security of the Muslim enclaves of Zepa and Srebrenica.

The agreement contained no reference to the peace plan proposed by the five-nation ``contact group,'' a glaring omission. Mediators have been insisting that any final treaty must be based on acceptance of that plan, but the new agreement suggested that they were backing away from that demand.
Bosnian Serbs had said they would not accept the contact group's plan, so for them the fact that it was not mentioned in the new agreement represented at least a procedural victory.

The chief U.N. envoy to the former Yugoslavia, Yasushi Akashi, who helped guide the mediation that produced the new agreement, said talks aimed at a comprehensive peace treaty would begin later this month. He said they would be held under the auspices of the contact group, which is made up of the United States, France, Britain, Germany and Russia.

``There have been many cease-fires, but this is the first time we have a cessation-of-hostilities agreement,'' Akashi said. ``I hope that we are turning a very important corner in this most tragic conflict in Europe since the Second World War.''
But many U.N. officials, including Lt. Gen. Sir Michael Rose, the senior U.N. military commander in Bosnia, warned that the forthcoming talks will be exceedingly difficult.

``You can say that the easy part, difficult as it was, is now over,'' Rose said after the signing. ``The difficult bit now begins. We have to put on the ground vast numbers of troops in pursuit of different security-building measures to insure that this process does not go backward.''

The process that led to the new agreement was set in motion last month by Carter, who mediated a week-long cease-fire that expired Saturday. The cease-fire seemed to hold throughout most of the country Sunday, although there were reports of continued fighting around the northwestern town of Bihac.
A diplomat who has closely followed the talks said both sides appeared to have signed the new agreement at least in part for tactical reasons.

``The Serbs are hoping that it will help them stabilize their front lines,'' the diplomat said. ``For the government, it is a chance to regroup and also a chance to open supply routes for relief convoys. But even if both sides are entering into negotiations only as a tactic, once you begin that process you never know what might happen.''

DOC.HEADLINE: MALLS COME TO GERMANY, BUT NOT EVERYONE THINKS IT'S A GOOD IDEA

TEXT.P: Watching change come to eastern Germany since the collapse of communism five years ago is like watching newsreels of life from the 1950s to the 1990s speed past in fast-forward.

Office buildings and construction cranes have sprung up in every major city. Streets have been torn up for new telephone lines, new sewers and new power cables, and then torn up again for new cable television wires.
New roads snake steadily out from city centers, drawing suburban housing developments with them and bringing cars, more cars, and constant traffic jams.

Now comes what some think could change the traditional German urban life style more than anything else yet: American-style suburban shopping malls, surrounded by vast parking lots with fast-food outlets and cineplexes. Leipzig has the biggest one in the country.

``We now have the greatest concentration of these shopping centers in all of Germany,'' said Niels Gormsen, the supervisor of construction projects in Leipzig. ``We see a danger that too many could kill off downtown commercial districts, just like in America.''

Gormsen and many other city planners here would like to avoid the crass commercial strips and decaying urban downtowns as successfully as they did in most medium-size west German cities over the last 40 years.
He, like many other civil servants here, came from the west to replace the communist functionaries who emulated Soviet urban development models in the old days.

But since reunification, commercial development and social change have come so fast that the city authorities have not had the time that was granted to them in western Germany to plan their cities to remain livable and commercially viable at the same time.
There, Germans built underground parking garages, pedestrian zones, and modern streetcar lines so cities and their neighborhoods could survive the automobile and monster suburban malls.

Here, the first thing that happened after capitalism came to eastern Germany in 1990 was a rush by west German retailers to open large commercial developments the fastest way they could, on undeveloped land just outside the crumbling major cities.

In the urban area around Leipzig (population 500,000) and Halle (300,000) alone, they have opened centers with a total floor space of 215 acres and have permission to build another 62 acres' worth. City planners have turned down plans for 173 acres more.

``What they are building now are bankruptcies in the making,'' said Dr. Ulrich Hatzfeld, an urban expert in Dortmund, who calculated that nearly half of the shopping centers now being planned in Germany were in the eastern part of the country, which has only 20 percent of the population and even less of the total purchasing power.

More than half of all retail shopping space in eastern Germany is outside the city centers, while in western Germany only 25 to 30 percent is, Hatzfield said. Apart from a few huge malls near Frankfurt and Cologne, big suburban stores tend to be specialty shops for furniture, carpeting, or gardening equipment.

Even more shopping malls might have developed in eastern Germany if not for the country's restrictive laws, which require all stores to close at 6:30 p.m. most weekdays, early afternoon on most Saturdays, and all day Sunday. Other laws restrict price discounts.

``The main danger we see is not to the centers of historic cities like Leipzig or Dresden, but to neighborhoods on the periphery,'' Gormsen said. ``It wouldn't be bad, from the city's point of view, if some of these shopping centers did go bankrupt.''

Already, it can take more than an hour to drive the 10 miles from Leipzig to Germany's biggest shopping mall, the Saale Park at the intersection of Highway 9 and Route 181, financed by a German savings bank. Two smaller malls have also sprouted along the way.
(MORE)

``Most days, you just sit in a traffic jam to get out here,'' said Gabriele Smetanin, who had come out to the Saale Park to do her Christmas shopping at the new Peek Cloppenburg department store there. ``Actually, their new store downtown has a better selection,'' Mrs. Smetanin said. ``I came out of habit today, I suppose, because this one opened first.''

Bernhard Jaeger, the shopping center manager, said that hurting downtown Leipzig was the last thing he wanted to do. ``I'm a native Leipziger,'' he said. ``We get about half of our customers from Leipzig and Halle, but the rest come from a 50-kilometer radius all around.'' The distance is equivalent to about 30 miles.
Still, that was 80,000 to 100,000 customers on the Saturdays before Christmas who did their shopping in the 100 shops in the open-air mall and not in downtown Leipzig.

Karstadt AG, a national chain that is planning to open a new store in Leipzig next year, calculated recently that the new suburban malls were siphoning off $380 million in annual sales from downtown Dresden, $255 million from Leipzig, and $240 million from Chemnitz.

What east German shoppers find in new malls like the Saale Park and the Sachsenpark on the northeast edge of town is the sort of thing familiar to suburban American shoppers. At Saale Park there is bland background music, a giant Toys ``R'' Us, a 10-cinema movie complex, an Ikea furniture store, McDonald's, and acres of parked cars.

``We're bringing customers a variety of choice they never dreamed of in the communist days,'' Jaeger said, ``and we've created hundreds of jobs. The villages around here didn't even have decent plumbing and electric power until we brought it to them with the mall.''

And the customers keep coming. ``We've all been out there,'' said Jutta Richter, who lives in downtown Leipzig. ``I bought a couple of couches, and if I have to put a new kitchen into our next apartment, I'll go there again to get it.''

But Mrs. Richter said she didn't enjoy the experience, and prefers to shop in town. The city is also trying to keep commercial development from driving apartment dwellers from the center of town, and introducing modern streetcars to provide easy access from the outskirts.

``You can't imagine how overwhelmed we are by all the changes we have gone through,'' Mrs. Richter said. ``Until five years ago, there was only one of everything, always at the same price, and the only question you asked when you went shopping was what the stores had that particular day. Now it takes me half an hour just to figure out which detergent is the best buy.''

Five years ago, Leipzig was an industrially polluted mess, the late Gothic Thomaskirche where Johann Sebastian Bach spent his most creative years as choirmaster slowly crumbling and begrimed like most of the 19th-century commercial buildings around it.

Today the church gleams, restored with money from the city and the state of Saxony. After a western developer, Juergen Schneider, disappeared early this year to avoid bankruptcy, German banks financed the completion of a new indoor shopping gallery around Auerbach's Keller, a tavern that is one of the settings for Goethe's ``Faust.''

The compact city center has so many shops, malls, and office buildings under construction that picking through the narrow streets is like running an obstacle course. Peek Cloppenburg's store, a dramatic stone-and-glass building designed by a Santa Monica, Calif., architectural team -- Charles Moore, John Ruble, and Buzz Yudell -- opened on the main shopping street, the Petersstrasse, last summer.

What Leipzig's downtown doesn't have enough of is parking spaces. It did not even have parking meters until after communism collapsed, and the few spaces that exist are inadequate. An underground garage is only in the planning stages in front of the modern Gewandhaus, home to the orchestra once directed by Felix Mendelssohn-Bartholdy and now by Kurt Masur, who is also the music director of the New York Philharmonic.

``The one sad aspect to all of this is that almost all the building is for places where west German companies can sell products made in west Germany to east German consumers,'' said Dr. Christoph Boeckenfoerde, another city official who came from the west. ``We're consuming here, not creating -- so far,'' he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVERTISERS TARGET SELECT GROUP OF CONSUMERS: `WORKPAUSAL WOMEN'

TEXT.P: Current television commercials for Levi's Jeans for Women show a Matisse-like stick figure with a shaped hangar as a face balancing on a seesaw and a silhouette escaping from a confining logo on a door, trading her dress for jeans and shattering the prison that encased her.

The ad campaign, created by FCB San Francisco, is somewhat unusual for its surreal style. But what really sets it apart is its attempt to speak to a statistically small but influential group of women: the ``workpausals.''

While now largely confined to the privileged set, workpausals represent the front line of an important emerging societal trend. New evidence suggests that perhaps as a reaction to the careerism of the 1980's, or because of a nostalgia for a more traditional life style, many mothers are yearning for a ``time out.'' Some are actually taking it, becoming full-time mothers for a few years and then resuming their careers.
``Women have stopped apologizing for staying home,'' said Donny Deutsch, chief executive and executive creative director of Deutsch Inc. ``Now it's a badge.''
Susan Small Weil, a strategist with the Seiden Group, said today's mother at home is ``a modern-day status symbol, a guiltless new traditionalist doing the responsible thing.''
Television and publishers have recognized this group of women, portraying strong mothers in TV shows and producing new magazines like Family Fun. But most marketers have not addressed the group.
Advertisers have retired the image of the superwoman, who, as portrayed in the 1970s Enjoli perfume ads, brought home the bacon and fried it up in a pan.

``Marketers are just now catching on to the fact that people have stopped glorifying work as the be-all and end-all of life and that portraying that may not be the way to capture women's hearts,'' said Maryann Gormley, spokeswoman for Women at Home, a Virginia-based support group.

Barbara Feigin, executive vice president and director of strategic services at Grey Advertising, said that while shows like ``Roseanne,'' and ``Mad About You'' show women ``in contemporary ways, the commercials in them do not.''
There are a few exceptions, like an ad for Dove soap that describes its rural protagonist as someone who's ``always known what works for her,'' which was praised by Woman at Home.
Still, Ms. Feigen said, ``Three out of four women think advertising is out of touch with where they are today.''

Sheile Wellington, president of Catalyst, an organization that deals with women and work issues, said the number of working women was continuing to rise, adding that ``women, just like men, work for a paycheck, not for pin money.''
But recent surveys by the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that fewer young mothers are working now than in 1987.

And Roper Starch Worldwide, a polling organization, says that while fewer than half of the women surveyed in 1985 wanted to stay at home, 53 percent of the same number surveyed recently said that they would like to do so.

``Although their actual numbers are small, the power wife-mother is our latest status symbol, more important than a mink coat,'' said Laurel Cutler, executive vice president and director of strategic planning at FCB San Francisco.

Arlene Cardozo, author of ``Sequencing,'' believes the time-out trend is already widespread. ``What started with trailblazers, professional doctors and lawyers' wives and women with wealthy husbands is rapidly becoming a well-worn highway with wives of garage mechanics and factory workers extending maternity leaves to a few years,'' she said.

Virtually everyone agrees that advertising is not yet zeroing in on these women. But a change in buying habits is already apparent. ``It's a shift from more money, less time, to less money, more time,'' said Ms. Weil of the Seiden Group. ``There's less `one-stop shop' and more searching for the better deal. They're ordering in and picking up prepared foods less, and heading to the library instead of the bookstore more.''

One obvious result is that sales of women's business suits are down and those of casual clothes are up. The Kayser-Roth Corp., a leading maker of women's hosiery, has reported that a decade ago sheer hosiery accounted for 85 percent of the $4.2 billion leg-wear market, compared with 67 percent late last year.
Sales of socks, meanwhile, jumped from 13 percent to 23 percent during the same period

``We recognize this as the age of the power woman,'' said Patti Cohen, advertising director for Donna Karan Inc., the clothing retailer. ``But power no longer means workaholism,'' Ms. Cohen said, adding that DKNY casual weekend wear was Donna Karan's strongest division.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

Advertisers are seeking neutral terrain -- outdoor scenes are a good example -- so that their campaigns are directed at all women. The trend is away from either-or images and toward those depicting a balance of career and home, said Ignazio Puccio, senior vice president and executive director of strategic planning at J. Walter Thompson New York.

Many marketers now shy away from at-home scenes, ``for fear it will play to a previous stereotype,'' Ms. Small Weil said. ``Today's housewife is not a scrubber. She's more relaxed about housework because she's not home for that.''

Ms. Cutler of FCB said: ``Marketing to their deep mothering instinct is marketing to them the old-fashioned way. A better language would be the universal one of business with overlays of caring, nurturing, gentleness, femininity and sexiness.''

``The ads that strike a chord with workpausals acknowledge they're at peace with themselves,'' said Marian Salzman, president of BKG America, a market research company in New York. She cited a Keds spot where a 30-ish mom does laundry accompanied by her trusty golden retriever while talking about things that are comfortable.

``It's reinforcement advertising that says you're still attractive and you can get back on the ladder,'' Ms. Salzman said. ``The operative word is choice. What their mothers saw as making sacrifices, they see as a chosen way of life.''

DOC.HEADLINE: RADIO INDUSTRY HAS BANNER YEAR

TEXT.P: For the oldest broadcasting medium, 1994 was a very good year.
Advertising revived with a vengeance, posting double-digit increases in 7 of the first 10 months of the year and ending the first 10 months up 12 percent over all.

In the face of this growing demand, the industry was able to raise its rates after several years of marking them down to gain business. Radio executives are optimistic that strong increases will be posted in 1995 as well.
As industry ownership continued to consolidate, the biggest got bigger, taking advantage of rules revisions adopted by the Federal Communications Commission in 1992.

One owner may now operate 20 AM and 20 FM stations and even though twice as many stations are on the air as a decade ago, the number of station owners remains the same. More deals are now in the works, so the consolidation will surely continue in 1995.

The Infinity Broadcasting Corp. of New York, for example, added four stations in 1994, giving it 16 FM and 10 AM stations, and gained control of the large Westwood One radio network. The other big radio companies -- CBS; Westinghouse Broadcasting, also known as Group W, a subsidiary of Westinghouse Electric, and Capital Cities/ABC -- either added stations, swapped smaller ones for larger ones, sharply increased revenue or all three.

The other growth spurt came in talk radio, which soared in numbers and in influence, as well -- a trend that was made clear by the many political candidates tripping over each other as they tried to get on the air before Election Day.
Radio stations carrying nothing but news, talk, business coverage or sports, or, in other words, no music, grew to 1,028 in 1994 from 841 in 1993, compared with only 308 in 1989.
And the Big Three of talk radio, Howard Stern, Don Imus and Rush Limbaugh, continued to increase the number of stations carrying their syndicated programs.

The radio industry scored another victory in 1994 when the FCC looked Stern in the eye, recoiled in disgust at what it called his indecent programming, but then slunk away, concluding that it lacked the power to penalize Infinity, Stern's employer, in any meaningful way.

The commission had discussed blocking Infinity's plan to pay $170 million to acquire three stations, or even rescinding some Infinity licenses, but it decided in February that a federal appeals court decision had eroded its power to do so. (More than $1 million in fines that the commission has levied against Infinity for Stern's on-air remarks continue to be appealed in the courts.)
Infinity's chairman, Mel Karmazin, continued to consolidate his position as radio's most influential executive.

Taking advantage of the huge New York audience and the enthusiasm of Imus and Stern for insulting each other, he continued his unusual strategy of having his two stations compete against each other in the morning ``drive time'' -- radio's prime time. And the strategy seems to work, for WXRK-FM, Stern's home, runs well ahead of the competiton as the area's top-rated station, while WFAN-AM, home to ``Imus in the Morning,'' ties for No. 5.

Another Karmazin strategy that has caught the eye of industry executives is his attempt to establish FM radio, traditionally the bastion of music, as a home for sports broadcasting. Infinity carries Dallas Cowboys games on KVIL-FM, Dallas; the Eagles on WYSP-FM, Philadelphia, and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers on WQYK-FM, Tampa. Next season, its WBCN-FM, Boston, will carry the New England Patriots games. If those bets pay off, imitators will surely follow.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIG SALES FOR RECORD INDUSTRY, BUT TURMOIL SPREADS

TEXT.P: The record industry closed its books last week on a year of considerable prosperity, but also one of significant turmoil. It was a year of upheaval in the executive ranks, and the impact of these changes is expected to ripple through the industry this year.

Sales of recorded music in the United States are expected to reach a new high of $11 billion in 1994, up 10 percent from 1993. And optimism remains high for this year, when many big-name releases are planned. But who will be where, taking credit for what, remains to be seen.

The face of the industry has changed during the last few years. The old guard of powerful entrepreneurs, most of them at least two generations older than the audience they were making records for, has been replaced by a crop of creative baby boomers.
Many of the newcomers rose through the ranks by grasping hold of new music, like alternative rock and hip-hop, and bringing it into the corridors of power.

The center of much of the turmoil last year was the Warner Music Group, a subsidiary of Time Warner Inc., which accounts for about 21 percent of the market in recorded music through its Atlantic, Elektra and Warner Brothers labels.
During the summer and fall, a number of longtime Warner Music executives left the company after they lost an internal power struggle.
These executives may start or join other companies, while the people who replaced them are likely to revamp their labels and in the process the industry itself.

Warner Music was not the only company that experienced unrest. The Polygram Label Group, which included the Island, Polydor and London labels, disbanded in June, and BMG, which includes Arista, RCA and Jive records, just ended its joint venture with Imago records after having lost tens of millions of dollars.

In comparison, the industry's No. 2 company, Sony Music, whose Columbia, Epic and other labels account for 13 percent of the U.S. market, had a calm and prosperous 1994, despite the enormous problems its parent company ran into with its Hollywood film studios.
What follows are snapshots of the movers and shakers to watch in 1995. Some are familiar faces at new posts, others are fresh faces thrust up by the growth of alternative rock and hip-hop.
MICHELE ANTHONY, 38, executive vice president, Sony Music Entertainment.

Before joining Sony in 1990, Ms. Anthony worked as a lawyer for artists like Guns `n' Roses, Soundgarden and the Pixies. She distinguished herself as a vice president at Sony Music by securing deals with Pearl Jam and Aerosmith.
In January, Ms. Anthony was promoted to second-in-command of Sony's music division, behind Tommy Mottola. Ms. Anthony is considered to be a sharp, hands-on executive whom artists respect.
FUTURE: In the short term, her mandate is to deal with the quirks of the company's cash cow, Pearl Jam. Long term, she needs to attract new talent.
JEFF AYEROFF, 47, JORDAN HARRIS, 41, co-presidents of an as-yet-unnamed Sony label.

They began their careers at AM Records in the 1970s and co-founded Virgin Records America in 1986. When they left Virgin 15 months ago, they were expected to take top positions at Warner Music, but the shake-up left them in limbo.

Sony grabbed them to establish a strong West Coast presence. Columbia, a Sony label, plans to fold the roster of its Chaos label plus some bands of its own into the pair's new label, which will open for business in January.
