FUTURE: It is too early to predict the future of the label, but rival executives are taking it seriously.
KEN BERRY, 42, chief executive, EMI Records Group and Virgin Music Group.

Berry, who has been at Virgin in England for 21 years, has proved himself in recent years by keeping Thorn EMI's $900 million purchase of Virgin from seeming like a folly. Better known as a money man than as a music man, he made Virgin a force in the United States by appointing as its president Phil Quartararo, who has helped make it EMI's most profitable label here. But EMI remains a troubled company in the United States.
FUTURE: Berry seems to be a likely candidate to lead the inevitable restructuring of EMI in the United States.
DAVID GEFFEN, 51, founder, David Geffen Co.

Since Geffen built his first label, Asylum, at the age of 27, he has been a formidable if unpredictable force in the industry. He started Geffen Records in 1980 and sold it 10 years later to MCA for $545 million in preferred stock. With artists like Nirvana, Counting Crows and Guns `n' Roses, Geffen and its sister label, DGC, have built up an impressive roster.

FUTURE: Geffen's contract with MCA will expire on April 1 and he has said he will start a record company with his new business partners, the director Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg, the former Disney executive. Some insiders expect him to abandon his namesake label and start a company with executives who defected from Warner Brothers. Others think he will try to to buy out MCA, and thus Geffen Records.
GARY GERSH, 38, president and chief executive, Capitol Records.

An ace talent scout at Geffen Records, where he brought in Sonic Youth, Counting Crows and Nirvana. EMI decided to put Gersh in charge of Capitol, its sinking flagship label, 16 months ago. Gersh trimmed the label's roster to 27 artists from 90, replaced more than half its executives and made deals with top producers like Daniel Lanois and Brad Wood.

FUTURE: Music industry analysts are waiting to see whether Gersh can change Capitol from an oldies label living off its catalogue (the Beach Boys, the Beatles and others) into a competitor in hip-hop, rhythm and blues and alternative rock.
DANNY GOLDBERG, 44, chief executive and chairman, Warner Brothers.

Three years ago, Goldberg was managing the skyrocketing careers of Nirvana, Bonnie Raitt and others. Brought into Atlantic Records as a senior vice president in 1992, he has quickly scaled the corporate ladder, driven by good instincts and alternative-music savvy. He brought the respected independent labels Matador, Mammoth and Curb into the Atlantic fold and has a reputation as an executive whom artists can trust.

FUTURE: With his promotion Jan. 1 to head of Warner Brothers, he must ease tactfully into many of the responsibilities that the widely respected Mo Ostin (who quit during the Warner shake-up) had for 22 years.
BRETT GUREWITZ, 32, president and owner, Epitaph Records.

Gurewitz surprised the music industry this year when an album he released by the punk-rock group Offspring became the most successful rock record released by an independent label in years. Though every major record label has offered Gurewitz substantial sums for all or a piece of Epitaph, he insists he wants to continue as an independent.
FUTURE: Will his bands stand by him, or yield to offers from major labels?
DON IENNER, 42, chairman, Columbia Records Group.

Ienner helped rebuild Arista Records in the 1980s with artists like Whitney Houston, Kenny G. and Expose. Five years ago he was brought by Sony to Columbia Records, the industry's fallen leader, to do the same. Columbia says its profits have doubled since then because of Ienner, a confident and forceful executive. But this year Columbia had relatively few big hits and is beginning to be eclipsed by its sister label, Epic. FUTURE: With new albums expected from Bruce Springsteen, Alice in Chains, Soul Asylum, Billy Joel, Bob Dylan and Michael Bolton, next year could be a big one for Columbia. Ienner's challenge is to change the label's reputation as a home for adult contemporary musicians and dinosaur rockers, and make it into a breeding ground for younger, hipper artists.
JIMMY IOVINE, 41, TED FIELD, 42, co-presidents and co-owners, Interscope Records.

By taking risks on gangster rap and industrial rock, Iovine, a producer, has created one of the highest-profile companies in the business, with the financial backing of Field. Through costly deals with Nine Inch Nails, Helmet and Tupac Shakur, and with the Death Row rap label, they built up the net worth of Interscope -- currently a joint venture with Atlantic Records -- to what they say is $300 million.

FUTURE: Warner Music wants to take over Interscope and position it as its fourth major label; Iovine and Field say they will not sell. Next year, it will become clear if they will crack, and for how much, and whether Interscope has enough successful acts to live up to its reputation.
SUGE KNIGHT, 29, DR. DRE, 29, co-owners, Death Row Records.

Knight and the rapper and producer Dr. Dre are one of the most successful business and creative teams in hip-hop. Between the record label and Suge Knight Management, whose singers include Mary J. Blige and Jodeci, they have taken in more than $75 million this year.

But since starting Death Row, Knight has been convicted for weapons violations and charged with racketeering. Next month he will be back in court fighting another weapons violation charge and a charge that he assaulted two rappers.
Dr. Dre was sentenced to eight months in prison for violating probation and Snoop Doggy Dogg, Death Row's biggest artist, is facing a murder charge.
FUTURE: Some industry executives call Knight the Spielberg of hip-hop, but they wonder if he can stay out of legal trouble.
DOUG MORRIS, 55, chairman and chief operating officer, Warner Music U.S.

A cunning strategist and a master of expansion, Morris helped Atlantic transform itself in four years from a has-been to the top label in the industry. His ascent signaled the changing of the guard in the music business. Morris has surrounded himself with a strong, young and loyal team of executives.

FUTURE: His biggest challenge is to keep the boat he rocked steady, a feat he took a step toward recently when he settled a contract dispute with Metallica and prevented the band from leaving Elektra after the departure of the label's head, Robert Krasnow.
SYLVIA RHONE, 42, chairman, Elektra/EastWest Records.

It took 18 years for Ms. Rhone to climb from secretary to the most powerful woman in the recording business. When she was promoted from chairman and chief executive of East/West Records to her new job in July, East/West was merged with Elektra and Asylum records.

Best known for developing rap and rhythm-and-blues acts like Snow, En Vogue, and Das EFX, one of her first big moves at Elektra was to help with the acquisition of 49 percent of the Seattle rock label Sub Pop, which began the careers of Nirvana and Soundgarden.
FUTURE: If, as expected, Sire Records becomes part of Elektra, can Ms. Rhone lift her division of Warner Music to equal stature with Atlantic and Warner Brothers?
OTHER PLAYERS

Val Azzoli was appointed president of Atlantic Records last month, as the label's top executives and labels were being redistributed by Warner Music Group. Now he must rebuild it. Chris Blackwell, the chairman of Island records, extended his contract with Polygram in December and is starting to play a much more active role at the label. Clive Calder, the self-effacing entrepreneur who runs Jive Records, had one of his strongest years in 1994 thanks to rhythm-and-blues artists like R. Kelly and Aaliyah. Clive Davis is just about the only old-school executive still running a label. Despites its small size, his Arista Records had an incredible year, becoming the No. 3 label of 1994 with with blockbuster acts like Kenny G., Ace of Base and Toni Braxton. Tim DuBois of Arista and Tony Brown at MCA were two of the most successful and sought-after executives in Nashville last year. Robert Krasnow left his position as head of Elektra when he found out he would have to report to Doug Morris. MCA wooed him with $3 million for a start-up label. Jim Gueirnot, manager of the punk-rock band Offspring, was given what is said to be more than $30 million to start an Arista-distributed label from scratch. Jonathan Poneman, a co-owner of Seattle's Sub Pop records, proved his worth by nurturing a good local music scene. Even after Seattle was almost picked dry by major labels, Warner Music gave him millions to spend and invest. Davitt Sigerson, stepped down as president of Polydor records during the shake-up at Polygram, must now try to salvage EMI records as its new chief executive. Tom Silverman, chairman and founder of Warner Brothers' Tommy Boy label, has an agreement with Warner that expires at the end of March. If negotiations don't work out, he said, he'll start a new label. And RCA Records is still looking for a president, if anyone is interested.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE INVENTORS OF A OIL FILTER FOR BOATS HAVE TROUBLE ATTRACTING A MANUFACTURER

TEXT.P: One of the first things independent inventors learn is that the phrase ``if you build it, they will come'' does not usually apply to manufacturing. Many inventors are stunned to discover that their low-tech, common-sense inventions do not inspire companies to retool factories to change the product's long-standing design.

Michael and Dorothy Kucik have hit that section of the inventors' learning curve. The Kuciks run a heavy-machinery rigging company in Baltimore and are avid boaters in their spare time. For years they struggled with the mess and water pollution caused by the changing of their boat's oil filter.

Finally, rather than continue using filters that always retained a bit of oil, the Kuciks designed and patented one with an extra valve so the residual oil can be drained before the filter is removed.
But Kucik says the manufacturers who every year produce 400 million disposable oil filters for cars and boats are not interested in his invention.

``The filter companies don't want to buy our invention because they're already selling filters now and they don't think this is necessary,'' said Kucik, who said he had pitched his patent to many manufacturers.

``We invented this strictly from an environmental point of view,'' he continued. Though boat owners are allowed to pump biodegradable wastes into water, many inadvertently add engine oil to the mix because they spill it. When oil is changed on a boat, the crankcase is drained and the filter is unscrewed. The problem: the filter contains about a quart of residual oil under pressure, which then overflows.

``One quart of oil can pollute a million gallons of water,'' Kucik said. Used motor oil and filters are considered hazardous waste in many places, and spills can be costly to boaters: the Coast Guard fines polluters up to $5,000.

``We always tried to do it with plastic bags to catch the oil,'' Dorothy Kucik said, ``but it's difficult because of the cramped quarters in a boat engine and because once the oil spills, the plastic bag sticks to the oil.''
The Kucik's filter has an extra valve extending from the bottom. A hose can be attached, or if there's room, a container can be placed under the valve to catch the residual oil.
``The valve can't vibrate open while the boat is in use,'' Kucik said. ``You have to give it a half turn with a pair of pliers.''
The Kuciks have put together a fact sheet about their filter and say they are not discouraged by the failure so far to license their invention.
``The Coast Guard loved the idea, so we're going to get it on the market if we have to manufacture it ourselves,'' Kucik said. The Kuciks won patent 5,366,400.

For those who spend their leisure time on land, Raymond and Hilde Smith have invented a two-story recreational vehicle. But they don't raise a roof or expand accordion walls over the first floor. Instead, they slide a fixed second floor down into the first level.

In the Smiths' design, the first floor has two bedrooms and a bathroom. In storage or travel mode, the ceiling lowers to about bed level. That same ceiling is also the floor of the second story -- which has a living room, kitchen and dining room, complete with furniture that never needs to be moved.
``As you lower the second floor, it goes down until it rests on stops or on the furniture of the first floor,'' Smith said.
When camping, a three-ton hoist driven by an electric motor lifts the second floor until enough room is created underneath to create the first floor.

``The second floor is raised by 12 to 14 cables which are attached to take-up drums and the electric hoist motor,'' said Smith, a retired design engineer from North Tonawanda, N.Y. ``When it gets all the way up, its locked into place so the weight is no longer on the cables.''

In storage mode, the camper is 10 feet 10 inches tall. When the second floor is elevated, it measures nearly 17 feet. The vehicle is stabilized by four legs that extend outside from the front and back of each side and are planted firmly on the ground.
A small elevator shaft is created between the two floors and directly in front of the camper's side entrance door.
Smith said his design could be adapted for trailers, motor homes or recreational vehicles. It received patent 5,374,094.

Ted Schott, a Minnesota game inventor, has a suggestion for dealing with pent-up energy: a good pillow fight. But his version has characters named Harry Hitman and Swingin' Sam, an electronic timer, a helmet and knee pads.
Schott has patented what he calls a ``stress-reducing'' board game for two to six players. Each person chooses a colored token and spins a dial to move along a serpentine path.

Along the way, a player's token may land on neutral squares or on a spot instructing the player to stop for a pillow fight. The timer limits the length of the pummeling, and the game comes with soft pillows, the helmet and elbow and knee pads.
Each player is pummeled by other players as he or she reaches the end of the path, marked ``bedtime.'' The last person to land at bedtime wins the game.
Schott received patent 5,362,062.
Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

DOC.HEADLINE: TESTAVERDE LEADS BROWNS TO 20-13 WIN OVER PATS

TEXT.P: Al Testaverde of Elmont, N.Y., was in Cleveland to lend his son, Vinny, some moral support in his first playoff game. But he didn't attend the game against the Patriots at Cleveland Stadium Sunday afternoon.

Vinny Testaverde doesn't know where his father spent the time during the game. He speculates that his father spent part of the day at church, no doubt offering up a prayer on behalf of his son and the Cleveland Browns. Testaverde thinks his father might have gone to a Cleveland mall to do some shopping.

``He has a little bit of a heart condition and he can't get too excited, can't get his blood pressure up,'' Testaverde said. ``We talked before the season and he told me that he wasn't going to come to the stadium for any of my games. But we made a deal that if I made it to the Super Bowl, he'd come.''
If Vinny Testaverde plays in his next two playoff games the way he played against the Patriots Sunday afternoon, then it's a date.

In a game fraught with potential pitfalls, Testaverde was masterly in guiding the Browns past all the trouble spots and to a 20-13 victory over New England, a team that had finished the regular season with seven straight triumphs.

The Browns, making their first playoff appearance since 1989, will play at Pittsburgh next Saturday. It's the third game between the American Football Conference Central rivals this season, the Browns having lost the first two to the Steelers.

``We're not looking at it like it's the third game against them,'' said Browns linebacker Pepper Johnson. ``We're going to approach it like it's the first game against them and like they're standing in the way of us getting the AFC championship.''
If Testaverde plays as well as he did Sunday, the Browns have an excellent shot.

The knock against Testaverde, who played six seasons at Tampa Bay, is that he isn't a big-time quarterback capable of leading a team through the playoffs because he makes crucial mistakes at the most inopportune times. In Cleveland his detractors detest him simply because he's not Bernie Kosar, the local favorite who was booted out of Cleveland last year by Browns Coach Bill Belichick to make room for Testaverde.

``People have always talked bad about Vinny, about the things that he can't do,'' said Browns left tackle Tony Jones. ``He showed today what he can do. He's a confident quarterback. He's very mobile and he has a strong arm. He came out of the pocket and moved around. He made a lot of plays on his own today. He showed up and showed everybody what he's capable of.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

Testaverde completed 20 of 30 passes for 268 yards and a touchdown and threw 7 passes to receiver Michael Jackson for 122 yards. Eleven of his completions were for first downs. In the third quarter, Testaverde was 7 of 7 for 80 yards and the Browns held the ball for 11 minutes 21 seconds of the period.

In the second quarter, when Cleveland was trailing by 7-3, Testaverde picked up 14 yards on back-to-back scrambles to keep Cleveland's first touchdown drive going. He capped the drive with a 5-yard touchdown pass to receiver Mark Carrier, a former teammate at Tampa Bay.

``I knew before the game that he was ready to play,'' Carrier said. ``He threw me a couple of passes in the pregame and he was really pumped up. He was so pumped up I think he might have had to take some oxygen.''
Testaverde settled down nicely in time for the game. Other than working from the game plan, Testaverde said he entered the game with a simple strategy.

``On every play I tried to make something happen,'' he said. ``I didn't want to make any plays where we had negative yardage. If it meant I had to scramble, I'd scramble. If it meant I had to throw the ball away, I threw it away. This is the playoffs and every play is important. If you lose, you go home.''

Drew Bledsoe, the Patriots' second-year quarterback who was also making his first playoff apppearance, learned that hard lesson. Bledsoe's 50 pass attempts were the most against the Browns this year and the most against Cleveland in the playoffs. But he completed just 21 of them and threw 3 interceptions.

Under heavy pressure and looking at a variety of blitz packages and zone and man coverages in various disguises, Bledsoe was never able to get into a passing rhythm. When the Patriots were trailing by 17-10 early in the fourth quarter, Bledsoe threw interceptions on successive drives to kill scoring opportunities.

``We knew if we kept hitting him we could rattle him,'' said Browns defensive end Rob Burnett. ``He started talking to the refs after a while, saying we were hitting him late. You know when the quarterback starts to talk to the refs, then he doesn't have his mind on what he's supposed to be doing. We knew we were getting to him.''

The Patriots were tied with the Browns at 10-10 late in the third quarter. Then Testaverde completed all four passes on a 79-yard drive capped by Leroy Hoard's 10-yard scoring run, putting the Browns ahead to stay.

Bledsoe had one final chance to tie the game after the Patriots kicked a field goal, then recovered an onside kick at their 36 with 1:28 to play. But after getting one first down, he threw four straight incompletions from his 48.

New England Coach Bill Parcells decided to keep the power running back Marion Butts on the bench and go with Corey Croom, who hadn't started a game this season and had started just one last year. It was a curious decision, which Parcells chalked up to wanting to get ``a little change'' in the offense. It didn't pay off.

``Butts isn't one of those backs who has 50 or more catches this year,'' Burnett said. ``I think they did it because they wanted backs in the game who could catch the ball. They came in here thinking that Bledsoe could beat us. He couldn't.''

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW STOCK AND BOND ISSUES FELL BY ALMOST 33 PERCENT IN 1994

TEXT.P: After a strong start, 1994 limped to a disappointing close for Wall Street's underwriters.
New issues of stocks and bonds totaled $709 billion for the year, down nearly 33 percent from 1993's record of more than $1 trillion and the lowest total since 1991, according to Securities Data Co.
The large decline in underwriting volume is the best illustration of the difficulties that plagued the securities industry last year, its most trying since the downturn of the late 1980s.

Underwriting new stocks and bonds is one of the industry's most lucrative businesses. In 1994 the total underwriting fees disclosed by Wall Street companies plunged more than 39 percent from 1993, according to Securities Data.

But not all the news was bad for Wall Street in 1994. Mergers and takeover activity reached a record $339.4 billion, surpassing the previous record of $335.8 billion set in 1988, according to Securities Data.

In contrast to the highly speculative takeovers typical of the merger boom of the 1980s, the 1994 deals were dominated by corporations making strategic moves to increase their reach in industries like telecommunications, health care, pharmaceuticals, financial services and high technology.

Analysts and investment bankers expect the merger trend to continue this year, as a weak dollar and relatively strong stock market make deals attractive. And as buyers look beyond banks to finance their deals, the trend could also help to lift the junk bond market.

The plunge in underwriting volume shows how swiftly Wall Street's fortunes can decline. The year began strongly, as the industry continued to ride a four-year boom that had seen steady declines in interest rates. With rates at a record low in 1993 and stock prices strong, many corporations took the opportunity to raise cash by issuing stocks and bonds.

When the Federal Reserve began raising short-term interest rates in February, the issuing of debt became more expensive. At the same time, the strong economy lifted revenue for many companies, diminishing their need to tap the markets for capital.

``Most companies had pre-funded a lot of their debt needs for the next year or two in 1993,'' said Seth Waugh, managing director of global debt financing at Merrill Lynch Co., which was the industry's leading underwriter in 1994 for the seventh consecutive year.

As the Fed continued to raise rates in each quarter, the volume of new bond issues declined. The $117 billion raised from new issues in the fourth quarter was nearly 60 percent lower than the amount raised in the first quarter. It was also the lowest quarterly total since the end of 1990, according to Securities Data.

Overall, the underwriting of mortgage-backed securities slid the furthest last year, falling 57 percent, as the climb in interest rates ended a boom in home-mortgage refinancing. Junk-bond underwriting fell nearly 39 percent, followed by investment-grade debt, whose underwriting fell 27 percent.

The rising rates also took their toll on the underwriting of stocks. Though the business remained relatively strong in the first half of the year, it fell off quickly as investors began to worry that the rising returns offered by bonds would divert funds from the stock market.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

``By the third quarter, the environment was very difficult on the new-issues side,'' said Tom Davis, head of equity capital markets at Merrill Lynch. The number of new issues dried up as companies postponed or canceled offerings.

Though the stock markets have remained relatively strong, the equity underwriting business has stayed weak. ``While the flow of funds into equities has slowed, it has not reversed,'' Davis said. ``The concern is still out there, but the reality hasn't materialized yet.''
As domestic new issues dried up, a larger portion of new issues of both debt and equity in the second half of 1994 were foreign. That is a trend that Merrill Lynch expects to continue this year.

``Foreigners didn't really take advantage of lower rates,'' Waugh said. Emerging markets in Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe are in a building phase, and if they are looking for long-term debt, they have little choice but to tap the American capital markets, he added.
But James Bianco, director of research at the Arbor Trading Group in Barrington, Ill., said domestic debt issuers were scarce because they were getting better deals from banks.
``Wall Street has a problem,'' he said. ``It is pushing a product that is not very attractive in the current environment.''

That is because, with short-term lending rates high, banks can raise cash from depositors relatively cheaply. Meanwhile, Wall Street companies have been forced to pay higher short-term rates to finance their underwritings. And the banks are making loans at relatively high medium-term rates.

The banks also helped fuel the record number of deals in 1994. ``The level of interest rates is not as key as the availability of funds,'' said Eric Gleacher, an investment banker who specializes in mergers and acquisitions.
Gleacher and other merger specialists say that the number of deals will remain high next year as industries continue to consolidate.
``I think you are going to see more activity from European companies next year,'' he said, ``because the European economy is coming back and the dollar is very weak.''

DOC.HEADLINE: A MILLION-DOLLAR FIGHT OVER 100 ACRES OF SCRUB OAK AND MARSH

TEXT.P: One bright autumn day a few dozen people waded across a shallow inlet to Bird Island, one of the last privately owned, undeveloped islands on the East Coast.

Surf broke gently at their feet. Small dunes rose behind them, backed by the twisted pines and scrub oak of the island's tiny maritime forest. On the far side of the narrow island, yellow-green marsh grass shimmered in the sunlight.
One person stood apart from the others, silent. He was Rees Poag; his mother, Jane Price Poag, owns the island and he is seeking permission to develop it.

``I am the Devil,'' he had said earlier as he sat by himself at a lunch sponsored by the Bird Island Preservation Society, which led the trip and whose name sums up its mission. ``These people think of me as the Devil.''

He and his mother have not said exactly what they would want to build on Bird Island. And even the most ardent advocates of preserving it say they should be compensated if they are barred from building.
The question is, How much?

As real estate goes, Bird Island does not amount to much. Most of the 1,100-plus acres are underwater at high tide; only about 100 acres are high and dry, and only about 30 or 40 of them are developable. And since a wooden bridge burned about 20 years ago, the only access is by boat, or by bare feet across a meandering inlet at low tide.
But Bird Island lies about halfway between the rapid growth of Wilmington, N.C., and the throbbing resort towns of Myrtle Beach and the Grand Strand of South Carolina.
Mrs. Poag's first husband bought the whole thing for less than $7,000 30 years ago, and today assessors in Sunset Beach, the town in which most of the island lies, value it at about $1.2 million.

State officials and environmentalists reckon that North Carolina would probably be willing to pay that much for it. But if there were a bridge, the arithmetic could suddenly change; the 30 or 40 buildable acres might bring $350-500,000 each, for a total of $10 million to $20 million.
Naturally, Poag says he would like to build a bridge.

``I see it as a very desirable piece of property,'' Poag said. ``This property sits at the terminus of the projected I-73 coming out from the Midwest. You have explosive growth just down the coast from here. There's not much undeveloped coast.''

There are some among the preservation group who maintain that the Poag family has no intention of doing any development. The family, which is seeking a bridge permit, this theory goes, is doing so only to jack up the price the state must eventually pay for the island.
Poag denied that charge. And he noted, with more than a tinge of irritation in his voice, that the bridge would begin and end on his family's property and would be built entirely with family money.
``You have to be concerned a little bit about property rights,'' he said. ``There are a lot of people who act as if this property were their own.''

(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS) One of them, in a sense, is Frank Nesmith (NEE-smith), a sturdy, white-haired man who has been fishing on or near the island for 45 years and who now lives on the mainland nearby.

Members of the preservation society call Nesmith the island's keeper and he estimates that he has led several thousand people from all over the United States on informal island nature walks, including the group that Poag joined.

Nesmith, who advertises the walks with handmade signs he posts in Sunset Beach, charges participants nothing. Since the dispute over the island's future has heated up, however, he has ended his talks with ``a commercial,'' an appeal for donations to the society.
Though he loves the entire island, its marsh grips his heart. ``As pretty as Grand Canyon,'' he said, gazing out across the water and grass. ``I don't know why it is so pretty to me, but it is.''
Because of the dispute over the island's future, Nesmith said, he keeps his groups to ``the wet beach,'' the area between the low and high tide lines that is in the public domain.
As the dispute drags on, bitterness on all sides grows.
Poag is irritated by the people who troop onto his island, even if they stay on the wet beach. Members of the society are angry with Poag.

But some, like Todd Miller of the North Carolina Coastal Federation, a conservation group, save their irritation for the state. They say officials are needlessly prolonging the a decision on the application to build a bridge, which they say is certain to end in denial.
But the process, and its attendant studies and fees, could cost the Poags hundreds of thousands of dollars, money they will ultimately want to recoup.

The seemingly endless review process continues. The Coast Guard said at the end of December that it had reversed an earlier decision and would allow the Poags to submit a relatively modest environmental assessment, rather than an elaborate environmental impact statement, on the effects a bridge would have on the inlet.
Meanwhile, the coastal federation plans to ask the state Coastal Resources Commission to rule on whether state regulations would permit a bridge over the inlet.

``The decision is going to be pretty telling,'' Miller said. ``From the perspective of the public, it's an easy case to deal with. There is massive public support to see that the island is protected. If the state can't deliver on Bird Island, there is little hope it can deal effectively with more complicated issues.''

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORIAL: THE SCHOOLS ARE GETTING BETTER

TEXT.P: The New York Times said in an editorial on Monday, Jan. 2:

It is widely accepted that the public schools are in decline and that one major reason for poor student performance is the disintegration of families. But a recent study by the Rand Corporation suggests just the opposite.

Student performance has actually improved over the last two decades, especially among minorities, thanks largely to changes within families. This startling evaluation deserves careful examination by politicians and Washington officials before they indiscriminately dismantle social programs that may actually have worked.

As households with working dads and stay-at-home moms became an increasingly smaller proportion of American families, social policy-makers worried about the effects of divorce, illegitimacy and working mothers on student achievement. But the Rand study found that factors like parental education, household income, family size and the age of the mother when the child was born are more important than family structure.

The Rand researchers looked at the results of standardized math and verbal tests -- known as the National Assessment of Educational Progress -- taken by youths aged 13 to 18 in the 1970s compared to the same age group in the 1990s. The scores went up an average of 3 percentile points for white students, 11 points for Hispanic students and 19 points for black students.

These tests, administered to a broad range of students, were considered better barometers of school performance than the scholastic aptitude tests, which exclude the non-college-bound students who made the greatest gains in recent decades and whose results can be skewed by changes in the mix of students going on to college.

The researchers found that the biggest family factors contributing to higher scores on the assessment tests were a drop in family size, freeing more resources for each child, and a rise in parental education levels. Those positive influences were tempered somewhat by an increase in births to younger mothers and an increase in the number of poor, single-parent families.

As the debate over public spending heats up in Washington, these findings could buttress the argument for more, not less, help for poor families and poor young mothers. The Rand researchers suggest that academic gains made in the last 20 years by minority students can be attributed in large part to public policies promoting equal educational opportunity and increased investment in children, families and schools.

The Rand study reinforces the notion that children benefit from being in healthy families. But it also makes an indirect case for selected and targeted government programs that promote the academic growth of children and their parents.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORIAL: BIPARTISAN FOREIGN POLICY

TEXT.P: The New York Times said in an editorial on Monday, Jan. 2:

In the new year, President Clinton confronts a new foreign policy reality -- a Republican Congress. Republicans are less united on international issues than on their domestic agenda. But critics of specific administration policies now lead both houses and chair key committees.

They have ample constitutional power to obstruct the president's agenda and advance their own. The Senate has the authority to confirm nominees and ratify treaties, and both houses can vote down or condition appropriations for everything from foreign aid and intelligence to troop deployments.

Sharper foreign policy debate can be healthy. The administration has not performed so brilliantly that it can afford to brush off useful criticism. No great philosophical differences divide Clinton from mainstream Republicans on many issues, and both parties need to consider how to reshape U.S. policies to a changed world.
What are America's interests today? What are appropriate uses of U.S. military force? What is the right relationship between trade expansion and other objectives?

As a candidate, Clinton promised dramatic reversals on a few high-profile issues like Bosnia, China and Haiti. That rhetoric was soon abandoned. Aside from Haiti, Clinton has generally kept George Bush's policies in place while focusing on domestic reform. A broad consensus is likely to continue over trade, the Middle East and some elements of arms control.
Congressional challenges are likely over Bosnia, NATO, Russia, China, peacekeeping and foreign aid.

Republican leaders liken foreign aid to welfare and demand that most aid not related to security or political aims be cut. But the aid budget has already been cut by nearly a third over the last five years, and most foreign aid is related to security or political aims.

Of the $14 billion foreign aid budget, $5 billion is earmarked for Israel and Egypt and another $1.2 billion goes to assist countries trying to move from socialism to capitalism. Most of the remainder goes to humanitarian, environmental and population programs that are the best insurance against new Somalias and Rwandas.
Republicans will press for more aggressive efforts to lift the arms embargo against the Bosnian government, efforts the administration should try to harness and in some cases support.

Washington should make clear to its European allies that if they prevent the United Nations from lifting the embargo, the administration may be unable to resist Congressional pressure for the United States to lift it independently.
The administration should vigorously resist all calls for direct U.S. involvement in the war.

Many Republicans favor incorporating Eastern European countries in NATO, which would needlessly isolate and provoke Moscow. Eastern Europe needs economic support and early access to the European Union far more urgently than it needs new military guarantees. The administration itself moved too hastily last year toward moving the NATO security umbrella eastward.

Mainstream Republicans favor continued support for reform and arms reduction in Russia, but want to make aid conditional on how Moscow treats the former Soviet republics. Such conditioning must be done carefully. America's security does not lie in isolating and humiliating Russia, but in encouraging its constructive participation in European and Asian affairs.

Republicans will also insist that Washington stand up more forcefully to Chinese bullying on human rights, trade, Taiwan and Tibet. A tougher line could help over time, but short-term progress is unlikely with China already in the throes of a succession struggle.

International peacekeeping has been a favorite Republican target, even though the administration is now cautious to a fault about committing U.S. troops to such operations. Recent U.N. operations have been troubled. But peacekeeping is a cost-efficient deal for the United States.

If the United Nations were so financially hobbled that it could no longer mount operations in support of policies Washington favors, American forces might have to act alone, at far greater human and financial cost to the United States.

This administration still has a chance to leave a credible foreign policy legacy, but for the next two years it will have to do so in conjunction with mainstream Republicans like Sen. Richard Lugar and Rep. Benjamin Gilman.

There will be unbridgeable differences. There should be substantive debate. But with good will and good luck, the result could be the kind of bipartisan foreign policy politicians often rhapsodize about but rarely produce.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITORIAL: GEORGE PATAKI'S VISION

TEXT.P: The New York Times said in an editorial on Monday, Jan. 2:

Early in Sunday's inaugural address, New York's new governor, George Pataki, paid gracious tribute to Mario Cuomo. He then took the next 35 minutes to make it unmistakably clear that the government to expect under his leadership will be radically different in attitude and agenda from anything New Yorkers have known during Cuomo's 12 years in Albany.
``The people seek change,'' he said. ``Let us give them sweeping and fundamental change that is certain and immediate.''

The centerpiece of Pataki's philosophy of change, a theme to which he returned again and again, is to restore a sense of individual responsibility, and release individual energies, by lightening the ``oppressive'' hand of government. There is, he asserted, a sense of crisis among many people, but it is ``a crisis not of the people's making but of the government's.'' And ``what those in government have done, those in government can undo.''
This speech was a declaration of war on liberal, regulatory, interventionist government, and it described his thinking more fully than any campaign speech.

His agenda was predictably conservative: lower taxes, a leaner, more responsive bureaucracy, lower government spending, privatized government services, term limits. He pledged to work for safer schools and safer streets: his call for the death penalty -- which this page opposes -- drew the loudest applause.

Though not in his predecessor's class as an orator, Pataki was full of earnest, even youthful enthusiasm. Summoning up New York's past to inspire its future, he invoked the ``revolutionary spirit'' of Saratoga and the ``faith and optimism'' of Ellis Island.

He also took his listeners on a kind an alliterative tour of New York's cultural, scenic and commercial glories, from ``Rochester to the Rockaways.'' He had kind words for New York City, where suspicions about his agenda are the strongest.

Pataki's pledges to re-invent Albany and end the ``cycle of dependency'' on government will resonate strongly with many New Yorkers. One big question, however, is whether he can achieve his aims without cruel damage to those who depend for basic subsistence on many of the programs that Pataki has targeted for reform.

The poor did not figure heavily in this speech. Whereas Cuomo had used his inaugurals to speak of government's responsibility to the weak and the marginalized, Pataki referred just once to society's ``solemn obligation'' to help ``those less fortunate.'' Yet even this reference came in the context of another attack on the welfare system, which he said no longer operated as a safety net but as a ``spider web'' of dependency.

The governor must now turn to the daunting task of translating his promises into legislation and then into reality. But inaugurals are not about the pesky details. They are about philosophy. Pataki has left little doubt about where he is coming from and where he wants to go.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS TALK OF POWER ON THE LAST DAYS WITH IT

TEXT.P: Like the dispirited troops of a defeated army, Democrats and Congressional staff members prepared to relinquish cherished posts and cluttered, file-filled cabinets on the eve of the Republican takeover of the House of Representatives. Lunch gatherings were grim, partings tearful and wishes for the new year filled with gallows humor.
At the Ford Annex building, Judi Greenwald introduced several colleagues as they were packing: ``We're with the subcommittee on Energy and Power. At least we are until the end of the day.''
The absolute, and at times absolutely capricious, exercise of power on Capitol Hill was a recurrent theme throughout that long goodbye.

Each of those staff members had known for nearly a year that they would be unemployed come 1995, since Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., for whom they all worked, chose not to run for re-election. But not one had expected to be part of a broader exodus.
``We knew a long time ago,'' Ms. Greenwald said. ``We just didn't have any idea that we were going to be in a whole throng of people.''
For Leon Lowery, who played Scrooge to everyone else's Pollyanna, the departure had great import.

``Not only have you lost your personal job,'' he said somberly, ``but people are telling you that the whole ideology you represent has been rejected by America. Personally, professionally, emotionally -- any level you take -- it's pretty tough.''
Shelley Fidler just grimaced. ``Leon has been reading the Bible,'' she said. ``Lamentations.''

Lowery raised an eyebrow that would have been jaundiced if eyebrows could master such intricate attitude. ``A lot of people don't believe in government,'' he said with a touch of devilish revenge. ``But now they are going to have to run it.''

Not everyone was so morose. While assorted Democrats fretted, feted and gnashed, Newt Gingrich and his newly minted Republican majority were champing at the bit as they prepared to take over the House.

Parties around the city were full of exuberant revelers still toasting the November victory, while the recently anointed seemed as anxious as new suitors as they prepared to move into new offices across the Hill.

Washington's permanent population was already figuring to profit from the shift. Among the first businesses to capitalize on the change has been that most ephemeral and yet most constant of Washington power bases: the trendy restaurants in which dining and doing business combine.
``Republicans eat, too,'' said Steven Damato, the owner of Nora's, a homey-trendy restaurant that is a favorite of President Clinton's family.

Damato said the restaurant would be host to a Republican event on Tuesday, one night before the 104th Congress convenes. And the future looks good, too. ``Change is wonderful for business,'' he said, capturing a Washington credo. ``The restaurants will be packed full of special interests.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
(MORE)

Real estate agents were crowing as well, using the most potent of Washington put-offs to archly inform reporters that they were simply too busy to talk. Several moaned that they could not stay on the phone for more than several minutes since their appointments with incoming power brokers were stacked like salmon jumping the rapids in spawning season.

``There has been an awful lot of scurrying around,'' said a very rushed Mike Frias, an agent at John Forman Real Estate. By most accounts, the new Washingtonians and the freshman invaders were settling as near as possible to ground zero, in the Victorian row houses and quaint apartments that bank the tree-lined but sometimes crime-infested streets near Capitol Hill.

It makes for a blissfully short commute and great public relations bites. ``These folks come in extremely early, work late. If they have a break, they want to go home,'' Frias said. Few have been buying properties, though.

``New members are not interested in giving their constituency the impression that they are becoming entrenched,'' he explained. Or else, just maybe, they have a clear and present sense of the fickleness of a disgruntled electorate.

Over at revolution central, in federal buildings where unsuspecting professionals have been chopped out of politics in part of a general restructuring initiated by Gingrich, confusion and resentment mixed with a poignant sense of purpose.

``I guess I am looking for a job,'' said Dr. Raymond Smock, the recently out-of-work House historian, who had to inform his staff of five that they were also abruptly unemployed since the office was decreed closed by the new House speaker. ``But, hey, I'm not complaining. Five thousand Amtrak employees are out of work. Nobody has any sympathy for anybody on the hill who lost his job.''
In federal buildings on the hill this week, offices were exchanged and furniture dragged about in the traditional horse trading that comes with the flip-flop of minority and majority slots.
Republicans moved into majority cubbyholes. The erstwhile majority slipped down to minority digs. But some offices just closed for good -- all part of a extensive restructuring.

It is hard, though, to quantify the scope of change just now. The House historian's office can not say because the facts and figures of the 104th Congress are not history yet. By the time the statistics emerge, the office will be long since obsolete itself.

Last week, even the House clerk's loyal staff could not answer basic questions. Inquiries about staff changes, personnel cutbacks and committee clear-outs were referred to Gingrich's office with the rather terse advice: ``Ask him. He's the guy with the power. He's only one who knows what's happening.''

The city's true denizens, of course, are used to all of this. Washington's equivalent of a stiff upper lip is a rather chronic sense of denial. ``We're used to this,'' said countless members of the newly unemployed. ``It's politics.''
Subsets of the city were already gearing up for an adrenaline rush, though.

John Brademas, the chairman of the President's Committee on Arts and Humanities, girded for guerrilla warfare. A longtime congressman and a former president of New York University, he knows how to play politics with the best of them.

After rather sadly conceding that funding for the arts, education and humanities are all prominent targets for the cutting board, he mentioned almost casually that most of the prominent board members of major opera companies, museums, theater groups were powerful Republicans with ample funds and huge political leverage.

``We're not quite sure what's going to happen yet,'' Brademas said. ``But savage reductions in these programs would mark a giant step backwards. And at least in my experience -- which stretches back to Eisenhower -- every government has come up with funds.''
Fine and well for opera singers if that record holds. But the House historian, Smock, really did seem to be watching history pass by last week.
Tapping his foot against a nondescript wood crate, he rather reverently mentioned that its contents were none other than the private letters and records of former House Speaker Joe Cannon.
``It doesn't look like something out of `The Raiders of the Lost Ark,' '' he said, creaking open the crate's top. ``But, hey, it's the real thing.''
And in this city of smoked salmon and oversized mirrors, that is rare indeed.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPE WON'T PUSH YELTSIN ON POLICY FOR FEAR OF WEAKENING HIM

TEXT.P: Two years ago, the Russian foreign minister horrified a gathering of 53 European countries in Stockholm by announcing what he called ``a correction in the course of Russian foreign policy.''

Foreign Minister Andrei Kozyrev warned that Russia saw a threat in overtures by NATO to formerly communist countries in Eastern Europe, and in Western hostility to the Serbs in the war in Bosnia. Moscow, he said, had a right to intervene militarily in what he called the ``post-imperial space'' around it, and would not hesitate to exercise it.

Then Kozyrev told his startled listeners that he didn't really mean it -- that he was just trying to shock all of them into realizing that President Boris Yeltsin's democratic and pro-Western policies could be elbowed aside by Russian hardliners if the West pushed him too hard in Eastern Europe and Bosnia.
Ever since, Western European leaders have been noticeably reluctant to criticize Yeltsin's actions in Russia's backyard and in Bosnia, for fear of weakening him.
They are more reluctant than ever now that some of Kozyrev's prophecies appear to have come true with the Russian assault on the rebellious province of Chechnya.

In an interview taped Friday and shown on Sunday on the NBC News program ``Meet the Press,'' Kozyrev said that there was ``no other way but to use force'' in Chechnya ``to reinstall law and order and to rescue the population'' from criminals.
``It is just intolerable to have a military gang anywhere, be it in the center of Moscow, be it in Los Angeles or whatever, or Chechnya, and we have to put it down,'' he said.

Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who is on a first-name basis with Yeltsin, had not called the Russian leader to express concern at mounting civilian deaths in Chechnya, the chancellor's spokesman said Friday. He said he had no plans to do so.
The spokesman said Kohl backed the message Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel passed to Kozyrev on Thursday on behalf of all his European Union colleagues.
Kinkel did not warn Moscow to stop its attacks, as the Clinton administration did the same day in a statement by the State Department.

Instead, he expressed ``great concern'' over the situation in Chechnya and the increasing number of civilian victims of the military operations in the capital, Grozny. On Friday, in Moscow, the Greek, German, and French ambassadors, on behalf of the European Union, reiterated Kinkel's views in a formal diplomatic demarche.

Kozyrev agreed, the German Foreign Ministry said, that a political solution had to be found as quickly as possible, one that respected the agreements on human rights and the peaceful settlement of disputes that Russia had signed within the framework of the 53-nation Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe.
That is apparently as far as most European leaders are willing to push the Russians at the moment, to the dismay of advocates of stronger international protest.

``With its inaction, the German government creates the impression that Russia has a privileged status on violations of human rights and the use of force in internal disputes,'' said one of Kohl's critics, Norbert Gansel of the Social Democratic Party.

In fact, according to several diplomats, the European and American caution reflects growing concern that Yeltsin has already lost ground to resurgent nationalists in Moscow, and fear that stronger Western protest could make him weaker.

But the change in Russia's course has unsettled European governments already shaken by disagreements with the United States about what to do about the war in Bosnia, and how fast to invite formerly Communist Eastern European countries into the Western fold.
A year ago, American foreign policy seemed to Europeans to be bending over backwards to allay Russian opposition to the possible expansion of the NATO alliance.

Many senior European officials thought the U.S. position reflected the influence of Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, an expert on the former Soviet Union whom they suspected of wanting smooth relations with Moscow even at the cost of Western interests in the democracies of Eastern Europe.
But over the last few months, American policy has changed.

Washington was riding roughshod over its allies, negotiating terms of possible membership with the Eastern Europeans and presenting NATO with accomplished facts instead of consulting with them, the German representative to NATO, Hermann von Richthofen, complained in a telegram to the Foreign Ministry in Bonn in November.

Secretary of State Warren Christopher appeared to have patched over the disagreement on Dec. 1, when he got NATO foreign ministers to agree to let the alliance tell Eastern Europeans within the next 12 months what they had to do to qualify for eventual membership if they wanted it.

But Kozyrev threw salt on the wounds the very same day, telling the assembled allies that Russia would not sign on to a detailed military cooperation plan with NATO until it found out what the allies' new approach to Eastern Europe meant.

Whether this was a clever maneuver intended to exploit allied differences or a reflection of Yeltsin's shaky grip in Moscow, it reawakened European fears about losing Russian help in dealing with the Serbs in the Balkans. The Russians are the only outside power that President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia listens to, in the European view, and Milosevic is the best hope of pressing the Bosnian Serbs to accept a peace settlement.

With NATO temporarily paralyzed by British and French concern about retaliation against their soldiers in Bosnia in the event of allied air strikes, the Europeans prevailed in December with the view that Russian diplomatic help in Bosnia was needed more than ever.

Critics of inaction in Bosnia denounced that as weakness. The underlying weakness may be that both European and American leaders see no alternative to Yeltsin in Moscow. Whatever the Russian military does in his name in the northern Caucasus, the prospect of effective international opposition to more war there seems remote.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOCKEY BARGAINING IS ON AGAIN

TEXT.P: Brian Burke, a senior vice president of the National Hockey League, was part of the small group that resumed bargaining Sunday in an effort to end the lockout that has postponed the start of the season for more than three months.

There were no details available from the subcommittee meeting, which was held at an undisclosed site under a news media blackout. It was expected that Burke and fellow NHL executive Jeff Pash would represent the league. Two attorneys, Bob Riley and John McCambridge, were to represent the Players Association.

These were the first such meetings since Dec. 17. Should the small groups agree to a framework for a new collective bargaining agreement, it is likely that they would be joined by Gary Bettman, commissioner of the league, and Bob Goodenow, executive director of the union. Those two haven't bargained since Dec. 6.

Bettman said last week that play must begin by Jan. 16 if each team is to play 50 regular-season games, followed by a full playoff tournament before July 1. Without an agreement, the entire season could be canceled.

Meanwhile, if Burke has time between bargaining sessions, he might get to read a paper on labor disputes in sports recently written by Paul Weiler, the Henry J. Friendly professor of law at Harvard Law School.
Weiler, a specialist in labor and sports law, calls the paper ``A Prescription for the Sports Disease.'' It will be part of a book called ``Sports on Trial,'' which he expects to publish next year.

Weiler recently sent Burke a copy of his theories. That made sense, since the two men go back a long way. ``Brian was my first student in the sports law program that I developed 15 years ago here at Harvard,'' Weiler said Sunday in a telephone interview.

Weiler feels part of hockey's difficulty is that team owners don't separate two different problems. One is of salary escalation, which they can't solve without player help; the other is disparity of revenue between big and small markets, which they can solve on their own. If they would agree to share revenue in a way that involves business principals and not internal charity, they wouldn't need to demand what Weiler calls ``a draconian tax'' on player payrolls.

``The big-market owners are saying, `We don't want to give any charity to the small-market owners from ourselves, but we don't mind getting a little bit of charity from our players,''' Weiler said. ``What they really want is for the players to give away their money to the small-market owners through a very, very rigid, punitive salary tax.''

The demand for a tax of up to 25 percent on total payrolls is what led to the last breakdown in talks. The players call it a salary cap in disguise. While acknowledging that owners might be suffering losses overall as a group and that the union should have studied the league's financial condition before the current crisis, Weiler said the union also has acknowledged the problem through deed, if not word, during bargaining.

``Goodenow and the players have made significant concessions to put a drag on salaries,'' Weiler said. ``At a certain point, you have to know when to declare victory. The owners in hockey should declare victory and should say `We've gotten enough, and we can do the revenue-sharing thing ourselves.'''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

Weiler said that in sports bargaining, unlike in other industries, there is a ``huge crisis every go-round'' and a mood that ``unless you solve the whole crisis all at once, you haven't done a thing.''

As for revenue-sharing, Weiler said big-revenue teams oppose it because they think of it as charity. He noted that many small-market team owners are wealthy as individuals, and that they should pay fair value for the right to share revenue.

``It should be perceived as a sale of a portion of the revenues, just the same as if the Canadiens or the Bruins sold off part of the value of the team,'' Weiler said. ``If the Canadiens give part of their revenues, from their big market, to Quebec, and if the Bruins give part of their revenue to Hartford, the owners of the Nordiques and Whalers should pay for it.
``You sell off the right to a flow of revenue in the future, and you get the full capitalized value of that. The owners didn't see this. That's one of the things that bugs me.''

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-GIANTS REUNION: TWO COACHES, TWO LINEBACKERS

TEXT.P: When the New England Patriots played the Browns here late in the 1993 season, Pepper Johnson approached Bill Parcells during the warmups.
``Why,'' the Browns linebacker asked, ``did you leave me?''

Once together on the Giants' two Super Bowl championship teams, they separated in 1991 when Parcells resigned as coach. And after Parcells joined the Patriots as their coach in 1993, Johnson was signed by Bill Belichick -- once his Giants' defensive coordinator -- after he had surprisingly been sliced by Dan Reeves, the Giants' coach.

But Sunday Parcells, Belichick, the linebacker known as Pepper and another Giant linebacker of their Super Bowl era, Carl Banks, were together again as the Browns eliminated the growing Patriots, 20-13, in an American Conference wild-card confrontation in the Super Bowl XXIX playoffs. Together and yet so separate.
``He's just another coach like I am when the game's on,'' Parcells was saying now, referring to Belichick. ``Tomorrow it'll be different.''

When Sunday's game ended in the raw gray chill of Cleveland Stadium, it was different. Parcells and Belichick hugged at midfield as Johnson and Banks mingled with them. Banks joined the Browns this year after having spent the 1993 season with the Washington Redskins.
``When you play defense in the playoffs,'' Parcells said, ``you're going to be representative in the playoffs. Our problem was turning the ball over late.''
One of those turnovers occurred when Johnson, who had sacked Drew Bledsoe early in the fourth quarter, intercepted the Patriots quarterback at the Browns' 31-yard line.
``That ball was tipped by Bill Johnson,'' Johnson said, referring to one of the Browns' defensive tackles. ``It just fell into my arms.''
Bob Kratch, once a Giant guard and signed by Parcells, thought that the Browns' use of their linebackers resembled what the Giants' 1990 championship defense did.

``We expected them to blitz as much as they did during the regular season,'' Kratch said, referring to the Browns' 13-6 victory here on Nov. 6. ``We figured we'd see everything. They didn't blitz nearly as much, but Pepper got his sack on a blitz.''
To Kratch, the Belichick influence on the Browns has created the look of an National Conference East team.
``I don't think of the Cleveland Browns as an AFC team,'' Kratch said. ``It seems like old-time football.''
But the Browns' defense, with its 4-3 alignment, is different than that of the two-time champion Giants.

``And the blitzing philosophy is different,'' Johnson said. ``When we blitzed with the Giants, it was a change of pace. And when Lawrence Taylor rushed, we didn't even call that a blitz. Here, we blitz to get momentum on our side. With the Giants, we blitzed on our own. Here, the blitzes are called.''
Even so, Banks described the Browns' basic defensive philosophy as basically similar to that of the Giants under Parcells and Belichick.
``The thing it shares is good tough football,'' Banks said. ``We don't take a lot of risks, which means our margin of error should be low. And we expect our players to be good tacklers.''
That defense will take the Browns to Pittsburgh for Saturday's divisional playoff, but the Steelers have an even better defense.
During the season the Steelers swept the Browns, 17-10 in Cleveland in the second game and 17-7 in Three Rivers Stadium two weeks ago.
``Defense is still the key,'' Parcells has often said. ``The teams that are going to win the big games are the good defensive teams.''

In other years, Parcells sprung surprise plays in post-season games: Gary Reason's ramble with a direct snap on a fake punt in the 1990 NFC championship game in San Francisco, Jeff Rutledge's quarterback sneak off a fake punt in Super Bowl XXI against the Denver Broncos. Yesterday he had the punter Pat O'Neill pass for a first down on fourth down.
``It's just a play we had ready,'' Parcells said. ``We always have plays like that.''

But for all the dazzling development of Bledsoe as a young quarterback and for all the justly earned coach-of-the-year honors for Parcells, the Patriots still need a few more cement blocks in their defense if they are to be a true Super Bowl contender.
Parcells had two rookie linebackers, Willie McGinest and Marty Moore, out there on defense. No team ever gets too far into the Super Bowl playoffs with two rookie linebackers.

But the Patriots have the coach and they have the quarterback. And when McGinest and Moore develop, just as Pepper Johnson and Carl Banks once developed under Bill Parcells long before they tormented him as opponents Sunday, the Patriots will be a team to fear.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD WATCHES TO SEE HOW ZEDILLO DEALS WITH FALLEN PESO

TEXT.P: When President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon goes on national television Monday night to outline his plan for rebuilding the crippled Mexican economy, he will also be doing his best to convince investors that the Mexican market they once thought the world of was not a mirage.

Zedillo worked through the New Year's weekend to put the finishing touches on an economic-stabilization plan that will limit wages, prices and government spending while lining up the financial backing of the United States and Canada, major European nations, American commercial banks and the International Monetary Fund.

In the United States as well as Mexico, investment bankers, money managers and financial analysts will be watching to see how Zedillo -- in office just a month -- applies the economics he learned at Stanford and refined at the Mexican central bank to this politically explosive situation. His challenge will be to lay out an economic recovery, while setting a national agenda that can keep the lid on simmering social problems bound to be aggravated by the disastrous devaluation of the peso last month.

Along with the details of a govenment agreement with labor and business that will be disclosed on Monday night, President Zedillo's stabilization plan will set much of Mexico's economic course for 1995. The most important points are expected to be these:
-- How does Zedillo intend to control inflation without causing a recession and possibly increasing social unrest?
-- How will price controls be enforced?
-- What policy will Mexico use to set exchange rates?
-- Which government-owned companies will be sold to investors to raise badly needed dollars?
-- What is the size and structure of the international rescue package, and will it be sufficient to restore investors' confidence?

``The main risk is that when you already are under a lot of pressure, you have to be real convincing,'' said Neal M. Soss, an economic consultant in New York. ``The world can be in an unforgiving frame of mind. If his plan doesn't appear to cover all the bases, and doesn't offer well-thought-out answers to all questions, he runs the risk of having another flight of capital.''

The peso's devaluation could turn out to be enormously damaging for Mexico. A study by Bear, Stearns Co. estimates that if the peso trades at a rate of about 4.90 to the dollar -- it closed at 5.0750 to the dollar on Friday -- Mexico's gross domestic product could fall to $250 billion in 1995 from $333 billion in 1993. Per-capita income might decline to $2,700 from $3,600 in 1993. The national debt would increase to 40 percent of gross domestic product, up from 26 percent.
To make his stabilization plan work, Zedillo will rely on the same sort of pact with labor and business that Mexican administrations have used for the last seven years.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
(MORE)

The agreement, backed by the persuasive powers of a party that has been in control for 65 years, helped get government, labor and business to agree to hold down prices, wages and public spending. All these groups stopped making wage and price demands based on existing inflation rates and agreed instead to work toward steadily improving targets, which helped bring down inflation to 8 percent in 1993, from 159 percent in 1987.
Zedillo is expected to reject the standing commitment to a semi-fixed exchange rate policy and adopt a more flexible system.

In previous pacts, the government agreed to hold the line on prices for goods it produces, like electricity and gasoline. It also pledged to keep the value of the peso within a tight trading band, no matter what changes took place in the international markets.
As a result, the peso got stronger -- which Mexicans liked because it meant that books, breakfast cereal or almost anything produced in the United States got cheaper.
From 1985 to 1992, imports grew by 238 percent. Exports increased by only 73 percent in the same years.

By the end of 1994, Mexico was importing so much more than it was exporting that it had accumulated a deficit of $28 billion. The government financed the debt with foreign money, a tactic that became impossible after investors started turning away from Mexico.

That led to a week-long speculative run on the peso, which ended just before Christmas. The government decided that it did not have enough money in reserve to defend the peso, and was forced to allowed it to float freely.
Within a few days, Mexico's currency fell in value by almost 30 percent.

Some economists have accused the Mexican government of hubris, saying that finance officials had become overly confident they could ward off any assault on the peso. They entered the crisis with $17 billion in reserves and standby lines of credit totaling about $7 billion from the United States and Canada.
This was not enough. More than $10 billion was pulled out of the country, first by Mexican investors, then by foreigners that week before Christmas.

Mexico is now looking for even greater backing from its trading partners. In the package that is already lined up, the Bank for International Settlements in Switzerland, which represents the central banks of Europe, will lend Mexico $6 billion to $10 billion. In addition, several American commercial banks have been asked to syndicate a loan of $3 billion to $6 billion.

There may also be some help from the International Monetary Fund, particularly in supervising the way Mexico handles the loans and its emergency stabilization plan. The appointment on Thursday of Guillermo Ortiz as finance minister -- in place of Jaime Serra Puche, who resigned -- could prove useful, as he worked as an executive director of the IMF from 1984 to 1988.

Many analysts say international backing will create confidence and help Mexico hold on to the foreign investments that have not yet been pulled out. One of Mexico's biggest concerns is the $30 billion in government notes known as tesobonos that come due in 1995. The notes are paid in pesos but are pegged to dollars, and the devaluation has substantially increased Mexico's obligations.

To encourage investors to roll over those notes instead of cashing them in, the central bank is expected to offer to replace mature tesobonos with something called sovereign debt bonds that will have longer terms and higher interest rates.

Another important part of Zedillo's plan is to raise the government's dollar revenue by speeding up the privatization of ports, petrochemical plants and electricity-generating stations. The government will also try to exploit the short-term price advantages of the devaluation to stem the flow of imports while increasing exports. The plan calls for cutting the current-account deficit of more than $28 billion by more than half by year's end.
Some economists think this goal is overly optimistic. But after the 1982 devaluation, the current-account deficit fell to $6 billion from $16 billion.

So far, the loudest complaints about the peso devaluation have come from foreign investors. The Mexican people, in many cases preoccupied with the holidays and their vacations, have not yet said much. Mexicans who have lived through other devaluations know they will again be asked to sacrifice. After the devaluation of 1982, for example, real wages fell 24 percent.

Mexico's outlook for the new year has already changed. When Zedillo took office on Dec. 1, the government's official estimates for 1995 were a growth rate of 4 percent, inflation of 4 percent and salary increases of about 10 percent, substantially above the rate of inflation.
Now, government economists are predicting 1 to 2 percent growth, 15 percent inflation and wage increases that do not keep up with inflation.

Inflation ravaged Mexico in the early 1980s and is again a central concern. ``The most difficult part of the recovery will be to really keep inflation in check,'' said Nora Lustig, an economist with the Brookings Institution in Washington.

The prices of products made of domestic material and sold in Mexico should not be affected by the devaluation. But after a devaluation, a kind of panic sets in and pushes everyone to raise prices, regardless of whether the product is imported.

Just a few days after the government said that prices across the board had been frozen for 60 days, the federal consumer protection agency shut down 27 stores in greater Mexico City for jacking up the prices of -- among other things -- tortillas and milk.

``The government will probably be able to get agreement from the business leaders not to raise prices, but what if there is no discipline in the ranks?'' Ms. Lustig said. ``What is supposed to be a single jump in prices to reflect the devaluation could become a spiral.''

DOC.HEADLINE: RESCUED FRENCH SOLO SAILOR TAKEN TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Isabelle Autissier, the French solo sailor who was airlifted from her stricken yacht Saturday in the Indian Ocean, said on Sunday that a huge wave had crippled her boat by rolling it over 360 degrees.
Autissier is expected to arrive on Monday in Adelaide, Australia, aboard an Australian Navy frigate, the HMAS Darwin.
The 38-year-old competitor in the BOC round-the-world race told competition officials by radio that she was fortunate to have been below deck when the wave hit on Wednesday.
``If I had been on the deck, I would have been washed away,'' she said, referring to her 60-foot yacht, Ecureuil Poitou-Charentes 2.
The accident occurred about 850 miles southwest of Hobart, Australia.

``The wind was blowing over 50 knots,'' she said, ``and I was making 8 knots with all my sails down. I was inside the boat, very fortunately for me, inside a narrow passage. I could hear the noise of a very big wave coming.''

The rollover filled the boat with water, and forced Autissier to slam shut a rear bulkhead door to keep the yacht from sinking. She moved her food and clothing to a forward part of the hull, where she lived until being rescued.

The force of being turned upside down caused part of the deck to cave in. Once the boat righted itself again, Autissier covered the 15-foot hole with a sail to try to keep water out. She had no steering, and knew that her only hope for survival was to set off two emergency radio beacons. The satellite distress calls were relayed to race officials in Charleston, S.C.

A Sea Hawk-class helicopter plucked Autissier from her damaged yacht three days later. The helicopter was brought within 100-miles of Autissier by the HMAS Darwin. Salvagers left Hobart on Sunday to try and retrieve Autissier's sailboat.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARDOSO INAUGURATED AS PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a 63-year-old sociologist, was inaugurated as Brazil's president on Sunday, promising to give all his energy to banishing inflation from Latin America's largest nation.
``The majority of Brazilians made a clear choice'' for low inflation and high growth, Cardoso said, referring to his landslide electoral victory in October.
Cardoso, the architect of Brazil's radically successful anti-inflation plan, also vowed in his inaugural address before Congress to further open Brazil to foreign investment and trade.
With ``the opening of the Brazilian economy, we are leaving behind xenophobic attitudes,'' said Cardoso, whose government experience includes recent stints as foreign minister and finance minister.
``Today, there is no serious specialist who does not forecast for Brazil anything but a long period of growth,'' he said.

While 21-gun salutes and fighter jet flyovers noisily marked Cardoso's new role as commander in chief on Sunday, some recalled that he was once exiled and blacklisted for his opposition to Brazil's military rule, a period that lasted from 1964 to 1985.

``It's an irony I savor,'' a longtime friend of Cardoso, Peter D. Bell, recalled from New York. When Bell worked for the Ford Foundation in Rio de Janeiro in 1969, U.S. Embassy officials unsuccessfully pressured him to withhold funding for a study group Cardoso was forming. The American officials argued Cardoso was a Communist and that he had no future in Brazil.

``Fernando Henrique's real crime was that he was a card-carrying democrat,'' said Bell, who is a chairman of the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington-based policy group. ``In the context of the military dictatorship, democrats were seen as upsetting the apple cart.''

Twenty-five years later, Cardoso is a social democrat who enjoys heavy business support. On Sunday, he appealed in his nationally televised speech: ``Let us retire the old ideological dilemmas and the old forms of confrontation.''
On a day of gray skies and intermittent rain, this young capital exuded optimism, recalling the days in the 1960s when it was called ``the capital of hope.''
``Exceptional flight conditions,'' Brazil's leading business magazine, Exame, said of Cardoso's prospects. ``No president has ever started his mandate in such an auspicious situation.''
In a survey released on Sunday by the Datafolha polling organization, 70 percent of respondents predicted that the Cardoso government would be ``good'' or ``great.''

Unfazed by the dramatic devaluation of the Mexican peso over the last 10 days, many Brazilians believe that their country is embarking on an economic boom that will rival the miracle years of the early 1970s.

``Thanks to the success of the Real Plan and to the election of its author as president, we are entering a new era, with the best chances and the best expectations that the country has ever had,'' Roberto Civita, publisher of Veja, the nation's most influential newsweekly, wrote on Sunday.

The Real Plan, implemented on July 1, slashed Brazil's monthly inflation rate from 45 percent in June to 2 percent in December. Low inflation triggered a spending boom that boosted factory production, cutting unemployment. Brazil recorded 5 percent growth in 1994, a level that is expected to be equaled in 1995.
The turnaround has been so decisive that Itamar Franco left Brazil's presidency on Sunday with an 88 percent approval rating, the highest on record for a departing Brazilian president.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

Encouraged by the low inflation and high growth, investors have flooded into Sao Paulo's stock market, and foreign investment is expected to grow. Cardoso has also promised to speed Brazil's program of privatizing state companies.

To meet his 1995 goals of 6 percent growth and 26 percent annual inflation, Cardoso will have to marshal congressional support to change Brazil's Constitution to allow more foreign investment, to transfer health and education duties to states, to raise more taxes and to close a yawning pension fund deficit.
Brazil's Congress reconvenes on March 1, and, at least for the first few months, Cardoso is expected to enjoy majority support.
About 60 percent of Brazil's 594 congressional representatives support Brazil's new president, according to Marcos Antonio Maciel, the nation's new vice president.

Cardoso was elected on Oct. 3 with twice as many votes as his closest competitor, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva. On Sunday, in inaugurations throughout Brazil, Cardoso allies became governors in 9 out of 10 of the most populous states, including Rio, Sao Paulo and Minas Gerais.
