In composing his Cabinet, Cardoso expanded his three-party electoral coalition to include the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party, the largest of 19 political parties represented in Congress.
The Cabinet is largely composed by men who are more than 45 years old, who have American university study on their resumes, and who are natives of Sao Paulo, Brazil's economic powerhouse.

One exception is the special minister for sports: Edson Arantes do Nascimento, the retired soccer star known throughout the world as Pele. The first black in memory to be appointed to a Cabinet-level post, he has vowed to bring soccer fields to the millions of Brazilian children who live in urban shantytowns without access to sports facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANGE AT ONE SOUTHERN CHURCH IS SWEET, AT ANOTHER SOUR

TEXT.P: You can see it as a tale of two Southern churches, both grappling with a question that not too long ago would have been unthinkable: What happens to a white church when it gets a black pastor?

The very different way the story has unfolded in the last six months at Christ United Methodist Church outside Birmingham, Ala., and at Plaza United Methodist Church here goes to show that integration can be sweet and smooth -- when it means blacks' being accepted into white institutions. When the goal is a genuine melding of blacks and whites on equal terms into institutions shaped by both, it is another matter entirely.

``Sometimes you can take the temperature of society better in church than you can outside it,'' said the Rev. Dr. Percy Reeves, who was appointed pastor last summer at Plaza United, a white church in a neighborhood that has gone from black to white. ``And I think we're finding that everything in society -- what real integration means, how to share power, how to have a partnership -- is playing out at our church. We have a shot at it, but it's not going to be easy.''

To a remarkable degree, 11 a.m. on Sunday, when whites generally go to white churches and blacks to black ones, remains the most segregated time in American society. And for the overwhelming majority of churches in the South or elsewhere in the United States, the idea of a black person leading a white church is as unlikely as the thought of a white person leading the NAACP.
Still, there are some intriguing signs of change.
In October, major Pentecostal denominations united in a new association that brings together some 10 million black and white members of the nation's fastest-growing Christian movement.

And, largely because of the efforts of the United Methodist Church to foster integration in congregations, it is no longer rare to see what was once unheard of: blacks heading white Southern churches.

Blacks lead white United Methodist churches here in Charlotte and in a suburb of Birmingham, Brevard, N.C.; Augusta and Columbus, Ga., and Greenville and Clemson, S.C. Black priests preside over Roman Catholic parishes in Boone and Hickory, N.C., and in Atlanta. Blacks head congregations of the Unity Church here and in Charleston, S.C.

Outside the South, there are black pastors presiding over largely white congregations at churches like the Evangelical Assembly of God in Chicago, the First Baptist Church of Vacaville, Calif., and the Riverside Church in Manhattan.

To see evidence of racial progress, it is necessary only to go to the Christ United Methodist Church on the outskirts of Birmingham, once one of the South's strongest bastions of segregation. On the pulpit is the Rev. Charles H. Lee, a black pastor who peers out at the green upholstered pews full of white families wearing plastic name tags.

Lee, who grew up in Georgiana, Ala., remembers when blacks tentatively began to move from the back of the bus to the front, long after the Jim Crow laws had been overturned. To some extent he believes his ministry at the church is part of the same process, an effort to knit together people in a way that no legislation or government action could ever do.

``Legislative actions brought people together and that bore some lasting fruits,'' said Lee, who was placed at Christ United by the denomination's administators. ``But in the church, as opposed to civil society and the legal environment, people are free to do as they wish, and so perhaps people travel a bit more slowly in their freedom than they do when they are legally brought together.''
Parishioners at the affably informal church, where the music minister takes hymn requests and the congregants applaud the music, say Lee has been a big success.

``This is a very tolerant church, more so than a lot of churches out there,'' said Cliff Capps, as he sat before services one day last summer, waiting to meet his son after Sunday school. ``I'm glad to be part of history, if that's what it is.''

But tolerance comes easily when it's on one's own terms. Here in Charlotte, where Reeves, a 35-year-old former tailback for the University of South Carolina, was brought in to guide a white church, the path has been much more difficult.

Situated in a middle-class neighborhood that has gone from white to black, Plaza United has been losing members for years, and the 120 or so worshipers who attend on an average Sunday do not nearly fill the pews. Total membership is 389. When Reeves was hired last summer, more than a few members felt it was a sign that the church, too, would go from white to black.
About eight families left as soon as he was hired. Others hung on but were wary. For many, the issue was about culture as much as race.

``People want to see this as a simple matter of racism, but it's really an ethos issue, one where the spiritual dimension of the church mixes with the cultural,'' said the Rev. Dr. Donald Haynes, superintendent of the Charlotte District of the United Methodist Church, who was excoriated by some members for bringing in Reeves. ``Do you want the culture to remain an Anglo church in terms of music and what we call the worship ethos, or do you want the black experience to be reflected? And can you serve the community if you do the first one and can you maintain the old members if you do the second?''

Charles Lamm, who as Plaza United's board chairman had opposed Reeves's appointment, became the keeper of the old virtues. If the preacher went on past noon, which is standard practice at black churches, Lamm would get up and open the church doors. If the sermon's decibel level got too high for the ears of the white parishoners, he would hold his hand up to his ear as a signal to tone things down.

``Percy Reeves, in my opinion, is a very capable minister,'' Lamm said in an interview in September. ``He preaches a doggone good sermon. But if you start to make radical changes very quickly, then you're going to upset people. I think Percy Reeves is intelligent enough to see the necessity to walk a tightrope and handle it appropriately.''

But finding that balance was not easy. Some congregants said the services tended to ramble on past noon, the music sometimes veered toward the gospel of the black church, and soon each Sunday took on the feel of a melodrama in which each inflection, hymn or digression could be seen as a sign of things to come.

In an interview in October, Reeves made it clear that his goal was to change the church to better serve its largely black neighborhood. He was hopeful but not confident that the congregation would support that change.

``Can it work? I don't know,'' he said, sitting in his office, its walls decorated with portraits of Nelson Mandela, Malcolm X and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ``I just know that there are certain things that every church has to do, and that is it has to relate to its community. It just so happens that ours is changing and becoming progressively black.''

Week by week, the drama played out, with many members becoming upset by local publicity about the church's direction. Eventually, it became mixed with grief. In October, Lamm's wife, Becky, one of the bulwarks of the congregation, died after an extended bout with cancer.

In November, Lamm and Reeves met with the church's regional bishop and had a long, emotional conversation about the church's future, not entirely seeing eye to eye, but both coming to some common ground and finding mutual respect. The pastor drove Lamm home, and the two agreed to talk some more.
They never got the chance. Lamm died in his sleep that night. As he had done for Lamm's wife a month earlier, Reeves presided over his funeral.
If the experience of Methodist churches in cities like Atlanta and Houston is a guide, the chances of Plaza United's remaining largely white or truly integrated are not great.

And yet, despite talk by some members of forming a new congregation, the Plaza United congregation has made it clear that it wants the current one to work. At an emotional meeting on Dec. 13, members expressed their fears and frustrations, but they overwhelmingly supported Reeves.

Attendance is about what it was when he arrived, and sometimes higher. The number of black families in the congregation has increased from 3 to 10, but some old members have begun coming back and visitors have included blacks as well as whites.
``It's really turned into an affirmation of Percy and his work here,'' said Ken Worthy, a white police officer who is the new board chairman. ``People want him to stay and do God's work at Plaza.''
For his part, Reeves remains skeptical, hopeful and exhilarated at the same time.

``It's been frustrating at times, but this is the most exciting thing I've ever been involved in,'' he said. ``This is uncharted territory. You can't legislate it. You can't force it. It has to come from people's hearts. For now, it's coming.''

DOC.HEADLINE: DESPITE SETTLEMENT, BITTERNESS LINGERS AT RACETRACKS

TEXT.P: There is a gathering place near the stable area at Santa Anita race track where jockeys, trainers and agents congregate every morning to swap stories and line up mounts for upcoming races.

All last week, the activity was frenzied, and tension was thick. Because the nation's leading riders were threatening a walkout over insurance coverage, there was a group of unfamiliar men auditioning for roles as replacements.

On one side of the pathway, well-known jockeys such as Gary Stevens and Randy Romero huddled. On the other side stood the replacements who were ready to swing into action if Stevens, Romero and their like declined to ride. Neither group made eye contact with the other.

On Saturday, the morning after a settlement with the race tracks prevented a walkout by the nation's leading jockeys, most of the replacement riders had vanished. But the friction remained and figured to linger for months to come.

Jockeys' Guild members who originally declined mounts for Sunday's races -- on what would have been the first day of the walkout -- felt betrayed by guild members who chose to ride. Jockeys who are not members of the guild felt the guild had put the interests of riders ahead of the health of the sport.

And yet racing, at least until the new contract expires in three years, avoided the labor strife that has crippled baseball and hockey. Brian McGrath, the commissioner of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, had accomplished something missing from the resumes of Bud Selig and Gary Bettman.

Racing also offered a precursor of what may happen in baseball this spring. Will replacement players, like replacement jockeys, be recruited to keep the show going? Will some players break ranks with the union and take the field, just as some Jockeys' Guild members were prepared to ride despite the dispute? And what lingering effects will there be on the field if and when the strike is settled and the major leaguers come back?

Jockeys were asking themselves some of those questions this weekend, examining their relationships with one another and with the guild. Among those doing so were Stevens and Diane Nelson, both successful jockeys who found themselves at polar opposites in this dispute.

Stevens, based in Southern California, has been in the guild since he started riding in 1979 and now is on the guild's board of directors. He declined to be named on mounts Friday morning when entries were taken for Sunday's races, and said he was prepared to ``to sit out until eternity and flip hamburgers at McDonald's, if that's what it takes'' to get a palatable settlement.
And though a deal was reached in time to keep Stevens riding, he felt hurt by the jockeys who would have replaced him.

``We were trying to help the smaller riders, and yet those are the guys who were going to ride,'' Stevens said. ``I have nothing but respect for the smaller guys who said they wouldn't ride, but I have no respect for those who said they would.''
Nelson, based at Aqueduct in New York, was scheduled to ride no matter the status of negotiations between the guild and TRA.
``I didn't feel like I was crossing because I'm not a member of the Guild,'' she said.
``I have my own insurance,'' she added. ``For me to stop working and not take care of my business, and to get the owners and trainers mad at me, would be wrong.''

Therein lies one of the many reasons why the jockeys could not show the solidarity that thus far has united the baseball and hockey players. For starters, the guild is not a union; all jockeys who decided to sit out had to chose so individually.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

Membership in the guild is not mandatory, though most of the better-known jockeys are members. And jockeys have a number of persons to whom they must answer. In effect, they are employed every race by a different owner and trainer.

``The jockeys are going to need to get the owners and the trainers behind them and then bargain with the tracks,'' said Ron McAnally, a trainer based at Santa Anita. ``That's the only way they'll get what they want. They have to discuss this with everyone, not go and say they're going to stop riding. They don't have enough riders in the guild to stop racing.''

The guild is in a precarious position. Many riders believe it is the jockeys' best voice, one that has fought for improvements such as safety rails and protective vests. But even a long-time supporter like Stevens found his emotions roiling.

``The guild may not be the best organization in racing, but it's all we've got,'' he said. ``But I'm going to take a step back and take a long, hard look why I'm in the guild. Unless the riders stand together, we'll revert to the conditions we had 30 years ago. I know none of those jocks who were going to ride were thinking about Gary Stevens. I'm going to have to worry about Gary Stevens more than I did in the past.''
Regardless, this episode hasn't exactly persuaded Nelson to join the guild.
``It should have never come to this in the first place,'' she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BATTLE OVER DNA EVIDENCE EXPECTED IN O.J. SIMPSON TRIAL

TEXT.P: Two months ago, two prominent scientists who have been vocal opponents in the battle over the use of DNA testing in court jointly announced in a respected scientific journal that ``the DNA fingerprinting wars are over.''

But no peace yet has been declared in the courtroom of Superior Court Judge Lance Ito, who beginning Thursday will preside over what could be a long and hard-fought hearing over DNA tests in the O.J. Simpson trial.

Confronted with conflicting appellate court decisions, teams of clashing experts and massive motions detailing the eye-glazing technicalities, Ito must decide whether the results of DNA tests on blood taken from the crime scene and Simpson's home and car can be presented to the jury.

On Saturday, Newsweek magazine quoted sources as saying Simpson's attorneys will file a motion asking that the hearing be jettisoned, or significantly curtailed, thus speeding up the start of testimony in the often-delayed trial.

``We're assuming Ito will let the evidence in for the jury to determine the weight (it should be given),'' a defense source told Newsweek. ``Judges decide admissibility; juries decide believability. We're willing to go right to phase two.''

At stake in what is known as a Kelly-Frye hearing are test results that prosecutors claim implicate Simpson in the June 12 stabbing deaths of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman -- crucial evidence in a case without eyewitnesses.

Further complicating matters is the fact that prosecutors have subjected blood samples to two different types of DNA tests, one of which -- known as PCR testing -- has undergone far less judicial review and thus is more vulnerable to defense challenges.

Citing a significant potential for contamination in PCR tests, the defense served notice during Simpson's preliminary hearing in July that it will argue that police investigators mishandled the blood samples from the start.
``I'm expecting a real battle over PCR and the various kinds of PCR evidence,'' predicted Myrna Raeder, a professor at Southwestern University School of Law who specializes in evidentiary issues.

In court papers filed in July, prosecutors said most of the blood samples would be subjected to some kind of PCR analysis. However, in an effort to undermine key defense arguments, they have ordered multiple tests performed at two different laboratories.

In light of recent scientific and legal developments, trial observers are more confident that prosecutors will be able to persuade Ito to allow them to use the DNA test known as RFLP -- considered the most definitive.

Although state appellate courts have split on the issue, the most recent opinion upheld the use of RFLP tests, quoting the ``war is over'' pronouncement of Eric Lander, the molecular biologist frequently quoted by Simpson attorneys, and Bruce Budowle, chief scientist for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
There is ``no remaining problem that should prevent the full use of DNA evidence in any court,'' Lander and Budowle wrote in the British journal Nature.

Harvard population geneticist David Hartl, whose 1991 article criticizing the way DNA test results are presented to juries is another mainstay of the Simpson team, said last week he agrees with Lander and Budowle.

``There has been a lot of effort by both sides (of the debate) to confuse the issues in this case,'' Hartl said. ``As far as I'm concerned, the scientific issues are settled. Everything else is not science, it's public policy.''

DNA typing -- also known as DNA profiling or DNA fingerprinting -- relies on the unique pattern of an individual's deoxyribonucleic acid, the long, twisted chain found in all living cells that carries a person's genetic code.

By analyzing four or five segments of a strand of DNA extracted from a splash of blood, a scrap of skin or a drop of semen, scientists can convincingly tie -- or definitively exclude -- a suspect to a crime scene by comparing his DNA to that found at the crime scene.

At issue is not the widely acknowledged scientific validity of DNA typing, which two prominent critics called ``possibly the most powerful innovation in forensics since the development of fingerprinting'' a century ago.

There is no argument when DNA patterns from a crime scene do not match a suspect's -- a result in roughly 30 percent of DNA test cases that is considered definitive and usually leads to a speedy exoneration.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL 2ND TAKE FOLLOWS.)

But the technique has been embroiled in controversy since its use was pioneered in Florida in 1987 because its aura of scientific infallibility has an overwhelming impact on juries in life or death criminal trials.

Two issues have fueled much of that debate: how to calculate the odds that a suspect's DNA might coincidentally match someone else's and the quality of the work performed by laboratories doing the testing.

Because these issues are highly technical, the law in California requires that the prosecution show that the statistical and laboratory methods in question are ``generally accepted'' by the scientific community -- an ambiguous standard that has provoked endless debate.

Because it was the first DNA typing technique to be widely used in court, the legal battle of the past decade has concerned itself primarily with RFLP testing, otherwise known as restriction fragment length polymorphism.

The weeks-long RFLP process involves chemically cutting a DNA strand to examine four or five points where individual variations are the greatest. Technicians then can develop a unique profile for comparison purposes.
RFLP testing is considered the most definitive type of blood testing, because it can reduce the odds of a coincidental match between a suspect and someone else to a very small number.

But just how small has been the subject of a rancorous debate, with estimates that have ranged up to 1 in 739 billion -- the kind of numbers fiercely resisted by defense attorneys because of their enormous impact on a jury.

``Once the scientists get up there and do their little spiel, it's a foregone conclusion (the jury) will accept it,'' said James Farley, the defense attorney in a 1989 Ventura, Calif. murder case that set a precedent for the use of DNA testing in the state.

The continuing scientific debate over whether substantial genetic variations between ethnic subpopulations affected the odds of a match led the National Research Council to appoint a panel of experts to study the issue.

In a landmark 1992 report, the NRC panel endorsed DNA testing in general and proposed a compromise known as the modified ceiling principle, an intentionally conservative and somewhat arbitrary statistical method that placed an upper limit on the odds of a random match.

Although Los Angeles prosecutors have had great success in using in the ceiling principle in trial courts, the NRC report failed to halt the debate or persuade appellate courts in some cases that DNA testing fully met the necessary ``general acceptance'' standard.

Simpson's attorneys argue that there still is no generally accepted method for calculating the odds of a match because existing methods don't take into consideration significant genetic variations among ethnic groups.

Even the ceiling principle is the subject of a ``raging controversy'' in part because some critics claim it may not be conservative enough, making DNA evidence appear more convincing than it should, the Simpson team argues.

``Can anyone seriously argue that the ceiling principle is generally accepted ... when prominent geneticists and statisticians are comparing it to the `flat earth theory,' calling it `pseudo-statistical,' saying it `has no rational basis' and calling for it to be `buried,' '' the Simpson motion said.

In the absence of a definitive Supreme Court ruling, California appellate courts have ruled on both sides of the issue. The Soto case, decided in November, found RFLP tests ``highly reliable and relevant'' on the basis that the ceiling rule is generally accepted.
The case for general acceptance got another boost when Lander and Budowle jointly endorsed the ceiling principle, a development noted by the 4th District Court of Appeal in the Soto case.

``Considering they were clearly two of the most vocal advocates of opposing camps on the forensic use of DNA, their mutual declaration that the dispute is resolved in the scientific community clearly carries great weight,'' the court said.
Simpson's attorneys also attack RFLP typing on the grounds that there is no meaningful way to determine whether the labs doing the testing are making errors that could affect the tests' outcome.
It makes no sense to talk about a one-in-a-million chance that anyone other than the suspect was at the crime scene if the lab makes a mistake in one of every 100 cases, the Simpson team argues.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL 3RD TAKE FOLLOWS.)

``The true error rate of all the laboratories is unknown and unknowable based on currently available data. Consequently, the value of DNA evidence they offer is impossible to evaluate and therefore inadmissible,'' Simpson's brief says.

Prosecutors argue that a lab's error rate goes to the weight the jury should give test results, rather than to their admissibility -- although they are quick to note that the two labs doing most of their testing undergo regular quality control checks.
The decision to use two labs also is aimed squarely at defense arguments.

``There are experts who hold that you can eliminate the statistical issue'' by conducting multiple tests, Deputy District Attorney Lisa Kahn, now on maternity leave, told Science magazine in September.
And by sending samples to more than one lab, ``you can pretty much blow the possibility of a laboratory error out the window,'' Kahn said.

Defense attorneys have served notice they will oppose any prosecution attempt to present the joint odds of a match on two or more DNA tests on the grounds that such statistics are unsupported by any published research.
The record on PCR, or polymerase chain reaction, tests is far less complete, in large part because the technology did not come into widespread use until as late as 1991.

PCR typing, a sort of molecular copying process, zeroes in on a particular DNA marker -- or set of markers -- and copies them hundreds of thousands of times, producing a large enough sample to make typing possible.

Less definitive and yielding much smaller odds for a coincidental match than the RFLP test, PCR can be used on degraded blood, semen or saliva samples that are in such poor condition or so small that RFLP testing isn't possible.

In addition to the statistical and quality control concerns that also apply to RFLP typing, the defense opposes the use of PCR tests on the grounds that they remain almost entirely untested, both in court and in the scientific community.

``The forensic use of these techniques by the laboratories are barely known to the scientific community, much less generally accepted,'' Simpson argues in court papers. ``The prosecution's burden at this hearing is very heavy indeed.''

Further, the peculiar vulnerability of PCR tests to contamination, both when the samples are being collected and when the testing is being done in lab, makes the results inherently unreliable, the defense team claims.

To buttress their case, defense attorneys cite the opinion of Kary Mullis, the La Jolla, Calif., biologist who won a 1993 Nobel prize for inventing the PCR technique, that it should only be used to exclude suspects, not tie them to a crime.

Prosecutors base their case for allowing PCR tests in court on the relatively small number of rulings in state courts nationwide, including recent decisions by the supreme courts of Washington and Virginia to admit PCR typing.
Although PCR tests have been admitted by California trial courts, there are no appellate rulings on the issue in this state.

In the 1990 Virginia case, which resulted in the execution of Timothy Spencer for murder and rape, the state Supreme Court upheld the validity of one kind of PCR testing performed by Edward Blake of Forensic Science Associates -- the consultant hired by the Simpson defense team.

In the Washington case, decided in October, the state Supreme Court ruled that PCR typing was generally accepted by the scientific community and ruled that potential contamination and other problems ``are either detectable or preventable.''
``No known appellate court decision has disapproved the admissibility of PCR-based typing results,'' prosecutors note.
The lack of judicial review in connection with PCR testing will make it a tougher call for Ito, said Southwestern's Raeder.
``There are some real question marks as to PCR ... I think Ito will be faced with a decision that will trouble him more because of the lack of appellate support,'' the law professor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE WORLD SHIFTED, BUT NOT MEXICO

TEXT.P: Mexico has this in common with Orange County, Calif., and with derivatives plungers and other big losers in 1994: It failed to respond quickly when the economic world around it began to change, or to realize how risky its economic strategy was until it was too late.
Mexico's risks were built into a strategy of luring investors with high interest rates and a narrow currency-trading range, international economists here have concluded.

That strategy paid off handsomely from 1991 to 1993, as foreign investors who found a limited number of attractive places to put their money during a global recession poured money into Mexican bonds and notes paying 15 percent interest and bought millions of shares in the fast-rising Mexican stock market.

Mexicans spent the money buying far more goods from abroad than the country could pay for with the proceeds from its exports -- running trade deficits three times as large as the biggest American deficits of the 1980s, if the sizes of the two economies are taken into account.

The strategy flew in the face of advice from officials of the International Monetary Fund. The result, as President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon acknowledged in a speech last week, has been disastrous.

The changes in the economic world that proved so devastating to Mexico's strategy came from a multitude of sources, at home and abroad. The Federal Reserve's decision in February to begin driving up interest rates made it more attractive for many to invest in the United States, rather than Mexico.
Many other nations' economies began to emerge from recession and compete for international investment in 1994. And political violence in Mexico made loans and stock purchases there seem riskier.

When the money stopped flowing in, the Mexican government spent close to $20 billion in six months to defend the peso's value. When reserves ran low, top officials were forced to abandon the centerpiece of their economic policy: a guarantee that no matter what happened, a fistful of pesos would hold its value in dollars. The peso has since lost roughly 30 percent of its value.
International Monetary Fund officials refuse to claim vindication. Financial analysts have been more outspoken.

``If the Mexican authorities had followed more closely the exchange-rate readjustment suggested by the IMF models and research, there wouldn't have been the chaos you saw in the markets,'' said Gregory Fossedal, a writer in Arlington, Va., who follows the IMF closely.

Mexico followed much, but not all, of the advice dispensed by the IMF, the World Bank and other international economic organizations. It sold state-owned enterprises to private buyers. It balanced the budget. And it eliminated trade barriers, most notably through the North American Free Trade Agreement, which took effect a year ago.
But the government chose not to run the risk of social turmoil from devaluing the peso, which would have made popular foreign goods more expensive at home.

Consumer prices in Mexico rose 27.9 percent from the end of 1991 through the middle of this year. Yet the value of the peso in dollars fell only 9.4 percent during this period. For would-be foreign buyers with dollars to spend, the slightly cheaper currency was not nearly enough to offset the higher prices.

Evidence that the peso needed to fall further was visible in stores in south Texas this fall. Throngs of Mexican shoppers were coming across the border because the prices were often cheaper than at home.

The result was an immense trade deficit, reaching 8 percent of Mexico's economic output in 1994. The rule of thumb commonly used by the IMF and other international economic organizations is that a developing country's trade deficit should not exceed its economic growth rate. Mexico's annual growth has ranged from 1 to 3 percent in the last couple of years.
Such large deficits lead inevitably to disaster, said a senior economist at an international economic organization.

(MORE)

A 1989 letter from the IMF to the Mexican government warned that if nothing were done, the trade balance, broadly measured to include some financial flows, would double by 1994. But Mexico allowed its line of credit at the IMF to lapse in May 1993 -- which cut it free from the fund's advice, but also from its money.

Still, Mexican policy-makers had reason for optimism as a result of the successful negotiation and approval in 1993 of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The accord prompted foreign investors to pour more money into the country. But as Zedillo pointed out in his speech on Thursday, most of that money went into stocks and bonds that could be quickly sold if confidence faltered.
To be sure, the United States has sustained big trade deficits for many years and relied heavily on foreign investment in American stocks and bonds.

One difference is that the American trade deficits have stayed under 3 percent of economic output. Another is that the United States does not try to fix the value of the dollar to other currencies, allowing it constantly to rise and fall against other money in markets around the world.

By the end of 1993, foreign investors in Mexico were spending six times as much adding to their portfolios of Mexican stocks and bonds as to build factories or buy controlling stakes in Mexican companies. These stock and bond investors proved fickle, IMF figures show.

After a peasant insurgency began in a southern state last January and the front-running presidential candidate was assassinated in March, the pace of these investments slowed severely -- by 86 percent in three months.
Mexico tried until Dec. 22 to maintain a minimum value in U.S. currency for the peso, through the use of a trading band whose lower limit declined at a very slow, steady rate.

Shortly before the recent plunge, the government had effectively guaranteed that anyone who wanted to sell 100 pesos could get $29 for them -- 29 cents apiece. It would go into the market and buy pesos at this price if no one else chose to.

When Mexicans and foreigners wanted to sell pesos for dollars this autumn, the Mexican government became the biggest buyer. In the last two months alone, it reportedly spent more than $10 billion buying pesos.
By late last month, the central bank's hoard of foreign currency had fallen dangerously low. The government lowered its guarantee level -- the process of devaluation -- to $25 for 100 pesos.

A day later, with central bank reserves at just $6 billion, the government abandoned the guarantee entirely, allowing the peso to trade freely in the currency markets. By the close of trading last Tuesday, 100 pesos were worth only $17.54, though their value had bounced back to $19.72 by the end of trading on Friday.

Patrick Conway, an associate professor of economics at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, who specializes in the Mexican economy, said Mexico did not appear to have learned from past mistakes.

In the late 1970s, as in 1993, Mexico abandoned its line of credit with the International Monetary Fund and pursued a strategy of fast economic growth that included huge trade deficits financed with foreign money.
In 1982, as in 1994, the outcome was a collapse in the peso and the need for an international rescue.
The parallels, Conway said, suggest that in each case Mexican officials ``were perhaps too hasty in cutting their ties to the financial institutions that got them where they were.''

DOC.HEADLINE: THE DNA HEARING: AN EXPLANATION OF TERMS

TEXT.P: Here is an explanation of some of the terms and key legal cases that will be cited during the coming court hearing on DNA evidence in the O.J. Simpson case:
-- People v. Axell: The first appellate decision on DNA evidence in California. The 1991 decision by the Los Angeles-based 2nd District Court of Appeal upheld the use of RFLP testing.

-- People v. Barney: This 1992 decision by the San Francisco-based 1st District Court of Appeal ruled that RFLP testing was not admissible because of a lack of general acceptance by the scientific community. This finding was based in large part on a 1991 article in Science magazine that criticized the methodology used in interpreting tests results.
-- People v. Wallace This 1993 opinion by the 1st District Court of Appeals affirmed the earlier Barney decision and ruled RFLP testing was not admissible.

-- People v. Soto: The most recent appellate decision in California. This Nov. 22, 1994 decision by the San Diego, Calif.-based 4th District Court of Appeal upheld the use of RFLP testing on the basis that it is generally accepted by scientists.

-- DNA: Shorthand for deoxyribonucleic acid, the genetic material found inhuman chromosomes that carries the coded messages of heredity unique to each individual. DNA can be extracted from samples of blood, semen, saliva, skin or hair follicles found at the scene of a crime, then compared to DNA drawn from a suspect to determine if there is a ``match.'' -- Kelly-Frye: Named for the California cases that established the legal principles involved. A Kelly-Frye hearing is held to determine if scientific evidence should be presented to a jury. One of the tests of admissibility is whether the scientific test or method used is ``generally accepted'' by the scientific community.

-- PCR: The polymerase chain reaction test, a sort of molecular copier, uses an instrument called the thermal cycler to copy a DNA fragment hundreds of thousands of times. In two hours, about 1 million copies can be created that enable scientists to determine in which of 21 population groups the genetic sample falls. Less precise than RFLP testing, the PCR technique can be used on samples that are too small or degraded for RFLP analysis.

-- RFLP: Considered the most definitive of DNA tests, restriction fragment length polymorphism is also the most time-consuming. Results can take up to two months. This procedure involves cutting the DNA with an enzyme and placing the fragments in gel, where the strands are separated by size. The DNA then is attached to a membrane where radioactive probes are attached to the strands and a series of sequential X-rays taken. Three to five ``windows'' in the DNA strands where individual variations are greatest then are examined to develop a profile used for comparison purposes.
Source: Los Angeles Daily News

DOC.HEADLINE: WELFARE DEBATE WILL RE-EXAMINE CORE ASSUMPTIONS

TEXT.P: A great debate is about to begin over one of the major premises of America's social welfare policy: that low-income people have legal rights to government aid guaranteeing a minimum standard of living.

Many of the Republicans who will take control of Congress on Wednesday contend that welfare, Medicaid and food stamps should be stripped of their status as open-ended ``entitlements.'' Instead, they say, Congress should appropriate fixed amounts of money each year for those programs, whose size would no longer increase automatically when, for example, a recession put more people out of work.

Neither Democrats nor Republicans are proposing to make significant changes in the largest entitlement program, Social Security, or to withdraw the entitlement status of Medicare, although the money spent on those two programs dwarfs the spending on welfare and food stamps.

Instead, the battle lines have been drawn over the use of entitlements to guarantee a minimum standard of living for the poor. That struggle transcends the debate over specific Republican proposals that would, for example, increase the use of orphanages, impose stringent work requirements on welfare recipients and eliminate aid to the children of young unmarried women.
Here is the outlook:

-- The Clinton administration is reassessing the whole question of entitlements, is receptive to some changes and has not decided on a strategy for dealing with Republican proposals to restructure the welfare system.

-- Nonpartisan experts believe that Congress may, for the first time, limit federal Medicaid spending, which has doubled in four years, reaching $82 billion in 1994. Medicaid provides health care for 33 million low-income people; Medicare finances health care for 36 million people who are elderly or disabled.

-- Congress will consider giving states a lump-sum payment, or block grant, to help poor people now entitled to benefits under the main cash welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children. Block grants would be a radical departure because they would eliminate individual entitlement to benefits and would give states more flexibility in deciding how to use the money.

-- The food stamp program is perhaps the most secure of the major benefit programs for poor people. House Republicans want to put it into a block grant with other food and nutrition programs, but they expect resistance because food stamps have support from a middle-class constituency that includes farmers, grocers and the food industry generally.
The struggle will challenge Democrats, in the administration and in Congress, to explain why entitlement programs were created and why they should be continued.

Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., who is on the Budget Committee, said: ``We have to get these programs off autopilot. They should be subject to annual appropriations. Entitlements have taken away the power of the people, through Congress, to decide where money is spent each year.''
Congress would need more control over spending to comply with a proposed constitutional amendment that would require a balanced federal budget, he said in an interview.
Democrats say the welfare and food stamp programs serve a valuable economic purpose, infusing money into a state when recession hits, unemployment rises and more families need assistance.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
(MORE)

Reps. Sander M. Levin, D-Mich., a member of the Ways and Means Committee who is trying to coordinate the Democratic strategy on welfare legislation, said he strongly believed that states should have more flexibility in designing programs, but he worried about Republican efforts to replace entitlement programs. ``What would happen in times of recession?'' he asked in an interview. ``You can't repeal economic cycles.''
Another Democrat, Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, said entitlement programs responded automatically to economic and demographic changes.
Shays countered, ``That's a good argument, but in the process we're going bankrupt.''

In an entitlement program, the government has a legal obligation to pay benefits to all applicants who meet eligibility criteria set by U.S. law. The formulas for deciding who gets how much stay the same from year to year unless Congress votes to change them.
If the demand for aid exceeds expectations, Congress must somehow come up with more money, by borrowing, raising taxes or cutting other items in the budget.
By contrast, Congress appropriates specific amounts each year for discretionary spending programs, which include defense, medical research, law enforcement, Head Start and job training.
Entitlement programs account for slightly more than half of all federal spending, roughly $800 billion of $1.5 trillion last year.

The great middle-class entitlements, Social Security and Medicare, which pay benefits regardless of financial need, dwarf the programs for low-income people -- the government spent $475 billion on Social Security and Medicare in 1994, compared with a total of $125 billion on Aid to Families with Dependent Children, food stamps and Medicaid.
But Social Security, which both parties have found to be a volatile issue, is off the table, and Congress is not considering changes in Medicare.

The roots of these programs run deep. Welfare, under the name Aid to Dependent Children, was part of the Social Security Act in 1935. President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the Food Stamp Act in 1964. Medicaid and Medicare were created in 1965.

While committed to the overall goals of those programs, the administration has not decided whether or how to defend their status as entitlements. White House officials are mulling that question as they prepare for a conference on welfare with governors and members of Congress from both parties in the next few weeks.
Administration officials said President Clinton, a former governor, was sympathetic to the governors' pleas for more flexibility in using federal money.

Asked if she would defend the entitlement status of welfare and Medicaid, Avis La Velle, an assistant secretary of health and human services, said: ``No, I can't. There is a re-evaluation going on throughout the department as to the whole concept of entitlement programs. It's just not smart for us to take an advocacy position one way or another. The ground is shifting under our feet.''
Levin said Democrats in Congress and the administration had ``no clear strategy'' for dealing with the Republican proposals at this time. ``It's important for us to develop one quickly,'' he said.

Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said that if lawmakers wanted to slow the growth of welfare programs, they could do so without eliminating the entitlement to benefits. For example, he said, Congress could restrict eligibility or make benefits less generous. Such changes could save substantial amounts of money, but the government would still have a legal obligation to pay benefits to any applicants who met the criteria.
``The notion that we are incapable of selectively modifying entitlement programs is just wrong,'' Reischauer said.

There is fierce competition for money among domestic programs, and it is likely to intensify this year. Current law imposes an annual limit on all discretionary spending through 1998, and President Clinton says he wants to maintain the ceiling at current levels in 1999 and 2000, with no allowance for inflation. Rep. John R. Kasich, R-Ohio, who is in line to become chairman of the House Budget Committee, says he wants to reduce the spending limits.

If a benefit program loses its status as an entitlement, it would have to compete with all the other domestic programs for which Congress appropriates money each year. And that, many Republicans say, is exactly what should happen.

DOC.HEADLINE: REBELS IN MEXICO HOLD A SUBDUED CELEBRATION

TEXT.P: In the great amphitheater carved from the rain forest to receive partisans of the peasant guerrillas with headquarters here, the rough-hewn benches where thousands once sat were nearly empty as the New Year began on Sunday.

The genial small-town newspaper publisher whom the insurgents call the true governor of the ``rebel state of Chiapas'' had brought some friends to celebrate the first anniversary of their uprising, but most of them fit into a single pickup truck.

A few hundred villagers and uniformed soldiers ringed the podium from which a band played and masked rebel officers spoke; local girls were still scarce enough that when the marimbas started up, the young soldiers had to dance in shifts.

``Together, we fulfilled our mission to show the bad government that there was poverty in this land of Chiapas, and that there was poverty in all of Mexico,'' a rebel commander known as Tacho said as midnight approached Saturday, recalling the morning that his forces seized a handful of remote towns and the country's attention. ``We did not surrender. We did not sell out.''

Yet a year after the Zapatista National Liberation Army stormed into view, changing Mexico's course abruptly and challenging a model of economic development widely admired in Latin America, there was an air of loneliness, even desperation to the ceremony.

One might have expected otherwise. Less than two weeks ago, after threatening for months to break a longstanding cease-fire, the Zapatistas helped to plunge the country into an economic and political crisis by announcing that they had broken through government lines and moved into dozens of municipalities.

The fact that the rebels and their supporters only blocked a handful of highways and briefly occupied a few undefended towns was lost on investors who withdrew about $1 billion from the country. This contributed to the already heavy pressure on the peso, and the government devalued the currency the next day. By last week, President Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon was urging new peace talks and pulling his troops from rebel areas to show good faith.
As the Zapatistas marked the first year of their war, however, their leaders seemed to be viewing the prospect of new negotiations with skepticism bordering on scorn.

Even as they congratulated themselves for drawing new attention to the plight of Mexico's Indian peasants, rebel leaders sounded ever more angry that their demands for sweeping changes in the country's political system and economic policy were not being heard.
The rebel leader known as Subcommander Marcos, rejecting the idea of talks, demanded early on Sunday that the president's month-old government be replaced.

``We call on all the political and social forces of the country, on all honest Mexicans, on all those who struggle for the democratization of the country to form a Movement for National Liberation,'' he said in a statement he titled the Third Declaration of the Lacandon Jungle.

The movement, he added, should ``struggle by all means and at all levels for the installation of a government of transition, a new constituent assembly, a new magna carta and the destruction of the ruling-party system.''

Despite the presence of dozens of Mexican and foreign reporters, Subcommander Marcos did not appear at the ceremony himself. Instead, his comrades played a scratchy tape recording in which he read three communiques over what he described as a clandestine rebel radio station; no such station was previously known to exist.

In the declaration, he suggested that the new movement be formed from the remains of the National Democratic Convention, the loose amalgam of social organizations and leftist political groups that trekked to the rebel capital here just before Mexico's presidential elections in August to show support for the Zapatistas. And he proposed that the leftist candidate in the presidential race, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, take the lead in the movement.
Cardenas did not answer the invitation on Sunday, but he is not expected to emerge to lead a new movement.

In recent interviews, Marcos has acknowledged that the rebels were badly disappointed by their failure to ignite wider political support for their demands of new rights for Mexican Indians, wide economic and social changes in Chiapas and political reforms throughout the country.

To hear Marcos, the insurgents draw new hope from the economic turmoil that has followed the peso's sharp devaluation. ``The economic crisis awakened Mexicans from the sweet and stupefying dream of entrance into the First World,'' he said.
Yet in the remote swath of southern Mexico that the army has effectively ceded to the Zapatistas for the last year, the situation seemed also to be wearing at the faithful.

Though market prices have nearly doubled over the last year for coffee, the region's most important cash crop, many poor farmers say they will have little profit because they could not buy pesticides for their plants. Asked whether they would be joining the rebel army, several teen-agers at the celebration demurred: their friends in arms eat little but tortillas, they said.
What is hardest, said a 30-year-old man who gave his name as Miguel, is that for most of the last year it has been painfully difficult to get through army roadblocks even to the closest town.

``People are getting angrier here,'' said a 20-year-old rebel named Eliver. ``People do not want to fight again, but they will. No one believes in the dialogue. We have been talking for a year, and nothing here has changed.''

DOC.HEADLINE: AT AN AIDS FACILITY, A NURSE FIGHTS HER OWN GOOD FIGHT

TEXT.P: Tim G. came back one Wednesday but he was changed -- thinner, quieter, diffident. He had been shooting up a combination of heroin and cocaine that had damaged one of his kidneys and impaired his memory.

Deborah Sollod, the clinical nurse manager at the Robert Mapplethorpe Residential AIDS Treatment Facility, stood behind Tim G.'s wheelchair in the narrow hallway of the brownstone and tried to reassure him.

``Hi, Angie,'' Ms. Sollod said to Angela A., who stood in the hallway. She was an increasingly paranoid 36-year-old recovering crack addict who barely remembered her four children. ``How are you, sweetie?''
Angela A. rolled her eyes.
A man with a lesion on top of his head complained that the dining room was cold, but his real complaint, Ms. Sollod said, was his AIDS, his cancer and his loneliness.

And so began another day for Ms. Sollod, a 34-year-old registered nurse who leaves suburbia each dawn to travel into the heart of the great plague of the 20th century. By 7 a.m. she enters her claustrophobic basement office in the East Side brownstone that is home to 15 women and 13 men with AIDS. Her days end 10 hours later.

In every major city, health care workers like Ms. Sollod increasingly deal with the new AIDS patient -- a poor drug addict with a range of social problems. For the patients, it is yet another crisis in lives spent scraping the bottom of their humanity. For health care professionals and social workers it has changed the trajectories of their cases from concerns about medical bills and miracle cures to include concerns about food stamps, drug treatment and housing.

In New York City, the epicenter of the AIDS epidemic with over 70,000 cases, most new cases involve intravenous drug users, not men who have sex with other men. Unlike the middle-class gay white men who brought AIDS to the attention of the nation, the new patients are increasingly black and Hispanic people, and their illness is often compounded not only by drug addiction but also by poverty and emotional problems and estrangement from family and friends.

And for those who work to ease their suffering, the disease takes a toll of a different kind. Turnover and burnout are high in AIDS nursing homes and in AIDS wards in hospitals in New York City and across the country. The Mapplethorpe staff members talk constantly among themselves about the strain of what they do. Some see therapists, some find other escapes.

``It's not pleasant being around people you know are going to die,'' Ms. Sollod said the other day. ``Personally, I have a hard time with it. I don't like to go visit them in the hospital. You fall in love with them. Just because you're a nurse doesn't mean it's easy.

``If I can make this one day a happy day, then I am pleased,'' she said. ``Many have never had a happy day in their lives. If taking them to a Christmas show can make a difference -- they've probably passed Radio City Music Hall for 20 years on their way to get high.''
Beth Israel Medical Center built the long-term-care residence with the help of $1 million from the Robert Mapplethorpe Foundation, established by the photographer, who died of AIDS in 1989.

The center, one of about half a dozen in New York City, is like a nursing home in that it serves people too sick to live on their own but not sick enough to go into the hospital. They receive medical care and psychotherapy and their drug treatment is monitored. Ms. Sollod took the job, she said, both because of a desire to help and because it offered a chance to go into management. She had previously been a case manager in neo-natal intensive care at Beth Israel and a staff nurse there, among other jobs.

``I didn't think of it as working with AIDS patients, I thought of it as working with people,'' Ms. Sollod said. ``This was like a stepping stone to the AIDS community. They need people. There aren't a lot of people dedicating their career to it.''

The world Ms. Sollod has entered is far different from the one in which she was reared, as a police officer's daughter in the bosom of a close Irish-Italian family on a quiet street in Staten Island. And she says she has learned that the universe inside the six floors of the Mapplethorpe brownstone is not quite real to those outside.
There are many nights she goes home and cries, she said, but what keeps her going is the belief that she can make a difference.

The 9 a.m. staff meeting at Mapplethorpe is a roll-call of woes. Ms. Sollod, who is expecting her first child in July, sits at the head of the table in the dining room and eats a pear to battle nausea, curling her beautifully manicured orange fingernails around the fruit.

There are eight staff members at the meeting and the details snatched from the patients' lives are intimate. Who has coughing pains, who has heavy menstrual periods, who has a family member trying to smuggle in some marijuana.

One patient's test shows that his brain is shrinking. Another is vomiting up methadone. A male patient refuses to allow a female dentist to examine him. There is a suspicion that one of the women is not taking her anti-psychotic medication, because she has been accusing the staff of plotting against her. There is concern about the continuing relationship between two residents who apparently lived together before coming to Mapplethorpe.
(MORE)

``The same cardboard box?'' deadpans R. Steven Fox, a psychotherapist with twinkling eyes behind thick glasses and blond hair caught up in a long ponytail. Fox said later that he jokes so he will not be overwhelmed by the sorrow he witnesses. He also sees a therapist and works out.
``If you don't laugh you're not going to make it through the day,'' Ms. Sollod said.

Right after the staff meeting the residents gather in the dining room. Ms. Sollod, wearing a flowing flower-print dress and black combat boots, goes to the front of the room and announces: ``Yes, I'm having a baby.'' There is applause and smiles of delight. Many of the residents have children, too.

``I don't know how I kept it from you for the four weeks I knew,'' she says. ``It'll be the first Mapplethorpe baby, so don't keep me stressed out.'' It's a joke, big time. Ms. Sollod said she had no special fears now that she is pregnant. She said she had always been very straightforward about telling patients to practice basic hygiene: not to kiss her when they have a cold, to blow their noses carefully, and not to pick their fingers until they bleed. A few residents have sex with one another, and Ms. Sollod admonishes them to wear condoms.

``Don't smoke on the way over there,'' she said to a patient who was going to Beth Israel Medical Center for an X-ray. Ms. Sollod quit cold turkey herself. ``Take some tissues. You're wiping your nose with your hands.''

To some, Ms. Sollod is a big sister, to others a mother. One of her favorite residents is a 66-year-old man who got AIDS from sex with prostitutes. They find great comfort in watching films together on the American Movie Classics cable channel.
``He could easily be my grandfather,'' Ms. Sollod said. ``Our backgrounds are very similar. I grew up Irish-Italian; we had family dinner every Sunday.''

Since she got the job at Mapplethorpe when it opened last October, she has worked every single holiday. She raids her husband's clothes closet for hand-me-downs for residents and even has a hairdresser friend come in to offer solace through shampoo.

She and Joseph Sollod, a computer specialist at Merrill Lynch, recently moved into a big house in Somerset, N.J. She is working on a master's degree at Hunter College in Manhattan that will make her a clinical nurse specialist in maternal/child health. Her dream is to open a house just for pregnant women with HIV and their babies.

Ms. Sollod is serene and matter-of-fact. Neither her tone nor her facial expression changes when she switches from ordering a bagel with cream cheese to talking about a 69-year-old resident who needs his leg amputated because of an infection. Ms. Sollod dresses his leg every morning, which is also the time to check his state of mind. This is a long-distance run, with no time to fall apart.

There is a lot of talking. The patients talk to Ms. Sollod about all kinds of things: their childhoods, why they started using drugs, how they believed they got AIDS. Most of them have a hard time believing they are going to die.

``I have a strong religious belief that God heals my body and could possibly find a cure,'' said Angela A., who says she got AIDS from sex. She said she found out in 1990 that she was HIV positive. Like all the other residents, she spoke on the condition that her full name not be used.

Eddie L., a 46-year-old who looks like someone awakened from a bad dream, wants to go back to school to be a substance abuse counselor. He wears a 32-year-old tattoo that says ``Born to Raise Hell,'' with the word ``Hell'' almost completely faded. He began shooting heroin in the late 1960s and has spent 18 years in prison for armed robbery, breaking and entering, and car theft.
``This place is teaching me that some days I'll have bad days but it's no reason to run off and stick a needle in my arm,'' he said.
He is not sure what happened to his family. He gave the virus to a lover but he has heard that their daughter is O.K.
``I love Debbie,'' he said.

It all comes down to drugs. There is the constant apprehension that someone like Tim G. will go out and get high -- he was gone several weeks -- which will only accelerate the inevitable deterioration of AIDS.

`'I'm bad,'' Ms. Sollod said the other day when asked how she was. One of the residents had a urine sample that came back positive for cocaine. Ms. Sollod just could not believe it. Her eyes were teary.
``He was doing so good,'' she said. ``He said he didn't use drugs. I want so bad to believe him.''
Ms. Sollod called an outside laboratory and was told that if the test was positive for cocaine, then the patient probably used cocaine. She wanted the urine tested again.
It was time for the bedroom check. All the bedrooms are checked for neatness. Ms. Sollod can also see how people are holding together.
``You O.K., honey?'' Ms. Sollod asked a woman stretched across her bed. ``Just sleeping?'' The woman mumbled that she was all right, but Ms. Sollod said later that she was depressed.
Another woman had a bad cold she could not shake and Ms. Sollod warned her that she must be tested for strep throat.
``Stop sucking that stuff up,'' Ms. Sollod said. ``Blow your nose.''
After the bedroom rounds were completed, Ms. Sollod walked down to her office. Her most pronounced pregnancy symptom so far is a voracious appetite, so she took a break to eat.
``Debbie?'' came the tremulous voice of a patient outside her door, popping the bubble of quiet.
``I'm here,'' Ms. Sollod said.

DOC.HEADLINE: A PRAMATIC CONSERVATIVE: GEORGE ELMER PATAKI

TEXT.P: To the friends he met at Yale College 31 years ago, George E. Pataki was a garrulous, beer-loving freshman who knew precisely where he stood on the political spectrum (to the right), the name of the next president (Barry Goldwater) and what he would become when he grew up (governor of New York State).

To the politicians he passed along the way to becoming the 53rd governor of New York, Pataki was also a conservative, but often a pragmatic one. His central beliefs did not stop him from working with more moderate politicians or from moderating his own views on difficult issues to achieve his goals. Taking over as governor of a state facing a $5 billion budget deficit whose electorate he described as angry and hungry for change, Pataki presented himself Sunday as both a steadfast conservative determined to shrink government, and a farmer's son who, like his idol Theodore Roosevelt, cares more about getting things done than staying true to dogma.

He comes into office at a time when national sentiment is also for smaller government. Many a Republican rode that tide to victory in November, but Pataki can claim to have arrived at this place by sticking with some basic beliefs he learned long ago from his father, the mailman and farmer.

``When government accepts responsibility for people, then people no longer take responsibility for themselves,'' he said in his inaugural address Sunday. ``We will begin where the people want us to begin, reducing the size and cost of government.''

Since he was a teen-ager Pataki has been unwavering about the political label he gave himself: when he defeated a better known and ostensibly more popular classmate for senior class president of Peekskill High School, he was already calling himself a ``small-c conservative.''

By the time he reached Yale, he was recruiting volunteers for the Goldwater campaign. He built his social life around campus politics, becoming a leader of the Conservative Party at the Yale Political Union and creating an informal club of like-minded friends who each had a nickname ending with ``fus,'' as in ``for the U.S.'' Pataki was Grufus, because he grew so tall.

Even as many of his peers drifted left in the 1960s, Pataki joined pro-war demonstrations at Columbia Law School and became known as the one guy willing to defend President Richard Nixon in barroom debates.

When he entered the state Assembly in 1985, he joined a severely outvoted Republican minority and saw only a handful of his bills passed during his eight-year tenure. Yet he enthusiastically endorsed the minority's political playbook, incorporating its main ideas into his gubernatorial platform: cut taxes, reduce Medicaid spending, put welfare recipients to work, strengthen criminal penalties.

Pataki also struck conservative poses that helped his career. In the Republican-controlled Senate, he twice was the lone Republican to vote against the state budget. Though the Senate leadership punished him for his insubordination, he repeatedly cited those votes as examples of his fiscal conservatism in his gubernatorial campaign.

Connecting all those experiences was Pataki's belief that people should stop looking to government to solve their problems. Pataki summarized that philosophy in a 1985 television interview, but the words could have been drawn from one of his 1965 Yale debates or even his 1995 inaugural address.

``It's very important to stand on your own feet to the extent that you can,'' he told an interviewer from the program ``Inside Albany.'' ``To try to better yourself by seeking out employment or education or anything else, instead of having the government come deliver it to you.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

George Elmer Pataki was born on June 24 in Peekskill, and grew up on the family vegetable farm. His father was a mail carrier who rose to the level of manager. But he also managed the 15-acre farm and occasionally worked a third job to support the family and save for his two sons' college tuition. George, his older brother, Louis, and 13 cousins who also lived on the farm were expected to pull their weight by tilling fields, picking strawberries and delivering produce to the farm stand.
``Picking, plowing, getting stomped by the work horses, that's what we did,'' Louis Pataki said. ``It was not romantic. It was work.''

In his steadiness, his unflappable demeanor and his work ethic, Pataki resembles his father, friends say. ``His father was a calm rock in the middle of everything,'' said Michael C. Finnegan, Pataki's friend and counsel. ``In many respects, that's who George Pataki is. In the middle of a catastrophe, he doesn't get rattled.''

The son also inherited from the father, who now has Alzheimer's disease and lives in a nursing home, a streak of political pragmatism. Pataki tells a story about how during the Depression his father was told he must register Democratic to get a post office job. ``I don't think I should do it,'' said the elder Pataki, who was then an independent. ``You're absolutely right,'' his wife replied. The next day, he registered Democratic and got the job. ``Thank God,'' said his wife.
``They were always very apolitical,'' Pataki said. ``But they had very strong values and beliefs.''

His friends see parallels between that story and Pataki's alliance with U.S. Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato. ``Clearly their relationship helped him get the nomination,'' said Mac Hansing, a Yale friend. ``But that doesn't mean he will obediently do whatever D'Amato wants. It was just political expedience.''

DOC.HEADLINE: BC-NY-PATAKI-PROFILE-2NDTAKE-NYT

TEXT.P: Critics say there are many other cases in which Pataki's positions seemed based on political expediency more than principle. Though he opposed abortion during the 1980s, he called himself ``pro-choice'' in 1992 when he ran against State Senator Mary B. Goodhue, his former mentor who was an advocate of a woman's right to abortion.

During last year's campaign, he called for banning assault weapons, yet voted against a Democratic gun-control measure last April. And at Yale, he abstained in one of the most heated debates of the year, over whether outside agitators did more harm than good in the civil-rights movement.

Pataki cites the changes in his abortion stand as evidence that he is open-minded, with an everyman's distaste for dogma. ``I am not someone who doesn't reflect on the whole question of abortion,'' he said in October. ``And I think most people do. It is a tough decision not just for politicians, it is a very tough personal decision for people.''

If Yale was an important proving ground for his philosophy, it did little to change Pataki's style, friends say. Though he found himself surrounded by prep school students and old wealth, he continued to dress in faded jeans and flannel work shirts and to frequent working-class bars.

Richard E. Jackson Jr., an old friend, recalls Pataki ``without missing a beat'' pungently scolding a snobbish roommate who denigrated Jackson's college, the University of Bridgeport. ``They stopped being roommates later that year,'' said Jackson.

With his easy-going manner, Pataki never seemed as if he were working hard, consistently scoring excellent grades although he played much basketball and took long vacations to places like Puerto Rico. ``He was easy to underestimate,'' said Edward W. Hayes, a Manhattan lawyer who was at Columbia with Pataki. ``But that's the biggest mistake you can make with him. He's very focused. And he's got terrific will to win.''

Many of his rivals for the Republican nomination also underestimated him, scoffing at his chances of unseating Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. William D. Powers, the Republican state chairman, said he first decided that Pataki's would win when he saw the candidate early on a frigid morning last winter, trudging up a snow-swept Albany street to use a phone at Republican headquarters because he could not make campaign calls from his Senate office. ``There aren't a lot of people who would leave the warmth of their Senate offices in the winter,'' said Powers. ``It demonstrated his commitment.''
At times, that commitment has faltered. On several occasions in his career, including during a low point in last year's race, Pataki has talked of returning to Peekskill to become a full-time farmer.

But when it counted most last year, Pataki was unwavering in his desire to win. Eight days from the election, when he had fallen behind in most polls, Pataki made a command tour of his Manhattan office.

``It made a palpable difference in morale,'' said Gary W. Maloney, a campaign research consultant. ``Here's the man who's seen a 6-point lead go to a 14-point deficit saying we're going to win this. He reached inside himself and proved to everyone that he was the man to replace Cuomo.''

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUNG TROJANS TO GET TASTE OF A BIG-TIME BOWL

TEXT.P: Last one out of Lubbock get the lights.
There are overflowing dog dishes and mailboxes all over West Texas today, because Texas Tech is in the Cotton Bowl for the first time since it joined the Southwest Conference going on 34 years ago.
That the Red Raiders play USC doesn't seem to have much significance here, where football is heaven and Spike Dykes gets to be God for a week.

The Trojans have gone largely unnoticed as the opponent in one of the least-attractive Cotton Bowls since the game's inception in 1937. For the first time, neither team is ranked in the nation's top 20 and the eight combined losses (7-3-1 by USC, 6-5 by Texas Tech) are the most since Kentucky and TCU played in 1952.

This is just the sort of thing that has followed USC around for the past several years, or at least since 1989, when it last played in the Rose Bowl. If not for the indiscretions of Texas AM, the Trojans would be playing the 10-0-1 Aggies today and the USC ticket office might have sold more than the 5,000 seats it did.
The Trojans might have been back in the national eye rather than fending off yet another Fresno State in yet another version of the Freedom Bowl.

Not that the Cotton Bowl against Texas Tech does not have its benefits. Forty-eight Trojans are freshmen or sophomores. This, then, serves as their January bowl training wheels, a ride USC coach John Robinson expects to take often as the decade goes on.

``We have an extremely young team,'' he said, ``one of the youngest I've ever coached in terms of freshmen and new players that are playing. For that, as you look into the future, the opportunity to play in a major game, to go out of town and to be exposed to the things that our players have been exposed to, is really great. The chance to have an extra 10 or 12 days of practice is also a very positive thing.''

Though a win here against underdog Texas Tech does not solve Notre Dame, does not solve UCLA, it might further validate the young players within the program. It might promote quarterback Rob Johnson in the NFL draft. It might deepen USC's inroads in Texas recruiting. A victory also would give Robinson his eighth of the season, a total he reached in each of his first eight years over his two terms at USC.
But, for a few hours anyway, it is only Texas Tech and USC, with none of the past and none of the ramifications.
``We don't have the best of records,'' Dykes said, ``and we're not the highest-ranked team to play in the Cotton Bowl, but, hopefully, on Monday at noon, you're going to see a great football game.''

The Red Raiders won only four of seven SWC games. When they won, it typically was with defense and with quarterback Zebbie Lethridge and tailback Byron Hanspard, both freshmen. They call their defense the Blitz Brothers, and it had 34 sacks and, on running plays alone, 65 tackles for losses.

``When I look at them, I think of Washington State,'' said Mike Riley, USC's offensive coordinator. ``When we played Washington State, they were not overly big, but very aggressive, very quick, and they were play makers.
``The scheme that they play reminds me of Arizona a little bit. Those were two great defensive teams that we played, and they remind me of them in different aspects.''
It should be noted that USC beat Washington State by 13 points and Arizona by 17 in back-to-back games.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TAILORS MILITARY TO PROTECT INTERESTS IN SOUTH CHINA SEA

TEXT.P: As Chinese diplomats talk of peaceful coexistence with their Southeast Asian neighbors, China's military leaders are refurbishing a portion of their large and antiquated military to enforce claims of sovereignty over the South China Sea and its resources, Chinese and Western experts say.

In this effort, Chinese military leaders have nurtured specific industries to develop advanced weapons technology and are tailoring their naval and air forces for the region, the experts say, even as the country's overall level of military production is declining.

At stake are potentially vast oil reserves, minerals and fishing grounds that intersect some of the world's busiest shipping lanes. With energy demands surging along with the population, oil supplies are falling behind in China, which in 1993 became a net importer of oil for the first time. So any major oil discovery in the South China Sea is likely to draw Beijing's immediate attention on securing it.

A group of former American military leaders who visited China last year has reported that China is forming a limited military force ``capable of rapid response'' and designed to protect ``island claims in the South China Sea as a matter of national priority.''

The group was led by former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and four recently retired four-star military officers, including, David E. Jeremiah, a former Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and James P. McCarthy, a former Deputy Commander of United States forces in Europe.
Although comprehensive military modernization remains a distant goal for China, these and other experts say, Beijing has in recent years built up its military in specific areas by:
-- Improving its ability to fight a sustained sea battle with its fleet of surface warships, support vessels and submarine forces.

-- Negotiating with Russia for the purchase of a total of 72 advanced Su-27 attack aircraft capable of providing close air support for naval operations at extended range. (The first 24 Su-27s were delivered in 1992 but negotiations over the terms for the rest have been troublesome.)

-- Organizing a handful of marine units for amphibious assault and training airborne forces for rapid deployment in Soviet-made transport aircraft. (One such force is based on Hainan Island for quick dispatch to the Spratlys and the Paracels, two island chains in the South China Sea.)
-- Developing mobile, conventional-warhead missiles to terrorize any foe within 1,000 miles.
``By the year 2005, they would like to achieve a core force of 500,000 to one million across their services who are fairly modern,'' said one specialist on Chinese military affairs.
Apart from the recent efforts, however, this goal seems illusive to other experts because China is still technologically unsophisticated in some areas.

Chinese warships, for example, have little or no effective air defense, and their targeting radars cannot reach over the horizon. China has no hope of financing aircraft-carrier development for at least a decade. Its submarines are noisy and vulnerable and are equipped with poorly functioning torpedoes.

The Chinese air force has yet to produce a modern, supersonic aircraft with all-weather air-to-air combat abilities. And China's air defense system could not stop penetration by the French Mirage 2000 attack planes recently purchased by Taiwan, whose pilots get more flight training hours in a month than Chinese pilots get in a year, experts say.

``We are aware that our weaponry of all services is far behind the present equipment of the United States,'' Adm. Liu Huaqing, China's top military officer, told the McNamara group. ``We hope to modernize, but the problem is that we have no resources; and if we compete with economic needs, we will be in competition with the economy, and that is not in China's interest.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)
Still, Chinese and Western specialists say, Beijing's limited buildup is threatening to neighbors like Vietnam, which lost two vessels in a clash with Chinese forces in 1988.

``The danger of what we have on the question of China's military is that people are beginning to make the case that China is benign,'' said James R. Lilley, a former ambassador to Beijing and longtime CIA officer in Asia.

``China says it has no military objectives, that on the South China Sea it wants to cooperate to find a diplomatic solution while exploiting the resources, that there are no military solutions and that China is focusing on the economy,'' he said.

Arguing that by all appearances, China's military buildup is tightly focused on the South China Sea area, Lilley added: ``I'm afraid the evidence tells us otherwise. And it is quite clear that that is their objective in 10 to 20 years.''
