Experts point out that Liu, a member of the ruling Politburo and former chief of the navy, has been a leading advocate for seizing the rich mineral and fishing grounds of the South China Sea to support China's swelling population. The diet of China's population, Liu once told the New China News Agency, will increasingly require the protein supplied from fish. As exploitation of sea-based resources becomes more important, he added, China will need a modern navy. Indeed, China's consumption of seafood has quadrupled since 1978.

In February 1992, the National People's Congress issued its ``Law on the Territorial Waters and their Contiguous Areas,'' which laid claim to 80 percent of the South China Sea with a horseshoe-shaped boundary that runs the length of Vietnam's coastline and then swings southwest to waters off Malaysia, Brunei and the Philippines.

The law laid down regulations for transit through the area and called for ``immediate eviction of foreign military vessels or vessels owned by foreign governments and used for noncommercial purposes that violate the laws and regulations'' of China. Seventy percent of Japan's crude oil imports traverses the area.

Last month, the official Guangming Daily said 400 Chinese scholars recently completed 10 years of research on the Spratly Islands and ``proved historically'' that China ``discovered and the developed the Spratly Islands.''

The Spratlys -- comprising 21 islands and atolls, 50 submerged land spits and 28 partly submerged bits of rock and reef spread out over 340,000 square miles -- ``are a sacred and inviolable part of Chinese territory,'' the newspaper said.

The United States has never taken a position on the territorial disputes in the South China Sea, which also involve claims by Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, Indonesia and Brunei. By far the most contentious dispute is between China and Vietnam, whose naval forces clashed most recently in 1988 when Chinese warships sank two Vietnamese vessels with the loss of more than 70 lives.
In 1990, Premier Li Peng offered to put the sovereignty question aside and called for joint development of oil resources by all the claimants, but there were no takers.

In mid-1992, China contracted with a small American company, the Crestone Energy Corp., to begin oil exploration off Vietnam's coast near Ho Chi Minh City. Vietnam replied last year by granting the Mobil Oil Corp. drilling rights in adjacent waters.

Diplomats in the region say China and Vietnam pledged in November to ``refrain from all acts that'' could ``broaden conflicts'' or lead to the use of force in the region. But a state visit to Hanoi by Chinese President Jiang Zemin did little to allay Vietnam's concern about China's long-term intentions.

While future use of military force by Beijing in the South China Sea is considered possible, Michael Swaine, an expert on the Chinese military at the Rand Corp., argues that by occupying islands and drilling for oil, China has seized ``a negotiating position'' and may want to avoid further military conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON WELCOMES '95 WITH OLD SONGS AND FRIENDS

TEXT.P: ``Life,'' the Southern boy's mother warned him, ``is like a box of chocolates: You never know what you're gonna get.''

With those thoughts, delivered in a wry, drawling homage to the fictional Forrest Gump, another Southern boy, Bill Clinton, welcomed 1995 this weekend, adding in his best self-mocking manner: ``Maybe that's why I never liked chocolate.''

Or so said several of the hundreds of guests who joined the president (who is, in fact, allergic to chocolate) at the annual Renaissance Weekend retreat here, and heard his off-the-record reflections at a private New Year's Eve party of singing, hand-holding, reminiscences and hopes for the future.

In a visit of just over 24 hours, Clinton stayed up chatting with old friends till 2 a.m. Sunday, and was jogging through winding seaside streets in the pitch dark with others by just after 6:30 a.m. He was on a nearby golf course by 7:45 for 18 good holes that ended just in time for him to catch the tail end of a noontime panel discussion called ``Life 101: What I'll Do Differently in '95,'' though he did not offer his own thoughts there.

``He hasn't lost his cool,'' said Liz Carpenter, an ebullient Texan and former aide in the Johnson White House who was making her first visit to the four-day talkfest of the prominent and the precocious that Clinton and his wife, Hillary, have been attending for a decade. ``He obviously feels very comfortable amid these people -- and so do I. They're wonderful people.''

His listeners said Clinton was in fine fettle during his 15-minute after-dinner talk late Saturday night, laughing about all the unsolicited advice he gets. ``He said, `I've gotten a lot of great advice lately, like: Don't waffle, compromise,''' one guest recalled.

But others said the president also spoke soberly, and affectingly, of the honors and burdens of his office, expressing sadness about the death of the pilot whose fatal crash into the White House lawn last fall he suggested was the result of the same fame-seeking motives that prompted a daredevil to make a successful surprise landing in Red Square in Moscow several years ago.

``He said, `It's a great honor to hold this office, but a lot of things make me sad, and probably not the ones you think,''' another guest said. ``He seemed to be saying I'm a person, and I'm the president, and that guy got killed because he landed on what happened to be my lawn. It was very heartfelt.''

Still others said Clinton spoke without partisanship of his hopes for passing tax breaks for education, and of his resolve to press on with health care change, though he acknowledged that it would have to be incremental because the public did not trust the government to do more.
``Some of us had speculated that he might take this occasion to whine,'' said one old acquaintance and one-time booster who has been sharply critical of his presidency. ``He didn't.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
In a year-end interview published in this week's Newsweek magazine, Clinton also took issue with the notion that he does not know what he stands for.
``I believe the purpose of government is not to expand bureaucracy but to expand opportunity,'' he said in the interview last week. ``I do not believe government is inherently good or bad.''

He cited his successful fight to pass a ban on assault weapons, and his unsuccessful one to change health insurance laws, and concluded: ``This idea that there's some battle for my soul is the biggest bunch of hooey I ever saw. I know who I am. I know what I believe.''

As he almost always does in such settings, Clinton partied this weekend till the last dog died, joining other celebrants around a piano at the Hyatt Regency hotel here to sing old favorites like ``Down by the Old Mill Stream.''

After a quick midafternoon walk back from the hotel to the private beachfront home where he and Mrs. Clinton were staying with their daughter Chelsea, he headed back to Washington Sunday evening, so Chelsea can return to school this week. Monday morning Clinton will be on the road again, bound for Little Rock, Ark., for two more days of relaxation.
Even his old friends marveled anew at his stamina.

``I've been running with the president for 12 years,'' said Joan Zoffnass, a doctor from New York who did her best to keep up with the president's predawn pace on Sunday, and was still grimacing a few hours later. ``I don't drink, but I feel like I have a hangover. At least I don't have any patients this morning.''

DOC.HEADLINE: BEARS DEFEAT VIKINGS IN WILD-CARD GAME, 35-18

TEXT.P: In effect, the winner of the Minnesota-Chicago wild-card game would get the opportunity to have their doors blown off by either San Francisco or Dallas. But at least the Bears will get a chance to try because Minnesota decided to be incredibly inept with so much on the line.

With its 35-18 victory on Sunday before 60,347 shellshocked fans at the Metrodome, Chicago moved on in the National Football Conference playoffs and will play San Francisco next week in the second round.

For the Vikings, this defeat marked a huge blow to the franchise for one reason: They hadbrought in quarterback Warren Moon to get them past the first round of the playoffs -- and he didn't even come close. The entire team didn't.

Minnesota made the very ordinary Bears look like world beaters. And Viking Coach Dennis Green must be concerned about why his team played so poorly. His teams have now been eliminated three straight times in the opening round of the playoffs.

It wasn't supposed to happen this way because Moon was supposed to be the savior this season. He limped into Sunday's game with a sprained knee, and the Viking offense was about as creaky as the brace that supported his left leg.

Moon (29 of 52 for 292 yards, 2 touchdowns and 2 interceptions) wasn't sharp, and it was difficult to tell whether it was because of the knee, his inaction last week, or both. Whatever the case both he and his teammates didn't perform well.

That's a sharp contrast to the overachieving Bears. Steve Walsh, a bargain-basement quarterback if there ever was one, looked sharp. Ahead by 14-9 at halftime, Walsh (15 of 23 for 221 yards, touchdowns, 1 interception) marched the Bears down field on their first possession of the second half and increased the lead when the rookie fullback Raymont Harris scored on a 29-yard run.

Later, Walsh hit a wide-open Jeff Graham for a 21-yard touchdown and a 28-12 lead. The Vikings cut into the lead late in the fourth quarter when Moon threw to running back Amp Lee for an 11-yard touchdown. The 2-point conversion was no good as Moon overthrew everyone by 10 feet.

Typical of how the game went for the Vikings, with just over three minutes left in the game and the team driving, Lee fumbled the ball after being hit by Maurice Douglass. The ball was picked up by Kevin Miniefield, a third-string safety, who went 48 yards for a touchdown.

Coming into this game, Minnesota had a distinct historical advantage over the Bears. Green was 6-0 against Chicago, including the sweep of the season series this year. All this week no one could quite explain why Green's teams have dominated the Bears, although the Vikings' defense has a lot to do with it.
In the six losses, Bear quarterbacks have thrown more interceptions returned for touchdowns (6) than actual touchdown passes (5).
But those same people were at a similar loss to explain why Green -- only one of seven head coaches to make the playoffs in each of his first three seasons -- had not won in the post season.
His previous quarterbacks, Rich Gannon and Jim McMahon, had been considered part of the problem.
Last year in the first round of the playoffs, the Giants eliminated the Vikings and knocked McMahon out of the game with a concussion.
The Vikings wanted Moon, who has reached the post-season in each of his past eight seasons, to get them over the playoff hump.

He finished the regular season as the National Football Conference leader in completions (371) and yards (4,264). But what really mattered to the Vikings was whether Moon could get them out of the first round.
In the first half, the Vikings got plenty of chances to get to a big lead on the Bears and help end their post-season slump. But it was their defense that was shining at this point.

Their defense has been among the best in the league and is ranked first against the run. The defensive line is among the fiercest in the game, and the unit is one of the hardest-hitting in the league.

Running back Lewis Tillman found that out in the first quarter. He was smashed by linebacker Ed McDaniel when the Bears tried to force Tillman up the middle. The ball was recovered by Minnesota's Henry Thomas.

But all the Vikings could get out of it was a 29-yard Fuad Reveiz field goal. And when Walsh threw the ball off the back of center Jay Leeuwenburg's head, with the ball landing in the hands of Anthony Parker, the Vikings didn't take advantage. Minnesota's drive consisted of an incomplete pass from Moon to Carter, a holding call on right tackle Chris Hinton and Bears lineman Trace Armstrong sacking Moon.
So instead of a possible 14-0 lead, the Vikings were ahead by just 3-0 after one quarter. The Minnesota defense had to be beside itself.
Walsh then took the Bears on an impressive 16-play, 80 yard drive that ended with a Tillman 1-yard touchdown.

After Viking wide receiver Quadry Ismail bobbled a pass thrown right into his arms that ended up in the hands of linebacker Barry Minter, Walsh took the Bears on a 4-play, 71-yard drive. It began with a 52-yard pass to Jeff Graham, and ended with a 9-yard touchdown pass from Walsh to tight end Keith Jennings on a naked bootleg.

As out of sync as Moon looked and as outplayed the Vikings were in the first half, Minnesota got back into the game when running back Lee took a routine catch over the middle and because of a sweet move turned it into a 38-yard completion. Three plays later, Carter scored on a 4-yard touchdown catch (the 2-point conversion attempt failed) to make the score 14-9.
But the Vikings could never catch up.

DOC.HEADLINE: WALL STREETERS BULLISH ON HIGH-SPEED FERRY

TEXT.P: Drinkers stood two deep at a horseshoe-shaped bar festooned with red and green holiday decorations. Laughter spilled from brokers swapping graveyard jokes about the subway bomber. A couple of financial analysts, the kind who probably would talk shop on their death beds, were huddled in a review of the day's trading on Wall Street.

The only unusual element was the setting. The bar was on an 82-foot boat zipping across the open sea, heading through the darkness for the New Jersey coast. The boat was half of the two-vessel, high-speed ferry fleet that runs daily between Monmouth County, N.J., and New York City.
And if the holiday season put the commuters aboard Express Navigation's ferries in a festive mood, regulars say spirits run even higher in the summer when the party moves to the open-air top deck.
``Most people at the end of a workday dread the commute home -- this one you look forward to,'' said Rob Wolf, 25, a broker with Prestige Planning Corp. in Manhattan.
``It's like hanging out with good friends on a cruise every night with great scenery and fresh air,'' he explained.

Aside from an atmosphere that accommodates both socializing and work, the ferries also rate raves for reliability. When heavy snow or accidents shut down the roadways and trouble on the tracks interrupts rail service, the ferries have clear sailing.

``It's like you're the only car on a 100-lane highway,'' mused Gary E. Dunzelman, the skipper of Express I, as the double-hulled ferry left an East River slip at the foot of Wall Street on schedule at 4:40 p.m. for the 45-minute run to Highlands.

Within a minute, the Express I, with about 200 passengers on board, was gliding over the smooth surface of Upper New York Bay at its cruising speed of 30 knots (about 34 miles per hour), its bow aimed directly at the necklace of lights framing the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

Daily ferries have been operating to New York City from points on the Raritan Bay shore of Monmouth County since 1986, and the acquisition of Express Navigation in 1994 by Holyman United Group, an Australian passenger boat concern, has raised expectations of expanded service in the future.

The ferries make three round trips each working day, and Express Navigation officials say they collect about 900 fares a day in winter (those who travel both ways are counted twice) and 1,200 in summer. All told, they said, the ferries carried about a quarter-million passengers in 1994 in 760 round trips, and service is expected to expand to 1,000 round trips by the year 2000.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
Monmouth County has acquired bay-front property at Belford, N.J., to build a proper ferry terminal, perhaps as early as 1997, said Henry Nicholson, the county director of transportation.

But financing for the $16.5 million project is not yet certain, and many Belford-area residents have objected to it as a subsidy for Wall Street workers who reside in tonier towns like Rumson, N.J.; Little Silver, N.J., and Shrewsbury, N.J.
Nicholson said expanded service would greatly enhance all property values along what is called the county's Bayshore.

While Monmouth's north shore is less than 20 miles from the Battery, it is a 65-mile trip by land, a distance that is made even longer by crowded highways, toll gates, tunnel bottlenecks and time-consuming transfers between transit lines.

A 1991 survey showed that 14,000 Monmouth residents commuted to work in New York and about half lived within a 15-minute drive of the proposed ferry terminal in Belford. ``That's a potential market of 7,000 ferry riders,'' Nicholson said.

So far, the cost of commuting by ferry has held down the numbers. A monthly commuter ticket costs $440, or $11 a crossing. Another drawback is that the last boat for home leaves lower Manhattan at 6:30 p.m. Missing it means making the trek home by roundabout surface transportation.
Still, regular ferry riders swear by the service.
Most work in financial district offices a short walk from the ferry slip at Pier 11 at Wall and South Streets.

``I used to drive to work, but now I figure I get 90 minutes a day of paperwork done on board the ferry,'' said Stephen Ferretti, 33, an exchange floor worker for Goldman Sachs. ``That saves me one day's work a week, or about one full week a month. Hey, how much is your time worth?''

A commuter who moved to Highlands to be close to the ferry is Emily Groff, an underwriter at Reliance National Insurance Co. When she lived in Point Pleasant, farther down the Jersey coast, she spent about 40 minutes a day traveling between her home and the dock.

She praised the shipboard socializing, likening the return trip home to dropping into ``Cheers'' for a couple of beers ($2 a can). ``I work or read on the morning trip, but on the way back I mostly hang out and chat,'' she said.

Captain Dunzelman, who also doubles as operations manager for the small ferry line, said service has been suspended only six days over the last five years. ``Ice is our biggest hazard, and last winter we were locked in a total of three days,'' he said.

The Highland-Manhattan ferries have had one serious accident -- in 1987, when the service was under previous ownership and was called Direct Lines. Two Direct Lines ferries headed in opposite directions ran into each other in a pea-soup fog, sending 18 passengers to the hospital.
Most riders said they believed the ferries were much safer than driving to work.
``The only thing that bothers me is the sound of ice scraping the hull,'' said Ferretti, whose job requires him to exhibit nerves of steel at work.
``Don't worry about it,'' chimed in Wolf, a shipboard friend. ``There are no icebergs out there.''
``Yeah,'' Ferretti said, ``that's what they said about the Titanic.''

DOC.HEADLINE: GOOD DESCRIPTION AND GOOD POLICE WORK LEAD TO CAPTURE OF RAPE SUSPECT

TEXT.P: Out to visit a friend on a quiet New Year's morning, the 33-year-old woman grew uneasy as a scruffy black van drew up beside her on a deserted South Bronx street Sunday. Suddenly, she later told the police, the driver -- a 300-pound, 6-foot menacing presence with a face pockmarked by acne scars -- stepped out, drew a gun and ordered her to get in.
She refused. He bashed her in the face, she said, and dragged her in.

The van had no side-panel windows, she remembered, but it was only 8:10 a.m., and there was no one around anyway. The man raped her, the police said, and then threw her, battered and bruised, back onto the street.
The man drove away. But his bulk, his terrifying face and other details had been burned into the woman's memory.
She staggered to a phone and called 911. Two officers from the 41st Precinct -- Lee Stewart, 29, a rookie, and Jose Martinez, 35, on the force for less than two years -- found her minutes later.
``She was on the sidewalk, leaning against a pole,'' Officer Martinez recalled. ``She was crying, very upset.''
They called for an ambulance. And while they waited, the officers tried to comfort her. They gently asked her questions, too, and obtained the details they needed.

The assailant, she said, had been in his mid-20s, had short hair, weighed more than 300 pounds and had a pockmarked face. He wore light blue jeans, a dark blue shirt and a dark sweater. And there were telling details about his van, a black Chevrolet, with two citizen band radios and a big stereo speaker that looked as if it had been homemade.
The ambulance took the woman to Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center.

Stewart and Martinez resumed patrol, searching the South Bronx for a dark van. It was 10:15 a.m., little more than two hours after the rape, when Stewart saw a dirty, black Chevrolet van six blocks from the scene of the crime. At the wheel was a corpulent man.
``Wow,'' Stewart said. ``I could hardly believe it.''
Martinez said he drove past the van so they could get a look at the driver. ``The guy had a lot of pockmarks on his face,'' he said.

Apparently aware he was under observation, the van's driver tried to speed away, Martinez said, but was caught by the patrol car and complied with the officers' order, over a loudspeaker, to pull over.
The officers did not approach the van immediately because the woman had said the rapist had a gun. Instead, they took down its license number and radioed for backup assistance.
Sgt. Elliot Mercado and Officer Thomas Armstrong of the 41st Precinct arrived two minutes later and they moved in with drawn guns.

``We approached cautiously from the rear at four different angles,'' Martinez said. ``The guy was alone in the van, and he was fidgety and nervous, looking back at us. We told him to throw the keys out the window, to step out and put his hands against the side of the car.''
A search turned up no gun. But the man's features, clothing, vehicle and the items the victim had seen inside fit her description.
While Mercado and Armstrong guarded the suspect, Stewart and Martinez went to the hospital and brought the rape victim back to have a look at the man.

``She identified him as the one who committed the crime,'' Martinez said. The victim was returned to the hospital, but was released after treatment for trauma and for cuts and bruises of the face and head, the police said.
The suspect, Eugenio Cruz Jr., 26, was charged with rape, assault and other crimes. The police said he had been convicted on a weapons charge last year and was free on bail pending sentencing.

``It was really good police work -- excellent police work,'' Sgt. Frances Haimeck-Mladinich, a police spokeswoman, said. ``They took a detailed report, they went back out on patrol and they kept their eyes open. There's always a hope that you might run into the person you're looking for.''

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECT'S WEAPON ISN'T OFTEN USED IN CRIMES, POLICE SAY

TEXT.P: To the many puzzles in the case of John C. Salvi III, the suspect in two killings at abortion clinics, add the question of why he was arrested carrying a weapon used more often for squirrel hunting than for shootouts.
When police officers surrounded his pickup truck on Saturday after a clinic here was sprayed with gunfire, Salvi tossed a .22-caliber rifle out the window.

To be sure, the rifle is no toy. The authorities said a .22-caliber weapon was also used on Friday in the slayings of two receptionists at clinics in Brookline, Mass. And at the clinic here, several shots shattered a plate glass door, whizzed more than 20 feet across the lobby, then burst through a similar window on the other side, a few feet from a clutch of demonstrators. No one was hurt.
The authorities have not yet been able to determine if the weapon they recovered could be linked to either shooting.

But gun experts said a .22-caliber weapon is not often used in crimes, because the ammunition's relatively small width means it does less damage than the firearms that detectives more often see on a street, usually .38-caliber or 9-millimeter weapons.

The .22-caliber has a light recoil making it easier to shoot. The gun Salvi surrendered in Norfolk was semiautomatic, meaning he would have had to squeeze the trigger to fire each round. The rifle found here was made by Ruger, a German manufacturer.

The Norfolk police would not say what model Ruger rifle had been recovered when Salvi was captured. The company makes both .22-caliber rifles used for hunting and more powerful .223-caliber military-style rifle, the Ruger Mini-14.

In both cities, witnesses said the man who fired at the clinics carried his weapon in a black duffle bag. In Brookline, Mass., the bag was left behind and held receipts from a gun shop in New Hampshire where, according to federal records, Salvi had purchased a .22-caliber pistol.
The Virginian-Pilot, the daily newspaper in Norfolk, reported on Sunday that Salvi had bought a .22-caliber Ruger rifle from a former employer for $100 in 1992.

At the time, Salvi was working for a building-maintenance company in Naples, Fla. The company's owner, Mark Rogers, was quoted as saying that about two years ago, just before Salvi moved from Florida to New Hampshire, he modified the gun by hacking off its barrel, cutting down the stock and adding a banana clip, a device to feed more ammunition into the rifle.
``He told me he needed it that way when he went into the woods to shoot,'' Rogers was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERSHIP STANDOFF COULD OVERSHADOW ANY LEGISLATIVE AGENDAS

TEXT.P: The California Assembly reconvenes Wednesday with its leadership still in question -- and the prospect of a long standoff between Republicans and Democrats that could overshadow any legislative agendas.

The power struggle began Dec. 5, when new lawmakers convened and failed to elect a speaker -- despite Republican gains in the Nov. 8 election that briefly gave them the Assembly majority for the first time since 1970.

The fight is now about to spill into the regular 1995-96 legislative session, as Democrat Willie Brown Jr. of San Francisco fights to remain as speaker and Republican Jim Brulte of Rancho Cucamonga seeks to topple him.
Assemblyman Richard Katz, D-Panorama City, a longtime Brown lieutenant, said legislators from both parties are exchanging plenty of phone calls, but said he doesn't believe anyone is making deals.

``I haven't heard of any serious efforts to gain any commitments,'' Katz said, adding that he believes all 39 Democrats and independent Paul Horcher of West Covina are still for Brown, and all 40 Republicans are still for Brulte.
Horcher was re-elected as a Republican but then switched his allegiance to Brown and became an independent -- denying Brulte the speakership.
Brown, the speaker for the past 14 years, has proposed a bipartisan group of legislators meet to devise a power-sharing arrangement -- preferably with him as speaker.
Brulte has countered that because voters elected a Republican majority to the Assembly, he must be named speaker -- but promises to treat Democrats fairly.
Late Friday afternoon, Brulte released a letter to Democratic Assembly members reminding them of Republicans victories Nov. 8.

``We won 41 seats on Election Day, and we will have 41 seats again, sooner rather than later. This being the case, there is tremendous reluctance to negotiate away the Republican majority. I cannot do that, but I can be fair,'' Brulte wrote.

The stakes for both parties are high, including committee chairmanships and assignments, board and commission appointments, and control of staff and resources, all of which could have major influences over legislation in the Assembly for the next two years.
And, because there is yet no popular outcry about the stalemate, it potentially could continue for weeks or even months, said political scientist Sherry Bebitch Jeffe.
``It's certainly important in the Capitol, but it has a very small audience,'' Jeffe said. ``It won't engage most voters until it begins to impact them, and that might not happen until budget time.''
The state Constitution requires the Legislature to pass a balanced budget by June 15, a deadline that is usually missed.

``Over time, we may see some kind of power-sharing or compromise third candidate emerge,'' Jeffe said. ``A lot of the Republicans' problems are with Willie Brown the person, they just don't trust him. So if this goes on, we could see them propose someone else. Until then, many people might not be too upset about the Assembly not doing anything.''

``What's really holding us up now is Brulte's refusal to name a group of Republicans to sit down with us and work it out,'' Katz said. ``He'd apparently prefer to gamble on costly recall elections. It's a risky strategy that could tie us up for weeks, with everyone waiting to see what happens in the recalls.''
The Assembly speakership plot so far has been full of twists and turns.
Republicans won a one-vote majority in November and declared Brown's long speakership over, but lost their advantage Horcher slammed his fist on his desk and quit the party.
Democrats could have won the speakership then by expelling Assemblyman Richard Mountjoy, R-Arcadia, who had also won a special election to the Senate.

But the Democratic chief clerk of the Assembly sided with Republicans and wouldn't allow the vote, only to be hospitalized with stress and exhaustion the next day leaving Brown, as the house's senior member, the presiding officer.
Republicans reacted to that problem by frantically leaving town.

Now, Republicans hope threatened recalls against Horcher and four moderate Democrats will swing at least one vote back to Brulte, while Democrats hope to break the tie by disqualifying Mountjoy, who still hasn't taken the Senate seat he won nearly two months ago.
Brown and Brulte have each declared themselves the only suitable leader, but each has since expressed a commitment to bipartisan power-sharing. However, the two still appear far from a resolution.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL 2ND TAKE FOLLOWS.)

Brown said he will preside at Wednesday's session and reverse the ruling of chief clerk E. Dotson Wilson (who says the law requires him only to preside on the opening day of session), which disallowed a vote on the fitness of Mountjoy to serve in the Assembly. With Mountjoy excluded from that vote, the 39 Democrats and Horcher could vote 40-39 to oust Mountjoy and elect Brown speaker.

But Brulte remains confident that at least a few Democratic lawmakers will respect the wishes of the voters who elected a Republican majority, and allow him to assume his rightful role as speaker, spokesman Phil Perry said.

``Do they really want to force out a duly elected member of the Legislature for purely political reasons? Is this the precedent they intend to set? We remain hopeful that a few reasonable Democrats will refuse to do that,'' Perry said, refusing to name them.

To prove his good intentions, Brulte is offering a constitutional amendment to reduce the speaker's power and guarantee the minority party representation on committees and a fair share of the house budget.

``We have the opportunity to force bipartisan cooperation, we have the opportunity to guarantee the minority party allocation of resources and real justice, and we have the opportunity to diminish the power of the speakership, to see to it that some of the abuses of the past never occur in the future,'' Brulte said last week.
``Term limits changes forever the way Sacramento gets to operate,'' he said. ``The stability of the institution is at risk.''

Immediately after Election day, Brown said he was the only person qualified to lead the house. Later, he said he planned to step down at various times during the session if elected speaker. On a Sacramento radio show last week, he rejected Brulte's idea and pledged instead to to go along with whatever a bipartisan group of 10 lawmakers decides, even if it means a new speaker.

``I think that a group of Democrats and a group of Republicans should meet,'' Brown said. ``Out of that discussion should come a new model for house operation, a model reflecting of the change in the makeup of the house as the result of term limits, as well as a result of voter participation.''
He said such a bipartisan solution is necessary because of the nearly even split between Democrats and Republicans, and because the house is now dominated by inexperienced legislators.

``I've always been prepared at any time during the course of my 14 years to do what is appropriate and best for the house, period, and that's my dedication and that's my goal, and I keep insisting that there shall be such a meeting,'' Brown said.

``Out of that may come either one of the two candidates for the job being given the responsibility, or somebody different. I'm prepared to support the work product of that which means it could exclude Willie Brown as leader.''

Eventually, the Assembly will have to get down to serious policy making this year, and there will be no shortage of issues. On the table will be cuts in the state income tax, school spending, prison spending, no-fault auto insurance, the Smog Check program, recycling programs, workers compensation reform, health care, Orange County's fiscal problems, and services to illegal immigrants while Proposition 187 is tied up in court.
If a speaker is elected this week and committees formed, those issues can begin to be addressed.
``I'm praying that happens,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROMISING `CERTAIN AND IMMEDIATE' CHANGE, PATAKI BECOMES N.Y. GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Calling for a new revolution to make government both smaller and more effective, George Elmer Pataki became the 53rd governor of New York Sunday with an inaugural address that promised ``sweeping and fundamental change that is certain and immediate.''

In a 38-minute address, long enough to lull 7-year-old Owen Pataki into dozing on his mother's lap, Pataki repeatedly summoned the imagery of the American Revolution and suggested that his election was born of the same discontent with taxation and bureaucracy that incited the colonials.

``The battle which took place on a farm not far from here near Saratoga was the turning point in that revolution,'' he said, returning later in the speech to what he called the ``revolutionary spirit of Saratoga.''

``And I would remind those who are disturbed by the people's current mood of the lesson from that battle -- the lesson that much good can come from the people's determination to see that government remains their servant and not their master.''

With former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo sitting on the stage to his left, Pataki said New Yorkers believe their government has become ``too big, too unwieldy, too distant, too arrogant.'' But he also suggested repeatedly that government was capable of resurrecting itself into a force for good.
``What those in government have done, those in government can undo,'' he said.

Much of the speech was a recitation of Pataki's campaign themes, delivered this time for a television audience that had a new reason to pay attention. He called for cuts in state taxes and spending, an expansion of the state's workfare program for welfare recipients, term limits for elected officials, restoration of the death penalty and abolition of parole for violent felons.
Pataki's speech capped a weekend of celebration for New York Republicans, who have not held the governorship for 20 years.

The 49-year-old Pataki stayed until well past 1 a.m. at a New Year's Eve party that he threw for friends and aides at an Albany hotel, dancing sweatily to hits from Motown and the Rolling Stones. He traveled to his inauguration in a comical convoy down Albany's State Street, where the only observers on a damp and misty morning were a few churchgoers and a jogging mob of reporters who pleaded with the governor to lower the windows of his Lincoln Town Car.

After the inauguration at the Knickerbocker Arena, which was attended by an estimated 13,000 people, Pataki made the rounds at a sprawling reception in the concourse of the Empire State Plaza, sampling a piece of a giant sheet cake that bore his likeness in icing.

The party featured salsa bands and barbershop quartets, as well as Lithuanian meat pies, Nigerian seafood rolls and other ethnic foods from dozens of countries. The day was topped off by a $100-per-person, black-tie gala at the Omni Hotel.

Although the day was reserved for pomp, Pataki's aides were preparing for a full workday on Monday. His counsel, Michael C. Finnegan, said that a senior staff meeting was planned for the afternoon and that another meeting would be devoted to reviewing death-penalty legislation.

Other personnel appointments are expected later this week, with Pataki aides saying that State Senator John B. Daly, a Lewiston Republican, is now the front-runner to become transportation commissioner.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)

Clearly, the day was historic for Pataki and the Republicans. But it also was momentous for State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who was sworn in as the first black New Yorker to be elected to statewide office.

McCall, a Democrat, had been elected by the Legisalature in 1993 to fill the vacancy left by the midterm resignation of Edward V. Regan. But he did not face a popular election until last fall, when he defeated Herbert London.

``My election,'' McCall, 58, said after the ceremony, ``will be a signal to young people throughout the state, particularly African-American young people, a sign of hope for them and a sign of encouragement. There will be no barriers as a result of race.''

Two other statewide officials, both Republicans, also took the oath of office Sunday. Elizabeth P. McCaughey, 46, a constitutional scholar who worked for a conservative foundation, was sworn in as Pataki's lieutenant governor. And Dennis C. Vacco, a 42-year-old former U.S. attorney from Buffalo, became state attorney general.
As a pipe-and-drum brigade escorted Pataki into the arena, he was greeted by a thunderous cheer that sounded the Republicans' relief from two decades of frustration.

In the stands, one fan threw his hands in the air as if his favorite team had just scored a touchdown. Supporters on the floor rattled ``Pataki for President'' signs. As Pataki took his oath, which was administered by Chief Judge Judith S. Kaye of the State Court of Appeals, those in the arena could hear the echoes of a 19-gun cannonade being fired outside.

Pataki delivered his speech in the breathy cadences that mark his oratorical style, making points of emphasis by pumping air rather than volume into his voice. Adopting the Reaganesque tactic of recognizing heroes in the audience, he stopped his speech at one point to pay tribute to Jason McEnaney, the State University student who was shot last month while tackling a gunman who had taken his class hostage in Albany.

The governor began by acknowledging the anger of the electorate but said he believed the ``anger is a generous and optimistic anger.'' He called for ``effective but limited government,'' and repeatedly stressed the theme of personal responsibility.
``When government accepts responsibility for people, then people no longer take responsibility for themselves,'' he said. ``Individual responsibility and personal freedom are inevitably linked.''

Pataki's largest ovation came when he reiterated his campaign pledge to sign the death penalty into law. ``When a society does not express its own horror at the crime of murder by enforcing the ultimate sanction against it, innocent lives are put at risk,'' he said. ``Not out of a sense of vindictiveness, then, but a sense of justice -- indeed, a sense of compassion for those who otherwise might become victims of murder -- I will ask the Legislature to pass and I will sign and enforce the death penalty.''

Cuomo, who vetoed death-penalty bills 12 times, sat motionless as the crowd erupted around him. ``It disconcerts me that the loudest cheer would be for death,'' he said in an interview Sunday afternoon.

But the former governor, who received a standing ovation from the primarily Republican crowd, also congratulated Pataki heartily after the address, telling him, ``That wasn't a good speech, that was a great speech.'' Cuomo said Pataki ``did what he had to do -- he had to say what he stands for.''

Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, said he found inconsistencies in some of Pataki's pledges and was eager to see Pataki convert from a campaigner into a governor. For instance, he said, ``if you are going to incarcerate more criminals and violent criminals for a longer period of time, you're going to spend money.''

Pataki will start to transform his broad promises into more detailed policies on Wednesday, when he will deliver his State of the State address, and again on Feb. 1, when he presents his first budget proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES SEEK REASON FOR CLINIC ATTACKS

TEXT.P: Investigators said Sunday that they were trying to figure out why John Salvi III, a New Hampshire man accused of killing two women at abortion clinics in Massachussetts on Friday, came to this Tidewater city, which has been a hotbed of anti-abortion activity.
Salvi has been charged with murder and with assault with attempt to murder in the attacks in Brookline, Mass., in which two receptionists were shot to death and five other people were wounded.
He was arrested here on Saturday, shortly after shots were fired at a Norfolk abortion clinic; no one was injured.

Police officials in Virginia and Massachusetts, as well as people on both sides of the abortion issue, said Sunday that Salvi was not known as a prominent figure of an anti-abortion group, though New Hampshire authorities said they had found anti-abortion literature in his home in Hampton Beach.

Salvi is being held in the city jail here and has been talking to the police since his arrest, which came 26 hours after the killings in Massachusetts. But he has refused to talk to reporters, and police investigators refused to disclose what he said in five or six hours of questioning on Saturday night.
The authorities said he did not yet have a lawyer.
Salvi, who was hailed Sunday as a hero by some local leaders of the anti-abortion movement, was described by friends as a moody, Scripture-quoting man.
Salvi's neighbors said he had a fight with his father shortly before Christmas, apparently because the older man disapproved of his son's decision to pursue a career as a hairdresser.
Salvi's parents live in Naples, Fla., and visited him over Christmas at his home; their whereabouts Sunday could not be determined.
The clinic here, the Hillcrest Clinic, has often been a target of picketing, protests and demonstrations since it opened in a block-long three-story building in 1973.

An intruder set a fire in the clinic in 1983, and a pipe bomb exploded near it in 1984. It is not known whether Salvi had visited the clinic before Saturday, or whether he had received information or assistance from local abortion opponents.

Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., who will be the Senate majority leader in the new Congress, Sunday described the attacks on the clinics as acts of terrorism. He suggested that clinics might need more federal protection.
On the CBS News progam ``Face the Nation,'' Dole said, ``Obviously this is murder, terrorism, call it what you will.''
While the government cannot protect every abortion clinic, he said, ``let's do what we can do to stop the violence.'

The Norfolk police said Salvi was captured by a stroke of luck. An arson investigator, looking into an earlier fire at a bank in the same building, saw the shooting, chased the gunman's truck and summoned police officers, who arrested Salvi three blocks from the Hillcrest Clinic.
The police said he had fired more than 20 rounds from a .22-caliber semiautomatic rifle into the building.

Larry Hill, a spokesman for the Norfolk police, said Salvi tossed the .22-caliber Ruger rifle from the window of his truck moments before he was arrested. Gun enthusiasts say such weapons are popular for squirrel hunting and target practice but are not often used in crimes.
Two militant opponents of abortion in the Norfolk area, the Rev. Donald Spitz, 48, and David Crane, 36, said the violence was understandable and perhaps even justifiable.

In an interview Sunday, Spitz, the director of an organization called Pro-Life Virginia, said that if Salvi had killed abortion clinic employees in Brookline ``to defend the lives of unborn babies, it's justified, it's moral, it was a righteous act.''

``It's not right to go kill people,'' said Spitz, who described himself as a Pentecostal evangelist. ``But when people are involved in killing babies, then it's justified to save the babies. The point is to save the babies, not to kill people. Babies deserve to be defended at any cost.''
Eight opponents of abortion showed their support for Salvi with a rally and prayer vigil in front of the jail Sunday afternoon.

Spitz and Crane said they had been field directors of Operation Rescue, an anti-abortion group that has tried to block access to clinics across the country. Spitz said he was expelled from the organization last year because it ``holds to the philosophy of nonviolence in every situation,'' and he could not endorse that stance.

The two men said they had not heard of Salvi before he was named as a suspect in the shootings in Brookline. Hill said that the authorities here had no evidence that Salvi had had any dealings with Spitz or Crane but that the police were investigating to see if there were connections.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

Crane, the director of a Norfolk anti-abortion group, Citizens for Justice, and Spitz signed a petition last year declaring that it was proper to take ``all godly action necessary, including the use of force, to defend innocent human life, born and unborn.''
The FBI expressed interest in the activities of both men in August, when it began an inquiry into a possible conspiracy to use force against women's clinics around the country.
In an interview at his church Sunday, Crane said the shootings and bombings at abortion clinics were ``random acts of individuals.'' But he said they could be explained.
``Deadly force is being used against the unborn, so people are now willing to use that same kind of force against the abortion industry,'' he said.

On the other hand, some opponents of abortion condemned the killings. The Rev. Richard Hardison, pastor at the Tabernacle Church of Norfolk and a longtime friend of Crane's, said the protests against abortion should be conducted peacefully. ``At no point did Christ ever take up arms to prove his point,'' Hardison said.

Judi Brown, president of the American Life League, based in Stafford, Va., said, ``The death of anyone diminishes each one of us, whether it be by suction machine or by bullets shot by a man who was most obviously disturbed.''
Marino, Montana and Moon.

The names lack the hallowed ring of Tinker to Evers to Chance but the trilogy signifies a sense of generation as three quarterbacks approach the defining points of their careers. One career has been truly spectacular, the other two outstanding but star-crossed.
Montana's career has been distinguished by fulfillment; Marino's and Moon's have been sprinkled with accolades, lavish statistics and mounds of frustration. Frustration they hoped to end this season.
On Saturday in Miami, Dan Marino outdueled Joe Montana as the Dolphins' 33-year-old quarterback inched closer to an elusive second Super Bowl appearance.
Saturday's game was billed as a battle of legends, but there's only one legend in all three of these M's, and that's Montana.

Marino simply won another battle of statistics, completing 22 of 29 passes for 257 yards with 2 touchdowns and no interceptions. Montana was 26 of 37 for 314 yards and 2 touchdowns. The game turned on a Montana blunder, when Miami's J.B. Brown intercepted his pass near the goal line as Montana was leading the Chiefs on one of his patented drives.

After the loss, Montana, who like Moon is 38, was asked about retirement. ``Ain't even thinking about that right now,'' said Montana. ``I didn't think I had to think about it. It's like asking a fighter after he's lost a championship bout if he'll fight again. You feel bad, but, yeah, the game's fun. I'm having fun with it.''

Montana, with four Super Bowl rings already, entered Saturday's game solidly enshrined as a legend, voted to the National Football League's 75th anniversary team with quarterbacks Otto Graham, Johnny Unitas and Sammy Baugh.

Marino and Moon entered their respective games this weekend with all those accolades but with a gap when it came to winning the big ones. Marino was blessed with great receivers and cursed with porous defense. Moon was beset throughout his career with gimmick offenses that built up passing stats but short-circuited in critical games.

While Montana was out to simply add to a legend created over a 16- year career, all Marino and Moon can hope for is to win enough games to put themselves in position to capture just one championship before time runs out.

After Saturday's game, a reporter asked the Dolphin quarterback whether the victory settled the score between Marino and Montana. In the 1984 season, Marino, a brash, 23-year-old, second-year pro, met Montana in Super Bowl XIX. Miami was trashed.

``This didn't settle a score,'' Marino said. For all the talk about gun-slinging, all the attention by the news media giving Marino equal billing with Montana, Marino knows that he has yet to scale a mountain that Montana has already scaled four times.

The difference between Montana and Marino may have best been encapsulated by a critical game against the Jets last month that came down to the final play. With time running out, with the ball near the Jets' goal line, Marino made believe he was going to spike the ball to stop the clock. Instead, in the split second that the defense relaxed, Marino fired a touchdown pass to win the game.

Ingenious. Legal. But a play that nonetheless leaves a bad taste in your mouth. That's not like Montana to Dwight Clark to beat Dallas in a conference championship game; not like Montana to John Taylor to beat Cincinnati in the Super Bowl.

If the phenomenon of Marino is numbers, the miracle of Warren Moon has been endurance. He entered the NFL in 1984, the season Marino and Montana met in the Super Bowl. Moon spent his first six seasons in the Canadian Football League and came to Houston in a high-priced deal that the Oilers hoped would take the franchise to new heights. It proved to be a roller coaster instead.

By 1985, he was criticized for an inability to read defenses; in 1986, critics were calling Moon ``disappointing;'' in 1987, he won the passing title and helped Houston make the playoffs for the first time since 1980. In 1989, the Oilers needed to win one of two remaining regular-season games to win an undisputed division title. They lost them both and failed to reach the playoffs.

In 1990, Moon was on pace to set passing records when he dislocated his thumb in the 15th game of the season. The Oilers were humiliated in a 41-14 first-round playoff loss, A year later, Houston won its first division title and failed to get past the second round. In 1992, Houston blew a 32-point lead to Buffalo and was eliminated once again. Last season, Moon was injured down the stretch, came back and met Montana head to head in the playoffs. The Oilers lost.

On Sunday afternoon, with a new team in a new city, with a bum knee, Moon was revisited by the same frustration. Lots of numbers: 29 of 52 for 292 yards, 2 touchdowns, 2 interceptions. Lots of dink passes. No victory. The game was a microcosm of Moon's playoff career: up and down, alternately cheered and booed. He excited the crowd with a touchdown pass to Amp Lee with 5:36 left to play to narrow the Vikings' deficit to 28-18. But then a 4-yard pass to Lee was fumbled and returned 50 yards for a Chicago touchdown.

The numbers that loom are the numbers that frame Moon's playoff portfolio: 3-6 in 10 seasons with Houston, 0-1 with Minnesota. The Vikings were first-round losers in each of the past two years. Now make that three.
Moon's playoff frustrations began 10 years ago under a dome in Houston. They grew deeper on Sunday afternoon under a bubble in Minnesota.
Marino survives, Montana is out. Now Moon is, too, at least for this season.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOMBING PLOT SEEN IN NOTES, OFFICIAL SAYS

TEXT.P: Notes and drawings found in the home of Edward Leary, the accused subway firebomber, show that he planned to detonate bombs with motion-sensing devices and remote controls and to gun people down with a high-powered rifle as part of a terror campaign in the subways, a law-enforcement official said Sunday.

The two gasoline bombs that have been attributed to Leary were both meant to explode aboard trains while they were in tunnels, possibly under the East River, to achieve the maximum carnage and panic, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Both devices instead exploded in subway stations, and the official said that one went off sooner than the bomber intended and the other exploded much later than intended.
Leary, who has denied any role in the bombings, was badly burned in the second incident, on Dec. 21 in lower Manhattan.

That bombing injured 45 people, brought subway and vehicular traffic in the Financial District to a standstill and revived the sense of vulnerability to terrorist attacks that gripped the city after the World Trade Center bombing, almost two years earlier.

The fact that the bombings were botched casts serious doubt on Leary's ability to carry out the more sophisticated attacks that were described in his notes, the official said. But since Leary is believed to have carried out two bombings, he said, ``It has to be taken seriously.''

In the days after the Dec. 21 bombing, officials said that six pages of notes found at Leary's home showed that he planned a campaign of bombings on the subways to extort money, probably from the Transit Authority or the city.
The plans for a remote-controlled, motion-sensing bomb and a sniper attack were first reported Sunday in New York Newsday.
Leary's lawyer, Stephen Murphy, assailed police leaks in the case Sunday, saying, ``What they're trying to do is prejudice the public so he can't get a fair trial.''

Asked Sunday about the drawings and notes reportedly found in Leary's home in Scotch Plains, N.J., Murphy at first questioned their existence, but he said later at a news conference that they were Leary's notes for a science fiction novel.

He also said that some of the threatening notes attributed to Leary by the police were actually notes written to him by other residents of the Brooklyn co-op building where he once lived, during a dispute two years ago.
Of the report that Leary planned more sophisticated bombings, Murphy said: ``He's not capable of this stuff. It's 50 miles beyond him.''
The law-enforcement official said the notes were crucial to building a case against Leary.

``You can't really get a conviction based just on people's plans to wreak havoc,'' he said. ``And we can link him to the Dec. 21 device through eyewitness identification, though that alone might not be enough for a conviction.''
But combining the witness accounts, the attacks that were carried out and the notes found in Leary's home, he said, ``You have a very strong case.''
Leary has been charged with the Dec. 21 bombing aboard a No. 4 train at Fulton Street and is a suspect in a Dec. 15 bombing aboard a subway train in Harlem that injured two teen-agers.

A police official said Sunday that 10 witnesses to the Dec. 21 incident recall seeing a man matching Leary's description sitting on the subway, holding a bag that reeked of gasoline and made sounds like glasses clinking together.
Investigators have said that the bomb was contained in a pair of glass mayonnaise jars.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

From the beginning, officials have surmised from the fact that Leary was injured that the Dec. 21 bomb went off sooner than the bomber expected. An official said Sunday that the Dec. 15 device, which did not ignite completely, went off much later than intended.
He said that the bomb may have been planted on the No. 3 train in Brooklyn, detonating as much as half an hour later at the 145th Street station in Manhattan.
In each case, the official said, ``He wanted this thing to go off in a tunnel,'' possibly under the East River, where escape and rescue efforts would have been most difficult.
Thirteen people were seriously burned in the Dec. 21 bombing, and nine of them, including Leary, remain at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.
One victim, Renfield Edey, remains in critical but stable condition. Two other people who were originally in critical condition, Leary and Brenda Dowdell, have been upgraded to serious condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG ISLANDERS SHRUG OFF NEW SMOKING BANS

TEXT.P: It was a New Year's Day of football, beer and munchies at Jerry Cusack's bar and restaurant here on Route 111, and even though a tough new smoking ban had gone into effect in the county, many patrons were smoking as usual.
Under the new law, Cusack and other restaurateurs do not face the threat of fines because of smokers until June 1, when the last of a series of new restrictions are to be phased in by Suffolk County.
Most of his customers, Cusack said, were unaware of the new regulations, among the toughest in the country and even stricter than those recently passed by the New York City Council.

``I'm not a smoker myself, and I hate smoke,'' Cusack said. ``And in a perfect world no one would smoke. But I'm in a business that serves both smokers and nonsmokers. And I can't afford to lose half my customers because of government interference.''

Those who support the smoking restrictions say such predictions are unfounded. Nora Bredes, a Suffolk County legislator who co-sponsored the ban with Paul J. Tonna, said she was confident that there would be no decline in business at bars and restaurants because of the new restrictions.

``There hasn't been a drop off in customers at movie theaters and at airlines where they've banned smoking,'' she said. ``Everyone who breathes air has got to have an interest in seeing this law go into effect.''

The new regulations will require bars and restaurants to ban smoking by the end of the month or start plans to construct separate enclosures for those who smoke. Cusack, who said he had not yet decided which course he would follow, said the average restaurant would have to spend around $50,000 for such a separate floor-to-ceiling enclosure.
For now, restaurant employees are supposed to tell patrons that the law has taken effect and that they should not smoke.
The fines -- to be paid by restaurant owners and not patrons -- will range from $50 to $250 a day. The law enables the county to place liens against businesses that refuse to pay.

The rules are the latest and strictest measures approved by Suffolk County, which for two decades has led the nation in enacting tough antismoking legislation, beginning with a ban on smoking in supermarkets, then including malls, offices, theaters and other public places.

The new law, signed last June, affects restaurants and bars where food constitutes at least 40 percent of sales. It also bans smoking in schools, day-care centers, bowling alleys and other sports and recreational facilities.
Cusack, who owns and operates Heffron's bar and restaurant here, also is co-chairman of the Long Island Hospitality Association, which represents some 400 bars and restaurants.

``We're still hoping that the law can be changed or modified,'' he said. ``If not, many of us will be going out of business. Certainly, no one's going to be opening any new restaurants in Suffolk under these terms.
``This law sends out a message loud and clear that Suffolk is anti-business,'' Cusack added.
Mrs. Bredes defends the restrictions and calls them overdue.
``Since tobacco smoke has been proven to be one of the leading causes of cancer,'' she said, ``it's surprising that we haven't done something about it sooner.''
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS.)
Both she and Tonna said that their efforts to pass the law made them the target of heavy opposition from the cigarette lobby, led, they said, by Philip Morris.

Nassau County is currently reviewing its antismoking laws and is expected to follow Suffolk's lead. Nassau now enforces state requirements, which ban smoking in hallways, elevators, bathrooms, sports arenas, hospitals and all other public places, said Cynthia Brown, spokeswoman for the Nassau County Health Department.

She said that restaurants with 50 or more seats must now limit space for smokers to no more than 25 percent of their capacity. However, smoking is permitted in bars and the bar areas of restaurants. Nassau also observes the state law that bans smoking in common areas in the workplace.

New York City also currently follows state guidelines in restaurants. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to soon sign a bill, adopted by the City Council on Dec. 21, that would ban smoking altogether in restaurants with 35 or more seats. Smoking would be permitted in bar areas and in enclosed ``smoking lounges.''

In the workplace, the New York City bill would allow smoking only in separately ventilated rooms and private offices with no more than three employees. If the bill is signed, the law would go into effect in late March.

Cusack said that his organization planned to continue to fight the new Suffolk rules and would speak against them on Jan. 24, when legislators who oppose the regulations plan to hold a hearing on whether to impose a yearlong moratorium.

Some opponents want the county to await the results of Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration hearings, to be concluded later this month, on whether to ban smoking in the workplace. Should restaurant workers be included in the ban, opponents say, it would make all local laws moot and would make the building of separate enclosures for smokers unnecessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECT'S WEAPON ISN'T OFTEN USED IN CRIMES, POLICE SAY

TEXT.P: To the many puzzles in the case of John C. Salvi III, the suspect in two killings at abortion clinics, add the question of why he was arrested carrying a weapon used more often for squirrel hunting than for shootouts.
When police officers surrounded his pickup truck on Saturday after a clinic here was sprayed with gunfire, Salvi tossed a .22-caliber rifle out the window.

To be sure, the rifle is no toy. The authorities said a .22-caliber weapon was also used on Friday in the slayings of two receptionists at clinics in Brookline, Mass. And at the clinic here, several shots shattered a plate glass door, whizzed more than 20 feet across the lobby, then burst through a similar window on the other side, a few feet from a clutch of demonstrators. No one was hurt.
The authorities have not yet been able to determine if the weapon they recovered could be linked to either shooting.

But gun experts said a .22-caliber weapon is not often used in crimes, because the ammunition's relatively small width means it does less damage than the firearms that detectives more often see on a street, usually .38-caliber or 9-millimeter weapons.

The .22-caliber has a light recoil making it easier to shoot. The gun Salvi surrendered in Norfolk was semiautomatic, meaning he would have had to squeeze the trigger to fire each round. The rifle found here was made by Ruger, an American manufacturer.

The Norfolk police would not say what model Ruger rifle had been recovered when Salvi was captured. The company makes both .22-caliber rifles used for hunting and more powerful .223-caliber military-style rifle, the Ruger Mini-14.

In both cities, witnesses said the man who fired at the clinics carried his weapon in a black duffle bag. In Brookline, Mass., the bag was left behind and held receipts from a gun shop in New Hampshire where, according to federal records, Salvi had purchased a .22-caliber pistol.
The Virginian-Pilot, the daily newspaper in Norfolk, reported on Sunday that Salvi had bought a .22-caliber Ruger rifle from a former employer for $100 in 1992.

At the time, Salvi was working for a building-maintenance company in Naples, Fla. The company's owner, Mark Rogers, was quoted as saying that about two years ago, just before Salvi moved from Florida to New Hampshire, he modified the gun by hacking off its barrel, cutting down the stock and adding a banana clip, a device to feed more ammunition into the rifle.
``He told me he needed it that way when he went into the woods to shoot,'' Rogers was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: A `NEW DAWN' IN ALBANY, BUT A SEATING CHART REVEALED AN OLD FEUD

TEXT.P: A 19-gun salute thundered outside Knickerbocker Arena and, later, lasers flickered from the podium as a disembodied voice sputtered, ``Pataki! Pataki! Pataki! Pataki!''
Birds and crickets chirped from somewhere, as if to greet what the printed programs called ``a new dawn.''
But for all the pageantry of the first Republican inauguration here in 24 years, it was the seating arrangement on the dais, more than anything, that hammered home how much things have changed.
Mario Cuomo, who has dominated every stage he sat on since 1982, was seated quietly to the podium's right, applauding selectively and fidgeting with his glasses.

The radio personality Howard Stern -- whose long hair stuck out in the crowd and not just because it sucked up so much confetti -- was seated in the third row, behind Chief Judge Judith Kaye and in front of William Powers, the Republican state committee chairman.

Stern is credited with turning out the vote in the last few days before the election by stumping for George Pataki on the air. Jackie Mason, the Republican bard, also sat near the podium, though in a back row.

Ralph Marino, the courtly Republican who was ousted last month after six years as Senate majority leader, took his place behind the man who wrested him from power, Sen. Joseph Bruno. And New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who won no friends among Republicans by supporting Cuomo in the election, was seated in the third row, the same as Stern, though across the podium and a bit farther from the action.

The dais, ringed with 4,000 roses, was a scene of jubilation. The oratory looked to the future. But some slights were not forgotten. Just before the ceremony, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato strode past Giuliani without looking at him. And then, as if to underscore his continued displeasure with an old friend, he then shook the hand of Giuliani's neighbor.
Behind Smoked Windows
The celebration began with a frosty procession from the State Capitol building over slippery streets to the arena.
The question: Where was Pataki? The 35 gold-bedecked bagpipers had marched off, followed by Peekskill and Cortlandt firefighters (the companies where Pataki's father, Louis, was once a volunteer).
Reporters scrambled, slipping on ice as they tried to figure out which limousine with smoked windows carried the state's 53rd governor.

Finally, halfway to the arena, a window came down and a few people on the street cheered. As reporters gathered in, practically crushing each other to hear every word, Pataki said he felt ``tremendous.'' He then explained the rolled-up window. ``We don't want anybody to get hurt,'' he said, without elaboration.
Luck Without Lentils

Mimicking his idol, the former New York Gov. Theodore Roosevelt, who used to greet the public on New Year's when he became president, Pataki will hold a reception for the public inside the Executive Mansion on Monday. But rather than greet anyone who stands in line, as Roosevelt did, Pataki's aides came up with a clever idea: hold a lottery to determine who is invited.

At the end of the swearing in, Pataki's daughter Allison, 9, selected the winning number, 68892, which was printed on the back of 500 of the programs. Those people, plus a guest, can attend and shake the governor's hand.

Tony Spano, one of the winners and the 28-year-old brother of Sen. Nicholas Spano, a Republican, said that in his family it's a tradition to eat lentils at midnight on New Year's Eve. ``But I didn't, and it's supposed to bring good luck,'' he said. ``It just tells you that it's a myth, all this eating lentils.''
Have a Varenyky

The new administration did know how to throw a party. The underground concourse at the Empire State Plaza was packed with what organizers said was 10,000 people. There were a dozen musical groups, from the Uncle Sam Chorus of Troy, N.Y., featuring Uncle Sam himself singing in harmony, to two guys in dinner jackets blasting out Jimi Hendrix.
There were 100,000 pounds of vegetables, 175 cases of cheese, 90 kegs of beer, 42,000 toothpicks and 200 pounds of lobsters.

There were also 22 booths of different ethnic foods. The people at this so-called ``People's Reception'' ate spinach empanadas from the Argentine booth; varenyky, or potato dumplings, from the Armenian booth and sauteed buffalo with wild rice from the Native American booth.
Pataki's ethnic origins are Italian, Irish and Hungarian, and the people who ran the Hungarian booth were especially proud to be there.

Sandor Fiegler, 54, a retired construction worker from Latham, N.Y. who immigrated from Hungary when he was 16, said that Pataki is a common name in his home country, where it means ``little creek or brook.'' He was in Budapest during the election in November and said many Hungarians went wild when Pataki won.

He said people flocked to his booth, where he was serving goulash thick with paprika, kielbasa and rolled pastries called kalacs. ``Everybody says, `we've got to try out what he eats,' '' Fiegler said. ``Probably he's never tasted it anyway.''
