The Pataki Express

Albin Sabol settled into his seat on Amtrak's Pataki Special Sunday morning, looked out at the mist shrouding the Hudson and mused aloud about how a tow-headed boy he used to help with science projects could grow up to become the governor of New York state.
``All I know watching George grow up is that he doesn't have to be led and he won't be led,'' Sabol said. ``He's got a mind of his own.''
``He was a bright kid and all our kids played together,'' Sabol added.

Sunday Sabol and his wife, Connie, were among about 250 people who got up at dawn and climbed aboard a special express train to Albany. There were 21 Lubavitch Hasidim from Crown Heights in Brooklyn, several Chinese-American Republicans from Flushing, Queens, a dozen Black Republicans from the city and a foursome of Bangladeshi businessmen who had supported the governor.

At Croton-on-Hudson, a party of 22 friends and aquaintances of the governor from his home town of Peekskill crowded aboard with drinks and American flags. They pasted a banner above their seats that read ``The Pataki Party Train'' and posted a list of the top 10 ways to get to the inauguration. (The top of the list was ``Take Amtraky to Pataki.'')
``I want to be part of it,'' said Gigi Lisella, 39, a housewife from Peekskill. ``I mean, how many times in your lifetime is the governor of New York state going to be from your hometown.''

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNT FOR SUSPECT WAS VAST, BUT LUCK PLAYED CRUCIAL ROLE

TEXT.P: In the frantic first minutes after a man shot his way through two abortion clinics here, instantly killing one woman, fatally injuring another and leaving five people wounded and bleeding, the Brookline, Mass., police took the first steps in an intensive manhunt that would stretch from U.S. Customs offices on the Canadian border to a lonely stretch of highway in Rhode Island.

Yet thorough as it was, the net stopped hundreds of miles short of where the suspect, John C. Salvi III, would later be captured. While officers from more than a dozen federal, state and local law-enforcement agencies followed a trail that began with what one official described as a ``wonderful treasure trove'' of evidence, the suspect -- identified within hours of the attacks -- eluded every net and was caught only by chance.

The manhunt and its conclusion, as detailed by federal, state and local officials and eyewitnesses, reveal both strengths and weaknesses in a system that combined the country's most sophisticated forensic research with old-fashioned good luck.

It began at 10:04 a.m. on Friday, when the 911 line started ringing and yellow panel lights flashed at the Brookline police station. The caller was traumatized and afraid. Moments before, the caller said, a tall man dressed in black had burst into the waiting room at the Planned Parenthood clinic at 1031 Beacon Street and started spraying bullets at clinic patients, their family members and the staff.

Howard Brackett, the chief of the Brookline Police Department, said the officers were immediately sent to the scene. Within minutes, the first two officers arrived, confirmed the attack and sent a message over the radio system calling for backup units.

Several blocks away, Patrol Capt. Daniel O'Leary heard the news and sent patrol cars to three other clinics in the area. One patrol car stopped less than half a mile from the Planned Parenthood site, at the Repro Associates clinic at 1297 Beacon Street. It was quiet. It was also calm at Women's Health Services at 822 Boylston Street.

Another car headed to the Preterm Health Services clinic about a mile to the west of the first attack. While it was on its way, the gunman took out a .22-caliber semi-automatic rifle and continued his murderous spree there. Another call came over the police radio. But the gunman had vanished by the time the patrol car arrived, running west along Beacon Street, witnesses later said, then disappearing from sight.

Chief Brackett said the first minutes after the shootings were chaotic. Victims were calling out for help. Witnesses were hastily rounded up for details. And areas likely to be important to the investigation were roped off.

As ambulances from the Brewster Ambulance Service started to arrive and emergency medical technicians began unloading stretchers, police still were not sure whether the attacks were over. More officers from federal agencies and the Brookline and Boston police departments were sent to guard other sites where abortions were performed, as well as flashpoints like the headquarters of the Massachusetts chapter of the National Organization for Women.
While police rushed to secure the other sites, investigators began to pore over the crowded crime scenes.
(STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)
(MORE)

As they pieced together the evidence, police learned that the gunman had exchanged fire with a security guard at the Preterm clinic. The security guard, Richard J. Seron, was wounded, but he unwittingly provided crucial material that would soon identify the suspect. When he shot at the assailant, the gunman left a duffel bag behind as he fled.

Inside it, a police officer familiar with the investigation said, were critical pieces of evidence: a .22-caliber handgun, a receipt from a Salisbury, Mass., gun shop, and four or five clips of ammunition that had been purchased a day or two before. The bag also yielded a print.

The sales slip provided police with their first important clue, sending them off to Bob's Tactical Shooting Range and Gunshop in Salisbury in pursuit of a suspect they then could identify only as John, the name written across the receipt.

An agent with the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and a Brookline police officer immediately headed for the shop, not daring to call ahead for fear that shop employees might themselves be accomplices. While they headed north, on an hour-long drive to Salisbury, a witness reported that a white compact car that was double parked outside the second clinic might have been involved in the assault.
The information led to a brief period of confusion as police officials started looking for that car, which Chief Brackett described as ``one of about 9 million white compacts in the Boston area.''
Information obtained at the gun shop would quickly resolve that confusion and send the police searching for another vehicle entirely, a black 1987 Toyota pickup.

Chief Brackett said records kept by the Salisbury gun shop soon connected a resident of Hampton, N.H., with the crime. But the clerk who had handled the sale, the shop owner's son, was the only person who could identify the customer. And on the day of the shootings the clerk was on a bus from Boston to New York City, heading back to college.

The Massachusetts state police were sent to stop that bus, but it had already gone across state lines into Rhode Island, shifting jurisdictions. The Rhode Island police picked up the chase near Providence. They found the bus, pulled it over and asked for the shop clerk, Fred Smith, who was taken away for questioning.
Smith, who was nervous but helpful, told the police he recalled selling bullets to the suspect and helped provide a thorough description.

Shop records were quickly located that gave Salvi's full name and address. Motor vehicle records provided a blurry photograph and the fact that the suspect had been issued a parking ticket outside one of the Brookline clinics on May 14.

Investigators went immediately to the motel where Salvi had been living. But they were too late. A landlady at the Beachside Inn, where the suspect lived in a furnished one-room rental, told them he had come and gone. The police later learned that he stopped to pack a bag and throw out his Chistmas tree.

Elsewhere, the police had already started to fan out looking for Salvi's local connections. They learned that his truck was registered both in New Hampshire and in Massachusetts. Old records sent teams of officers off to Lynnfield, Mass., a former residence, and to the home of an uncle in Ipswich. The uncle said Salvi's parents had visited for the Christmas holidays but were on their way home to Naples, Fla.

Investigators got the telephone number of a mobile phone that Salvi's parents had with them as they drove south. That information was conveyed to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which within minutes placed a tap on the number in case the parents were to try to reach their son.
``We thought that maybe he was heading to a summer home or something and that they might be calling him not even knowing what was happening,'' an investigator said.
Although the police would not release Salvi's name until early the next morning, when a warrant was issued for his arrest, hour by hour investigators gathered more details linking Salvi to the crime.

They copied the image off his New Hampshire driver's license, duplicated the photographs of several other men with similar features and then provided witnesses with a photographic line-up of possible suspects. Several of them identified Salvi as the gunman. The questioning continued until well past dawn.

Suspecting that Salvi may have slipped north, to cross the border into Canada, or headed south by plane to Florida to rejoin his family, law-enforcement officers were stationed at customs offices in Maine and Logan Airport in Boston.

Shortly before noon on Saturday, while the investigation continued in Hampton, a man stepped out of his black pickup truck in Norfolk, Va., about 450 miles south. Outside the Hillcrest Clinic, long a site of abortion protests, he fired, spraying the three-story brick building with more than 20 rounds and shattering the glass back door.

But this time, Ken Harlan, a Norfolk Fire Department investigator who was searching the site as a result of a suspicious fire on Christmas at an automated teller machine in the building, watched the suspect coolly fire.

Harlan, who was in plainclothes but had a department-issued 9-millimeter Smith and Wesson in his holster, chose not to shoot, fearing that pedestrians might be hurt. Instead, when the suspect climbed into a black truck and drove away, Harlan followed and called for police reinforcements.
Three blocks away, several Norfolk police cars converged on the truck. Salvi threw his rifle from the window in a sign of surrender, then gave himself up.
At the Norfolk police station Sunday morning, Officer Larry Hill said it took the Norfolk department almost 30 minutes to confirm that the man in their custody was the subject of the manhunt.
